*The Record of Zhou’s Communication with the Unseen*
*Sutra Title: The Comprehensive Record of Zhou’s Spiritual Communication*
*Four fascicles. Composed by Tao Hongjing.*

**Fascicle One**

The transcendent Zhou Ziliang, styled Yuansu, was a disciple of Tao the Recluse of Mount Mao. Originally from Jiqian Village, Du Township, Runan County, Runan Commandery in Yuzhou, he later resided in Qinghua Village, West Township of Jiankang in Danyang. His family was of illustrious lineage, renowned along the Jiangzuo region. In later generations, their fortunes declined, and they fell into hardship.

His grandfather, Wenlang, was nominated as a Filial and Incorrupt Candidate and served as Left Attendant in the household of the Prince of Jiangxia under the Liu-Song dynasty. His birth father, Yaozong, childhood name Jingang, was Wenlang’s fifth son. Yaozong held the post of Assistant in the Commandery and resided separately in Yuyao. He passed away in the second year of the Tianjian reign (503 CE) at the age of thirty-four and was provisionally interred there.

His adoptive uncle, Yaoxu, served as Registrar of the Prefecture and later as Consultant in the Yangzhou Administration. His mother, Xu Jingguang of Yongjia, dreamed during her fifth month of pregnancy that all the sages in a celestial chamber rose and circumambulated her from all sides. Thus, on the second day of the first month in the ding-chou year of the Jianwu reign (497 CE), at the hour of *ren ding*, he was born in Mingxing Village, Yuyao.

At the age of one, he was taken in and raised by his aunt, Baoguang, who treated him as her own son. From childhood, Ziliang was upright and intelligent, his nature gentle and refined. His family never witnessed him display anger. At ten, he followed his adoptive mother back to Yongjia.

In the seventh year of the Tianjian reign (508 CE), the Recluse journeyed eastward to the sacred mountains. Temporarily residing at Mount Qingzhang in Yongning, the Recluse entered the east. Originally bound for Yuyao, they boarded a sea vessel to Mount Huo in Jin’an. As they descended the Zhe River at dusk, the tide surged, dragging the boat toward Dingshan—a force beyond human control. They thus proceeded to Dongyang, intending to stay in Yongkang. Suddenly, they encountered a man from Yongjia who extolled the beauty of the local mountains and waters, so they followed him to the commandery. There, they sought out Magistrate Lu Xiang of Yongning. Lu personally escorted them to rest at the Hall of the Celestial Master, where Ziliang had already been lodging. Here, they first met. The circumstances of his arrival seemed divinely ordained, as if summoned by numinous spirits. Otherwise, the reason would remain unfathomable.

At the time, Ziliang was twelve years old. He sought to enter the mountain, submit to discipline, and become a disciple. He first received *The Register of Immortals and Spirits*, *The Five Thousand Character Scripture of Laozi*, and *The Talisman of the Western Marchmount for Suppressing Tigers and Leopards*, thereafter devoting himself wholeheartedly to the duties of incense and lamp offerings. Whatever he took interest in—calligraphy, painting, or miscellaneous arts—he mastered with focused attention.

Later, he followed the Recluse to Southern Huo. Upon returning to Muliu, he served with utmost reverence and diligence, day and night.

In the eleventh year, he followed [the Recluse] back to Maoling. Thereafter, he advanced to receive *The Charts of the Five Marchmounts* and *The Esoteric Writings of the Three Sovereigns*.

In the autumn of the twelfth year, his maternal relatives came to reside in the mountains, so he moved out to dwell separately in a western hermitage. On the summer solstice of the fourteenth year, the twenty-third day of the fifth month in the *yiwei* cyclical year, he suddenly fell into a deep sleep at noon in the hermitage. After a long while, he arose and emerged. His aunt, not understanding the reason, pressed him severely. He then recounted in detail what he had seen, as recorded separately.

From then on, for forty or fifty days, he felt profoundly altered. He constantly lowered the blinds, shut the doors, and barred others from entering his chamber, burning incense in solitude. At midday, he consumed only a *sheng* of honey. His family had long worshipped common spirits, and his maternal uncle and Daoist companions all feared this was a deception by mundane deities or suspected he had been afflicted by perverse *qi*. They repeatedly questioned him in alarm, but he only replied: "Perhaps it was merely a dream of *vārttā*—I know nothing for certain. I am troubled and anxious, so I have cut myself off." Thus, none could discern the truth, and they let the matter rest, observing his inclinations.

In the seventh month, he secretly received the true teachings, which instructed him to blend into the world outwardly while drawing near, so as not to arouse suspicion.

From then on, his diligence in service surpassed even his usual devotion. In the tenth month of that year, he followed his master to Zhu Yang. Later, when the master moved to reside separately at Shu Mountain, he remained solely at the Western Lodge, overseeing external affairs, receiving both Daoists and laypeople—all held him in love and reverence. By nature a gentleman, reticent in speech yet swift in action, whatever he undertook was accomplished in silence. His cultivation was pure and upright, utterly free of self-interest. Having long since cast off worldly desires, he secretly followed the hidden decree. Anticipating the need for a posthumous name, he devised a pretext to request construction. Though he built three modest chambers, the work remained unfinished for some time. By the tenth month of this year, he had quietly completed it himself, arranging windows, doors, and curtains. On the nineteenth, he invited his relatives and Daoist companions to contribute to its furnishing. Those who came to inspect it sensed his concealed form and sidelong demeanor, yet

On the twenty-ninth day, he was interred at dusk, and a tomb of fine jade was constructed on the eastern ridge. On the third day of the eleventh month, the *bingyin* day, he was again interred at dusk, and earth was heaped to form the grave. Thereafter, his voice and form vanished into silence, leaving no trace in waking or dream—was this the boundary between man and spirit, a moment awaiting its time?

The origins of his attainment of the Dao and his posthumous title are fully recorded in the *Account* he received, while the present text briefly outlines his deeds in this world as witnessed and heard, hence its placement before the *Account*.

That same day, four sealed letters were found upon his writing desk, their seals and covers damp. One was for his master, one for his stepmother and maternal aunt, one for his uncle Xu Puming, and a large one—containing four sheets—for the Daoists of the Southern Lodge and Eastern Mountain. All were farewells, each dated the twenty-seventh. Judging by this, he must have returned from Zhuyang and written them then. After finishing the letters, he burned incense.

Upon inspection, the warm wine pot still held the usual scent of alcohol, but the clay basin had been rinsed with water, leaving no trace of qi, nor any sign of medicine. The cause remained unfathomable. A prescription was later found in the *Account*, leading some to suspect it might have been the one. His master, lamenting the matter, regretted not having examined the letters sooner. Now, others meticulously searched through chests and boxes, hoping to find the lost *Account*, yet not a single note remained. Fortunately, it was recalled that on the sixteenth day, he had burned two bundles of writings—over a hundred sheets—allowing no one to see them. It was suspected these had all been destroyed, deepening the sorrow, which lingered unresolved.

On the first day of the eleventh month, the *jiazi* day, a trial journey was made to the cave at Yankou Mountain, where a large sealed letter was indeed found. Climbing the rugged slope, it was retrieved with a hook, and upon returning, it was opened with reverence. It contained instructions received five months prior, detailing only four matters after the Summer Solstice, with June and July fully recorded. From August onward to the seventh month of this year, entries ceased. The table of contents briefly listed events, merely noting their occurrence, leaving it unclear whether other matters—like those of June and July—had been omitted or simply not recorded in full. Perhaps they were intentionally left unelaborated. How could one know?

In the first few dozen days after his descent, he had found leisure and tranquility, but later, entangled in worldly affairs and the burdens of kinship, he could not escape others’ notice. What he committed to paper was only the barest outline. One can only imagine how much instruction he must have given in those ten-odd months—what a pity it was not inquired after! This was his master’s failing.

The sealed letters contained scattered and disordered papers, now arranged in chronological order. From the eighth to the tenth month of this year, not a single entry was found. As for the burned writings, they were surely of a different kind, for he would not have incinerated them one by one. Perhaps they were texts meant to remain hidden.

Previously, only a few matters had been disclosed to his master and maternal aunt. The first was his midday nap on the Summer Solstice, which drew strange rebukes from within and without, leaving him no choice but to explain. The second was his refusal to eat dried meat, which also provoked suspicion, forcing an explanation. The third was the true decree to change from vermilion to ink when jointly petitioning for rain, which he could not conceal. The fourth was the decree to halt his master’s summons, which he was instructed to reveal. These were the only clear instances. For all other inquiries, he remained evasive, never issuing explicit commands.

Earlier, after his master had perused the scriptures once, he had declined further visits and moved to Zhuyang. Later, when matters arose, he was repeatedly questioned and answered, but as he did not always respond, no replies were recorded, and thus nothing was made known. Now, upon reflection, it seems certain there were answers. Perhaps he feared that responding would invite endless requests, while silence would draw reproach. To answer fully would risk exposing hidden decrees, so he concealed them all.

The *Account* contains many taboo names of true immortals and various teachings, akin to sacred scriptures. It must be approached with the same reverence: washing hands, donning clean robes, burning incense, and only then reading it. If one wishes to copy it, one must first inform the assembled immortals and adepts—it is not to be treated like ordinary writings.

Around the dwelling where he resided, the courtyard altar was shaded by several large *xiang* trees. The one before the door was especially lush. On the fifteenth day of the twelfth month in the *jiawu* year, something like sugar was suddenly seen scattered all over the tree, with the middle portion particularly dense. Around dusk, Ding Jingda, the lecturer of Huayang, came to visit Xu Puming and witnessed it as well, asking in astonishment. Seeing this sweet dew descend, the household wished to conceal the matter and jested, “The children must have poured sugar on it.” They tasted it together—it was like honey—and hastily broke off two branches to display, hanging them on the door curtain, where they remained for over ten days. According to the *Illustrated Record of Auspicious Omens*, sweet dew falling on bamboo and *wu* trees is a sign of propitious qi. Upon reflection, of all the trees near the altar, only this one before the door was so luxuriant—surely this was meant to reveal that divine spirits had descended to guide him.

To the south of the dwelling, a covered walkway was flanked by bamboo planted on both sides, their roots creeping beneath the veranda. On the eighteenth day of the fifth month in the *yiwei* year, he and his uncle Xu Puming were in the main hall conducting a three-day grand vegetarian feast for the Xie family. After its conclusion, during the dispersal of the fast, Xu Puming briefly returned to the dwelling. Suddenly, he saw a bamboo shoot sprouting from the roots beneath the walkway, already over three inches tall and split into two stalks, both shooting up with tender shoots nine inches long. Yesterday, nothing had been there—now, it had appeared in an instant. Xu Puming, recognizing the marvel, feared his young nephew might pluck it, so he broke it off and brought it to the main hall, showing it to all the Daoists, who gasped in amazement, having never seen the like. The recluse deeply regretted not letting it grow into bamboo and, fearing it would rot, dried it by fire. It remains preserved to this day.

Examining bamboo, it is the essence of stars, often manifesting numinous efficacy. The people of Xiangzhou craft "united-heart bamboo," all awaiting the emergence of shoots, then carving notches into the sides to form openings—thus, a single stalk may bear four, yet this remains one bamboo, merely hollowed at the center on both sides. Never before has there been a bamboo that splits into two shoots from a single root, each standing apart. On the twenty-third day of this month, the summer solstice, this portent descended, surely signifying a hidden resonance of harmonious union, bearing the virtue of the parasol bamboo.

Moreover, Zhou Yi Zhu, a yang-dwelling official, had a house built in the east. Stacked thatch lay in the northeast of the house, and behind it, remnants of thatch covered the rear. When Zhou went to gather and restack it, he suddenly saw a white tortoise, about six inches long, its body, shell, and skin smooth as talc, save for four black markings on its back resembling written characters, though indecipherable. He caught it and played with it for some time, then wished to take it home but dared not, so he released it. Upon returning, he told his family of this.

Now, the tortoise is inherently a spiritually potent creature, long-lived and prescient, and it emerged from beneath the stacked thatch, seemingly to manifest the numen of Tea Ridge. Generally, white creatures are all considered divine marvels. When the recluse heard of this, he wished to record it for posterity, but upon further search, it was no longer to be found. Nearby Daoists often spoke of a white tortoise in Willow Valley that would vanish whenever someone tried to take it. It is suspected this tortoise was the same, though its appearance in the thatch pile several hundred paces from his home remains a mystery.

The above is recalled in retrospect, as I remember these two extraordinary events recorded in the annals. Thus, the account is presented.

Your Highness,

I, Hongjing, respectfully submit: In the latter part of the tenth month, the matter concerning the Zhou family arose suddenly. As I was then observing purification rites, I had no means to report it immediately. Now, I have meticulously compiled the recent events into four scrolls, as separately presented, and humbly offer them for Your Majesty’s perusal.

Yet, I remain entangled in the webs of doubt and delusion, having failed to awaken to the truth sooner. In hindsight, I reproach myself deeply, and fear my negligence may incur severe censure. I have recounted the details in full, and prostrate myself, beseeching Your Majesty’s forbearance for my lapses.

Respectfully submitted,
The sixteenth day of the twelfth month.

---

Upon reviewing the memorial and examining the relics left by the Zhou family, the revealed truths are manifest, their signs and confirmations aligning with earlier prophecies. The clarity of these two or three matters is all the more extraordinary. The four scrolls are now retained here, and the details are fully recorded in the accompanying text, inspiring only greater admiration.

The twentieth day of the eleventh month.

*Divine Brush*

---

When the Zhou matter first arose, I was in seclusion at Yugang, observing the Leaf-Limited Fast, and thus could not report it at once. Only after completing the posthumous records did I dispatch Pan Zhongzheng to present the memorial. It was received in the inner palace, where the four scrolls were unsealed and read in full. Every detail was scrutinized, and questions were posed on each matter, to which I responded accordingly.

*Account of the Zhou Transmission*

---

The fifth-month affair was transcribed exactly as it occurred. There was a recluse who instructed Zhu to annotate the imperial edict.

On the day of the Summer Solstice, a little before noon—specifically, the twenty-third day of the fifth month in the fourteenth year of the Tianjian era (the year *yimao*, *bingzi*)—I was resting in the southern woods of my residence. As I awoke, I had Shansheng lower the curtain. At the time, I was staying in the western chamber of my aunt’s residence, where she was afflicted with ringworm. Shansheng was the son of my two aunts, originally surnamed Zhu. At the age of seven, he fell gravely ill in Yongjia for over ten days, nearing death, when I intervened to save him and took him in as a disciple of the Dao.

Before I had fully settled into sleep, I suddenly beheld a man standing nearly seven *chi* tall, with a small face, fierce mouth and nose, thick brows, and a sparse beard. His complexion was pale with a bluish tint, and he appeared to be around forty. He wore a crimson robe with red shoes, his cap adorned with cicada-shaped ornaments and long, trailing ribbons. A purple leather belt, about seven *cun* wide, encircled his waist, from which hung a brush-case shaped like a dragon’s head. His shoes, dyed black and purple, made a rustling sound as he walked. Twelve attendants followed him.

Two of the attendants wore their hair in topknots, styled like those of the elderly women of Yongjia. This knot was bound loosely at the roots, the ends hanging down to the forehead. They wore purple robes with green trousers, their shoes loosely tied to the trousers, the bindings exceedingly slack. Three others were clad in purple trousers, their jackets gathered with flat-folded headscarves. Each held a bamboo slip, inscribed with characters that could not be deciphered. The remaining seven all wore white cloth trousers, their jackets tucked into their shoes, each carrying something in hand. One bore a sitting mat, another a *ruyi* scepter, and a third a five-colored feather fan. One carried a large scroll of books, another held paper and brush along with a large inkstone—black in color, the brush no different from those of the world. Another grasped a *jiao*, its form resembling a feather or variegated silk, mottled and lovely. The *jiao* was round and deep, its handle black and exceedingly long. After entering the room, they leaned it against the eaves. Two others each carried a satchel, as large as a small pillar, seemingly filled with documents.

The one bearing the mat unfurled it upon the book stand. The mat was white, luminous, its weave like that of a fine rush mat, though its strands were coarser. Six attendants entered the room and stood before the low table. As the man entered, he frowned and said, "This is far too close." He then took his seat, resting his arm upon the book stand. At that moment, the brush and the ruler—about a *chi* in length—lay upon the stand. He took them and placed them within the inner frame, then moved the frame to the northern end.

The room he occupied was the west wing, consisting of two chambers, separated from the main hall by only three bays of a veranda. He had remarked it was too close, perhaps because it was pressed near the hall, though the hall had already been burned to the ground. It was unclear what he meant by "too close." The room faced east, with a door on its northern side. A five-*chi* sleeping couch stood against the western wall—this was where I had been napping. My head lay to the west, allowing me to see outside. Another five-*chi* couch stood against the northern wall, where the low table was placed. A third five-*chi* space by the window held the book stand, which faced east. The inkstone originally sat at the northern end of the stand, the brush frame at the southern end, so he moved the frame beside the inkstone and rested his arm upon the stand.

He then asked those beside him, "Why did you not bring the desk?"

He replied, "The officials were on the move and did not bring it."

Then he said to Ziliang, "I am the vice-magistrate of this mountain’s prefecture. I have come to visit you because I admire your blamelessness."

Ziliang rose to adjust his robe but did not respond. At the time, I felt myself rise to answer clearly, yet others saw my body still outside, bewildered and unable to comprehend.

He then asked, "Today is an auspicious day, and the sun is nearly at its zenith. Are you observing the fast?"

Ziliang answered, "I follow the usual court rites and take my midday meal—though I do not yet understand the rules of fasting."

He said, "A midday meal is sufficient. But in summer, napping is not beneficial. Do not indulge in excessive sleep." He then added, "Your body is frail; even minor tasks leave you weary, and when weariness comes, you feel as though you must sleep, unable to resist."

He said, "Such small matters need not trouble you."

Just then, a gust of wind blew, nearly knocking him over, so he ordered his attendants to steady him. A child named Chidou was playing in the courtyard and ran up to the edge of the steps. The attendants pushed him away with their hands. Langshan then reached from a shelf to take a dam, but in doing so, he bumped into the attendants, and Langshan fell to the ground. The attendants caught him with their hands.

The visitor asked, "Where did this little boy come from?"

Ziliang replied, "My family is in Qiantang, surnamed Yu. We are temporarily lodging here."

He said, "Do not let him go naked—it offends the good spirits."

The little boy, named Chidou, was five years old, the son of Yu Sengxia. He said the child had suffered many misfortunes and was temporarily entrusted to a Daoist for care. In summer, he often played outside naked.

The visitor then asked, "Who is Langshan?"

Ziliang replied, "My family resides in Yongjia, under the patronage of Master Tao Ying."

He continued, "Master Tao possesses noble aspirations, and many seek refuge with him."

Langshan was surnamed Xu, a native of Lecheng County, aged sixteen or seventeen. He had previously followed a recluse back to the mountains but had since departed.

The visitor then said to Ziliang, "Your father once committed minor transgressions, but they were absolved three years ago, and he now dwells in a place of peace. He claims his tomb lies in Yue. Though he has wandered far, he does not wish to have it moved. There is a pit to the south—it should be filled. He had intended to come with me, but unfinished matters of documents prevented him. Next spring, he will be reborn into a royal household, for his past transgressions are not yet fully exhausted, and so he must return to the world. You originally planned to retrieve your father’s coffin in the year *jiawu* and bring it west, but the matter did not come to pass. The Zhou family is of the *jiao* lineage; after this year, when the years *shen* and *you* have passed, we may discuss it again. It was your father who did not permit the move, and thus he informed me."

Ziliang went to verify this and indeed found the pit, which had already been filled.

The visitor said, "In your past life, you were blessed to encounter the true Dharma. In this life, you have not lost the heart of a human or a spirit. According to the records, your great fate still extends forty-six years. Truly, while living as a man, one clings to the world, but as a spirit after death, one lingers in the unseen realm. If we speak plainly, the unseen realm is superior. There is now a vacancy in the prefecture, and I wish to appoint you to fill it. The details are nearly settled—say no more. Next year, in the tenth month, you will be summoned. Prepare in advance, for I have come to inform you. If you do not accept this appointment, the writs of the Three Offices will arrive—take heed."

Ziliang’s face showed fear.

The visitor said, "You hasten to remain in the world and accumulate transgressions—how could you be fit to assume a post in my grotto-realm? Facing the celestial perfected, roaming the sacred precincts—you should know there is no place in the world more exalted than this."

Ziliang then replied, "I can only defer to your guidance."

The visitor continued, "From your youth until now, you have not been without minor faults. Reflect upon them and repent. If you do not, they will become a burden upon you. All who cultivate the Dao must not go naked or bare their topknots, nor harm the innocent without cause. In all matters of conduct, eating, and drinking, you must adhere to the regulations. I have told you this much—my words end here. Now return to your duties. The affairs of your office remain uncertain, but the resolution is not far off."

"Take heed of my words, and do not reveal them to the careless folk of the world—those here in the mountains who share our knowledge will have no quarrel with you."

He then rose from his seat, and before stepping through the door, Ziliang saw upon it the names *Lingchun* and *Liu Bai*: the former was his aunt’s serving girl, the latter a younger cousin on his father’s side. The visitor added, "Do not let the children approach the altar or the oratory, for within the oratory lie true scriptures. The great hall’s foundation was lost in the previous fire, and even now, officials and guards stand watch—do not treat it lightly. The ignorant may act recklessly, but such matters implicate the household’s master."

"The gate lies ahead, with a chamber dividing the inner and outer sections. The quiet chamber and the altar stand beyond the partition. The scripture hall was burned, so the texts were moved to a secluded place. The hall had four bays: the eastern two served as the refectory, while the western two were where your aunt resided. On the twenty-third day of the fourth month of that year, the fire consumed all four bays. Your aunt was reciting the *Three Ones of the Yellow Court*, making offerings to the *Wei Transmission*, the *Su Transmission*, the *Five Marchmounts*, and the *Five Talismans of the Three Sovereigns*. The true scriptures likely refer to these, though I do not understand why guards remain when the foundation lies empty."

"Your aunt’s illness runs deep. Though it may not prove fatal, it will be difficult to cure." Ziliang then asked, "How might it be treated? And what of the mass in her abdomen—how can it be removed?" The visitor replied, "It cannot be removed at once. Over months and years, who can say what may come? The mass in her abdomen may yet improve suddenly, but I will speak of this to you another time."

"The earlier remark about matters implicating the household’s master referred to your aunt—thus I spoke of her illness without waiting for your inquiry. Your aunt is forty-seven years old and has long suffered from wind-stroke, with frequent shortness of breath. On her left side, a mass of qi the size of a cup has formed, which no physician or medicine has ever cured."

Lingchun and the others departed, and as the visitor descended the steps, he vanished. Though divine beings come and go without fixed abode, appearing as suddenly as a forest without doubt, there are times when they avoid others—lest the impure and base offend them.

This entry was recorded on the Summer Solstice, written on four sheets of white paper with margins. Following the previous account, this concerns Zhao Yubao of Hedong, known variously as *Siming* or *Bohuo*, who oversees the celestial registers, wind, rain, and water, as well as the administration of the Five Zhi, gold, jade, and herbs. Recorded in *The True and Unadorned Pavilion*.

That night, at the third watch, someone again knocked at the door, announcing, "Marshal Fan has arrived." Before a response could be made, he had already entered—a man of imposing stature, dignified and solemn in appearance, wearing a tall crown resembling stacked layers, and dressed in ceremonial robes. Only three attendants followed him, all clad in black, their features indistinguishable even in daylight. Outside the door, a radiance like a torch burned, yet no flame was visible.

The marshal leaned against a tree and spoke: "I am surnamed Fan and serve as the controller of ghosts and spirits in the *Dinglu* Prefecture. The *Dinglu* and *Baoming* Prefectures share the same domain but govern distinct territories, each guarded by celestial perfected ones. Both lords share the surname Mao—brothers, with the younger brother of *Dinglu* overseeing *Baoming*. You should already know this. Recently, a great minister toured the boundaries, recording the sins and blessings of men."

Having passed by your residence, I learned that the two lords and all the supervising officials of the prefecture have selected you to serve as *Baoji* Vice-Minister—a position newly established to assist in overseeing the registers. Though its duties are minor, its rank is lofty and its purity esteemed; ideally, it should be held by two or three who enjoy the patronage of the Perfected Immortals of the lineage. Your earlier responses to the minister were not at all displeasing. Why then did you later disagree with your aunt, thereby allowing the daily administrators to report the matter and inform the minister? Suspecting you of lapsing into heterodox customs, the minister was deeply displeased and wished to charge you with the offense of faithlessness—hence my dispatch to deliver this warning.

I observe that your worldly attachments remain unsevered, and the clamor of dust easily leads you astray. Why do you indulge the seven *po* while constraining the three *hun*? Truly, this stems from your long entanglement with the affairs of the silk-clan households—petty practitioners who boast of their merits to delude others, as if you were one of their flock. Had your earlier judgment not faltered, your name would not have been inscribed on the black tally.

The Zhou family’s ancestral rites are those of common gods—prayers and vulgar invocations, the very way of the silk-clan. Even Master Xu, when tested, spoke thus. Your maternal grandmother, née Du, was a great shamaness, and her influence lingers. Your mother’s family, the Xus, were once Daoist libationers, and your aunt converted her father’s branch to the Way. Thus, I feared only that you might be ensnared by vulgar spirits. Yet seeing you sink ever deeper into rusticity, I have come to admonish you in full.

Since you have not yet grasped the true purport, it is only natural that doubts persist.

Ziliang said: "I once harbored doubts, but how dare I now dissent?"

The Marshal replied: "The sacred and numinous have their own principles—how could they be debated in mere words? Moreover, you once served as Prefect overseeing Wu and Yue, entrusted with great responsibilities. When proclamations were issued, how could you refuse to comply? Your late father also petitioned me, claiming no heir remained, but I did not permit it. Even when he appeared in the netherworld to plead in person, I did not relent. Now, with a corpse defiled by death, how could a mere written petition suffice? Even if it reached me, I would not grant it—wasting only paper and ink. At the time, your aunt wished to submit a memorial and draft a petition on your behalf, so I spoke thus to put an end to it.

You burn incense day and night, praying for immortality and transcendence. Now that your wish has been granted, what more do you seek? As for the Second Perfected, he has journeyed to the Palace of Grand Primordial and has not yet returned. When he does, I fear he will question you, so I have sent him ahead to verify. You may answer according to your heart.

Your elder brother, the Second Lord, is the Great Director of Destinies and a Perfected of Grand Primordial, governing the Crimson City of Great Huo. He likely departed for his audience there on the summer solstice and has not yet returned."

Ziliang replied: "I am but an unlearned layman, unable to discern truth from falsehood. I humbly beg your indulgence and dare not dissent."

The Marshal said plainly: "Good."

He continued: "Each time you perform your rites, first complete the ceremonial obeisances to the four directions as prescribed, then bow to the Three Perfected Lords—Director of Destinies, Recorder of Deeds, and Guardian of Life. Since you reside in the countryside, this is proper."

At that moment, Ziliang had placed his clogs crosswise before the general’s seat and was lying down without his robe. The Marshal said: "As a Daoist, it is improper to sleep exposed or to place clogs crosswise. If clogs are laid crosswise, evil spirits will not fear you."

Ziliang assented.

The precepts warn: "When removing shoes, place them with the heels aligned and toes pointing outward." This is the reason. All Daoists should always wear sleeping robes, resembling short unlined garments. It is also forbidden to sleep with the topknot unbound.

Ziliang then asked: "Since the numinous ones have deigned to instruct me, might I humbly request an extension of several years?"

The Marshal replied: "Lower your voice—others may hear. Earlier, we discussed your doubts, and the Director of Destinies has already been informed. Now that I have come to verify, you still seek an extension. I fear word may reach the throne, so I tell you to lower your voice—not necessarily because I fear others hearing."

At that time, Zizao was also sleeping in a separate grove. The Marshal added: "What was previously requested cannot be granted. Your fate is already fixed, and this office cannot remain vacant for long. That is why I have come again in earnest—solely for this reason. Now, I speak to you privately—do not disclose it.

Since you lack the arts of deliverance, you must still secure a proper resting place for your remains. Only south of the great ridge, in the land of your ancestral gardens, may you find a suitable burial site. If that area is too stony, examine the left side of Mount Liangchang in the north—there should be good earth. Do not return to the original site. The original plot is defiled by worldly filth and overgrown with weeds; if buried there, it will bring you no benefit."

I have never determined where the gardens south of the ridge lie. Liangchang is some ten *li* northeast of Zhuyang, its ridges extending to this region, yet I have never heard of anyone surveying the land. Today, in haste, you have chosen this eastern ridge for the tomb. Later, upon reviewing these records, you will recall that on the eighth day of the eleventh month last year, the Recorder of Deeds declared: "Building a house where divination for burial was conducted is inauspicious."

When the house was first constructed, you wished to site it near the eastern grove, but the recluse objected, finding the grove too large and distant. Now you have returned to the western slope. Clearly, the current burial site aligns with the earlier directive, though it does not match this marshal’s mention of Liangchang, it accords with the Recorder of Deeds’ divination on burial.

Since you lack the arts of deliverance and must secure a resting place for your remains, this corpse will not return. Thus, I have sought a good burial site in cold earnest. The rest of the coffin and burial rites may follow worldly customs.

All the scriptures and talismans you have received may accompany you, but their divine guardians will require the names of your three masters, along with the year and month of your ordination. The Three Officials and water spirits may question you again—you must be prepared to answer, not left speechless. Leave instructions for your family to do the same, for this is following the master’s teachings.

You have inscribed *The Five Peaks Chart*, *The Transmission of the Three Sovereigns*, and various scriptures and talismans, stating they should be worn on your person. But I do not know who your three masters are—does this refer to the master of registration, the master of ordination, and the master of scriptures, or simply three generations of successive masters? I never inquired further, but scriptural records state that when a person’s life ends, whether they become immortal or ghost, they must pass through the Three Officials, all of whom require verification of lineage. Thus, the bond between master and disciple is not easily formed.

I now depart—do not forget this proof. Though your fate is fixed, you must still exercise caution. True caution repels dark evil, and divine spirits will guard and protect you, making it easier to attract blessings. Since you dwell amid worldly dust, we cannot return often."

Then, pointing to the peach-and-bamboo decoction written on the wall, he said: "If you feel unwell, bathe according to this formula. How did you come by this prescription?"

Ziliang replied: "I copied it from the *True Reports*."

The Marshal said: "This was what the Southern Perfected revealed to Yang and Xu—you have obtained it well. The Second Lord also marked it as outstanding."

Before his words ended, Ziping awoke, and the Marshal departed.

This passage records the instructions received on the summer solstice night, densely written on a large sheet of hemp paper.

This Marshal Fan is the Guardian of Life, one of the Four Ghost Marshals. His name is Fan Jiangwu, the foremost of the four, as recorded in the *True and Unadorned*. However, the reason he refers to himself as "I" and addresses others as "you" remains unclear.

On the twenty-seventh day, during the second watch, I opened my eyes to see a figure standing before me. His appearance was dignified, with a full beard, fine brows and eyes, and an age of perhaps twenty-odd. His face was most pleasing. He wore a lotus crown with long, hanging blue tassels, and his robe resembled a single-layer garment, though woven with red, blue, yellow, and white in a pattern like brocade, yet not plain silk. His waist sash emitted a radiance like the candlelight when Marshal Fan had previously appeared, though the candle had already extinguished itself.

The figure claimed to be from Zhongshan, and said: "Master Mao has appointed you as his chancellor. He has already sent the chancellor-marshal to inform you, and the matter is settled. I have now come to teach you the method of cultivating the Dao. You may follow my instructions and draft a memorial to Ziliang, then begin writing it on paper."

This occurred on the twenty-seventh day of the fifth month. Upon seeing Ziliang record the date, the figure smiled and said: "Noting the month is good, but as the years grow distant, those who see it later will not know which era it refers to."

Ziliang replied: "The previous chancellor-marshal’s arrival was already recorded by year. Now, I only need—" The figure then said: "Recording it on paper is best."

Ziliang thus wrote four characters below: "The year of *yǐwèi* under the Great Year Star."

According to this figure’s words, he was clearly not bound to the mortal world, yet the reason for concealing the *Zhou* seals and caches remains unclear. His intent seemed to be that the transmission should not be freely disseminated. The earlier accounts of Yang and Xu were also of this nature.

Those who become Daoist practitioners must first understand the essentials of longevity. If one cannot yet feast on rosy clouds and drink the radiance of the sun and moon, or discipline oneself to seek the truth, then remaining in the world is of no benefit to the body. The reason for summoning you now is twofold: first, to assist in timely affairs, and second, to receive instruction for cultivating the body. Over time, you may gain its power. Only when the five viscera are whole and the marrow is full can one truly seek the Dao. Now, your four limbs are weak and emaciated, your spirit and essence obstructed. The true destiny cannot be awaited in haste, but you may observe the two stars once or twice daily to establish a connection.

Ziliang then asked: "I do not know where these stars are located or what they look like."

The figure replied: "The Northern Dipper has nine stars, but only seven are visible, while two remain hidden. Observe them on the twenty-seventh day of the month or the third day of the new moon. Their forms will shine with exceptional brilliance. You may now draw the seven stars, and I will vaguely indicate their orientation."

Ziliang dipped his brush and sketched the seven stars. The figure said: "I cannot move my hands freely. Simply place the two stars at the head of the Dipper’s handle, and I will tell you."

After arranging them, Ziliang asked again, but the figure did not answer, nor did he respond to a second inquiry. Only after adjusting the planchette and asking once more did the figure reply: "This is correct. When observing, burn incense, compose your mind, and wait. If they appear, make your prayers and express your wishes—there will be other signs, which I will explain later. Tonight, during the third or fourth watch, you may try observing them, but do not let others know. If others are present during the observation, the stars will not appear."

The figure then said: "I will now depart. Do not lightly reveal this to others. There are also scriptures in the world, but you have the karmic affinity to receive this oral transmission." Without a sound of the door opening, he lingered and then vanished.

The above account was received on the night of the twenty-seventh day. It was recorded in a large ledger, with white hemp paper joined together to fill the page.

According to the *Separate Record*, this man from Zhongshan was surnamed Hong, named Zijuan. Originally from Mount Song, he had now come to Huayang, though his position was not made clear. Later, he also transmitted the *Cavern Chamber Sutra* orally from the Northern Lord. He was accustomed to instructing disciples. However, this person does not appear in the *True Reports*.

The method of observing the two stars of the Northern Dipper is found in the *Fangzhu Cavern Scripture*. Zhou had never before glimpsed the upper scriptures. His nature was cautious and upright, and he did not seek or request them. He regretted deeply that he could not obtain all the essential scriptures or meet the true instructions of Yang and Xu. Though he could no longer undertake this important task, he felt a deficiency in his devotion to his master.

These three entries were all from dreams, not entirely clear. In another dream, he saw towering cliffs and sheer walls, lush and verdant as if within a green cicada’s shell. Below the mountain, he looked up and saw two figures above: one wore a *yuanyou* cap and embroidered robes, and seemed to be the Lord of Life Preservation; the other sat high above, resembling Laozi, engaged in conversation with the first. Zhou could not understand their words. After a moment, he awoke, never knowing where the two had gone afterward.

The above was recorded from a dream during a daytime nap on the twenty-eighth day, written on two small sheets of white paper.

Upon reviewing the records, those marked as "dreams" were visions seen during sleep, while entries stating "on such-and-such a day, such-and-such an event was seen" were witnessed while fully awake, though it was unclear whether he was seated or outside.

From the eighth month of the *yǐwèi* year onward, he traveled to various places, but these were journeys of the spirit while his body remained still.

In many of the records, characters were hastily altered, likely due to the urgency of receiving the instructions and later recalling and revising them. Yang Jun had often done the same.

The above covers events from the twenty-third to the twenty-eighth day of the fifth month, comprising four entries, written on eight sheets of large and small white paper. All correspond to the catalog without omission.

*Record of Zhou’s Communication with the Unseen, Scroll One* concludes.

[Note: The character "弟" appears to be superfluous. #2 The character "其" likely should be "甚." The character "浩" likely should be "拙."]

*Record of Zhou’s Communication with the Unseen, Scroll Two: Sixth Month Affairs*

On the first principle of transcription, matters that remain obscure shall be left unannotated for now. On the night of the first day of the sixth month, all these beginnings were inscribed on paper, each dated to the year *yiwei*.

The former assistant reappeared, now wearing a *jinxian* cap, still accompanied by seven attendants in white as before. The objects they held remained unchanged. He settled onto a mat, seated beneath the southern grove.

Two youths, both around fifteen or sixteen, appeared beside him. Their forms and garments were radiant, each wearing twin topknots. Their robes seemed single-layered, yet resembled embroidered silk without being so.

The assistant spoke:
*"The appointed day draws near—no cause for doubt."*

Pointing to the youth on the east, he said:
*"This is the Jade Youth of Huayang. The Lords of Fixed Record and Life Protection sent him to deliver their message."*

Then, indicating the youth to the west:
*"This is the Attendant Youth of Ziyang. The two Lords visited Ziyang yesterday to recount the origins of your affairs. This is the source of it all."*

Ziyang then jested:
*"The great clan of Zhenxu harbors many whose aspirations soar like clouds—such principles are not confined to one."*

The Lord of Fixed Record replied:
*"This is merely what is seen on the surface."*

Ziyang laughed:
*"Should the Eastern Flower and Purple Tenuity burn their records?"*

The assistant said:
*"I believe these words truly praise you."*

The Jade Youth of Huayang then spoke:
*"The talent to ride dragons and ascend the heavens is not meant for worldly use. The heart that schemes for glory—how could it harbor thoughts of divine transcendence? Your mind is free of stagnant thoughts, your breast unclouded; thus, your success is swift. Without this emptiness and clarity, one might pursue a single aim without attainment, advance without turning back—could such a one achieve the Dao? You possess no renowned talent or learning, nor the beauty of supreme virtue. Yet you seek the green hues of fate, and though burdened by minor transgressions, your heart remains unburdened—this is why you have succeeded. Do not cling to the mundane, linger among kin and acquaintances, or yearn for wealth and sensual pleasures. These are but mountains of accumulated sin, cauldrons that boil the self. Reflect deeply on these words; do not take them lightly as mere amusement. If you transcribe this faithfully, the Way of Immortality will be fulfilled."*

Someone then asked:
*"What of Tao’s talent and discernment?"*

The reply came:
*"His virtue and conduct run deep—none in this world compare."*

Another asked:
*"Yet I fear his karmic conditions may not suffice—what then?"*

The Ziyang Youth responded:
*"Your words echo those of Ziyang. The Way of Immortals is easily attained, but human virtue is difficult to perfect. Though the two paths diverge, their boundaries remain blurred. The true Dao may be heard but not seen; the human path may be seen but its practices are rarely heard. As for humanity, all are driven by greed, cruelty, deceit, and desire, indulging their passions without restraint. Thus, the Three Evils never leave their hearts, and the Five Passions remain unchecked in their bodies—all due to the weight of sins sown in past lives. If one is born in the Central Kingdom, aware of the Dao and virtue, with a complete human form, bright talent, and steadfast conduct, it is because of the blessings of past lives."*

The transmission of the Lord’s words seemed to end here.

*"In a past life, you were already born into the Zhou household, a descendant of the Lord. Now, reborn into the Zhou family again—though of humble origins—your past merits have not faded. Thus, you have been granted study in the Immortal Palace and entrusted with duties in the Divine Bureau. The Lord sighed yesterday, saying: ‘Since we parted, centuries have passed.’ His earnest words to you are now complete, and his counsel as your teacher is exhausted. Strive well, for our comings and goings will continue—this is no long farewell."*

He then added:
*"The Lord has already changed your name—it will be conveyed to you through others."*

The two youths then exited through the door.

The assistant said:
*"All these words were taught to them by the True Lord for this discussion. I cannot stay; I will return shortly."*

He descended from the mat and vanished.

This record, received on the first night of the month, was written on two small sheets of thin white paper. The assistant was still Zhao Cheng.

The *Later Record of the Huayang Youth* states his surname is Jing and his given name Benqi, while the *Ziyang Youth* is surnamed Feng and named Lingzhi. According to the earlier passage, "your name has already been changed—it will be conveyed to you through others," and eight days later, they revealed the new names, which were still those of these youths. It seems they dared not speak of it at the time.

On the night of the fourth day of the sixth month, the Huayang Youth came and instructed:

*"Since you have shown resolve to align your thoughts with the divine, you must not harbor worldly desires or seek personal gain. If you fail to benefit others, displeasure will arise. In your service to others, if a superior reviles you as they might revile Jin, when you are reviled in turn, you must inwardly recall your body’s spirits—your ears may hear, but your heart must not receive it. Do not respond with words. If you are cursed as livestock or beasts, you must immediately bathe. Such words are grave defilements to the body; defilement prevents the descent of true spirits and allows evil qi to invade.*

*In the past, Liu Wenchang studied under Li Shaolian. Shaolian was cruel and immoral, whipping and berating him without restraint. Wenchang endured it and responded verbally. After eleven years, mountain spirits tested him, and he later fell ill with demonic possession. Now, he serves as a messenger under the Life-Preserving Assistant. Because of the loyalty and sincerity in his past life, he was deemed fit for service by the true spirits. Shaolian remains by the river, toiling day and night, yet cannot be seen. Take heed of such matters—can you afford not to be cautious?"*

Having spoken thus, he departed.

The above was a revelation received over four days and nights, recorded on a sheet of white mulberry paper.

Last year, I heard from his family that his maternal aunt often practiced the ingestion of talismans, merely instructing him to transcribe them. Once he began to experience spiritual communion, he would miss the appointed times for writing talismans and was also careless in his work. His aunt reproached and scolded him severely, saying: "Even a household dog must guard, bark, and chase rats. You, having been taken in, fail to provide proper service—merely transcribing talismans and copying texts without care. What use are you?"

At the time, his expression was deeply troubled. Now, this admonition has come to pass, and its source lies therein. His aunt, considering him young and prone to serving others, feared his mistakes and thus reprimanded him frequently. Thereafter, whenever he was scolded, he would rejoice, smile, and immediately bathe, to the astonishment of all, young and old. Yet in the presence of his masters, he never once displayed resentment in word or countenance.

Now, the cases of Wenchang and Shaolian serve as warnings. They are equal in the principle of being among the three [realms of existence].

On the night of the sixth day of the sixth month, a man appeared, his attire impeccable. He wore a cinnabar robe, a green cloak, and a lotus crown, upon which rested a small flat parasol, green with a purple border. On his back hung three green bells. He appeared to be in his twenties, his complexion fair, with a slight beard. Four attendants accompanied him—two men and two women.

After a long while, he spoke: "I am Deng Lingqi, the Immortal of Tongwu. Hearing that you are destined for the Dao, I have come to offer my regards."

Zili replied: "I am but a lowly and unworthy man, with little affinity for the true Dharma. By fortunate circumstance, I dwell in this mountain abode, assigned to the character *ze* [泽]. How could I dare expect the gracious descent of a true sage? Overwhelmed by my own filth and unworthiness, I find no place to rest. If my past karma permits, I humbly beseech your guidance and deliverance."

The immortal said: "Excellent words! Through a thousand lifetimes, you have cultivated abundant blessings. This meeting arises naturally—what need is there for formal instruction? Those who would deliver you will come of their own accord. I have come merely to praise your karmic virtue and to form a bond with you. Do not be overly modest."

"Others from Tongwu will come again. Receive them well. Now, I take my leave." In the latter part of the month, we shall meet again, for our paths align in leisurely wandering, and our thoughts remain intertwined.

Taking his hand, he departed.

The above was a record of the revelation received on the night of the sixth day, transcribed on a sheet of green paper.

Following the later separate record, Deng was first appointed as the Prime Minister of Tongwu, serving as the Imperial Canopy-Bearing Censor and overseeing Huayang, where he studied the arts of immortality and observed the prohibitions. This is not found in the *Zhen’gao*.

The statement "Others from Tongwu will come again" refers to Xu Xuanzhen, who would arrive later.

On the night of the eighth day of the sixth month, the Purple Yang Youth arrived, dressed as before. He asked, "Do you wish to know my surname and given name?"

Ziliang replied, "I would be honored to hear them."

The youth said, "My original surname is Wang, my given name Ziqian, and I am from Taiyuan. In a past life, my father was the Prefect of Chenliu, and we later moved to Danyang. I transformed at the age of fifteen. Due to the blessings of my former life, I was born as a human and, having further cultivated merit, died to become a spirit, serving as the Jade Youth of the Purple Yang Inner Palace. I was granted the surname Feng and the given name Yunzhi. Today, you shall change your name to Taixuan, with the style Xuling."

(Whenever the youth referred to "you," he meant Ziyang.)

"Do not change your surname; it shall remain Zhou. These names and styles carry profound meanings, which I shall briefly explain. *Tai* signifies the ultimate origin, its essence embodying truth. *Xuan* refers to the blackness of the void, a distinction bestowed by fate, not something attained through self-cultivation or merit. *Xu* denotes a form akin to the transient, a mind unburdened by trivial attachments, aligning with the true in desolation. *Ling* signifies one who, while in the world, communes with spirits and, upon leaving it, becomes a numinous being. This reflects the success of your inner and outer cultivation, which shall nourish your descendants. Such is a brief outline of its principles. There are deeper mysteries yet to be revealed, which cannot be disclosed now. Do not use this name in the world, nor reveal it to others.

Your style, Yuansu, is a fine name for this life, though it is not meant for worldly use—it is only to be employed in the unseen realm."

With these words, he departed.

The above was a record of the revelation received on the night of the eighth day, transcribed on a sheet of white rattan paper.

Ziliang’s brothers all bore names with the character *zi*. Ziliang was given this name by his father at birth, with no other childhood name. The style *Yuanci* was bestowed upon him at the age of seventeen in the *gui-si* year, when he underwent the capping ceremony on the eastern ridge of Huayang. He received it after burning incense and making an offering to his teacher.

According to the later record, the name he was given corresponds to the jade script of the Azure Register, and his Zhou surname was retained for this purpose.

On the night of the ninth day of the sixth month, Ziliang dreamed he heard a voice, though no figure was visible. The voice was lofty and stern, saying, "If you don the purple mantle and wander leisurely in secluded chambers, this is the beginning of the path to immortality." These were the only words spoken, but their intent suggested they came from a spirit of the Definite Register, a hidden message for him.

Awakening suddenly, he saw the former Attendant. The Attendant asked, "Did you recognize the one who just spoke?"

Ziliang replied, "I did not."

The Attendant said, "It was a Perfected One. It is not yet time for you to see him, so he spoke to you from afar."

(Previously in Huayang, only the Attendant and the youth had come, and neither of these two lords had descended. This hidden message marked the beginning of such visitations.)

The Attendant then asked, "Did you smell the scent of blood?"

Ziliang answered, "I did not."

The Attendant said, "Your body flows with blood, yet you remain unaware. You claim to have no blood, only sweat."

Ziliang replied, "I thought it was merely sweat."

The Attendant said, "What difference is there between sweat and blood? Sweat is the essence of blood. Human blood is like water—cold, it congeals; in summer, it clarifies. When clear, it flows; when easily congealed, it bursts forth like ice, and blood appears. Your reservoirs are shallow and weak, so the flow cannot be stopped. Human blood is like deep water: it is not troubled by excess, only by depletion. I possess the art of fortifying the reservoirs. I shall treat you. For now, await the embrace of the radiant blossom, which will bring subtle improvement."

"I shall take my leave now, for someone else has arrived."

He descended from his seat and vanished.

Immediately, a man entered, accompanied by three attendants. Approaching Ziliang, he said, "I am Zhang Xiao, styled Zian, from Li Jing in Rongyang." With these words, he disappeared. He appeared to be around thirty, wearing a purple square cap and embroidered robes, likely a lofty immortal.

The above was a record of the dream and revelation received on the night of the ninth day, transcribed on a sheet of white rattan paper.

According to the separate record, Zhang Zian was the master of the Xiaoxian Hall in Huayang, a detail not found in the *Zhen’gao*.

On the night of the eleventh day of the sixth month, a woman arrived. She emerged from the ridge, her appearance graceful and lovely, with a large topknot and a flowing cyan robe. She said, "Tonight, four individuals from the Yi-Qian realm intended to visit your dwelling, but since I am already here, they will not come. They shall arrive on the nineteenth day instead."

Ziliang said, "I was accompanying my teacher here and did not know there would be a visitation tonight. If I return to my dwelling to await them, would that be acceptable?"

The woman replied, "Since you are already here and it is late, there is no need to return, lest others grow suspicious. You need not mention that I came here tonight."

Ziliang asked, "May I know your surname and given name?"

The woman said, "My surname is Li, my given name Feihua. I am from Huaiyin and have been in the Yi-Qian realm for ninety-four years. Though I began my studies long ago, I have not yet attained advancement. I have come tonight at the behest of Lady Zhao."

She then took her leave, saying, "I shall meet you on the nineteenth day at the Western Slope."

Ziliang bowed and parted from her.

The woman appeared to be around twenty-three or twenty-four, and two others accompanied her, though only she spoke. One was likely her attendant.

The above was a record of the revelation received on the night of the eleventh day, transcribed on a sheet of white rattan paper.

On this day, the teacher left Bingwan and ascended the mountain. He returned to the eastern ridge after sunset. Zhou Xun entered Ziliang’s dwelling at dusk and stayed the night. At that time, within the ice-mouth chamber near the ridge, the divine maidens did not gather. The western inspection revealed disorder, and those who sought to follow him did not grasp this principle, mistaking it for mere sensual indulgence.

On the twelfth day of the sixth month, five individuals arrived around the third watch.

One appeared to be around thirty, wearing a yellow-flowered crown and a cloud-brocade feathered robe. Four attendants accompanied him, bearing purple-feathered staffs and holding flowing-gold bells—this was Perfected Master Feng, as recorded in the *Declarations of the Perfected*. Another wore a lotus crown and a crimson embroidered robe, with two attendants who carried nothing—this was Zhang Zian. A third had a black lotus crown and a green embroidered robe, with two attendants—this was Master Hong of Zhongshan. Another was clad in a vermilion robe with a purple-grass sash, accompanied by six attendants all in official garb, each bearing something—this was Registrar Le. The last had twin topknots and an embroidered robe—this was the Youth of Huayang.

Of the five, the first three sat in a row facing south, while the Registrar and the Youth sat to the side recording. The Registrar stepped forward and said, "This evening, exalted perfected ones have arrived. Rise, rise!" Ziliang then rose and bowed to those before him. They replied, "Be seated, Ziliang." Then they asked, "Zhou has cultivated merit and accumulated virtue—can this be said to fulfill his aspirations?" Master Zhang said, "The bright mirror of discernment should rightly illuminate his heart." They answered, "So it is." Master Hong asked, "Has Zhou not shown joy in his progress along the Way?" (The character *yifa* should be *xifei*.) They replied, "Though he may not rejoice, even if he did, it could not mar his golden tally." The Registrar said, "Zhou may indeed be called one who preserves the immortal’s path."

Then they asked Ziliang, "Today, with all these present, have you fully expressed your heart?" Ziliang answered, "To be so graced by the descent of the exalted perfected into this humble place fills me with both joy and trepidation—I know not how to compose myself." They smiled but said nothing. The Youth of Huayang then said, "You may not recognize all these perfected ones, so I shall introduce them. The first is Perfected Master Feng of Mount Song, the second is Immortal Minister Zhang of Leisure, the third is Immortal Master Hong of the Central Marchmount, the fourth is Registrar Le of the Bureau of Life-Preservation, and the fifth is I, the Jade Youth of the Celestial Minister of Agriculture of Huayang. Thus, I make their names and ranks known to you. Among them, any position here is as esteemed as a palace attendant or minister in the mortal world." Ziliang replied, "How could the lofty and numinous perfected ones be compared to worldly mortals?" The Registrar said, "*Youce* should be written as *yuce*. The obscure one here is Zhou." Then he added, "Now that the perfected have deigned to descend, each should compose a verse."

The perfected ones said, "You are the clear witness—proceed first." Ziliang answered, "I dare not disobey, but I fear it would be improper for one as lowly as I to go first." The Registrar then instructed Ziliang to fold paper and moisten his brush, dictating:

*"The radiant splendor illumines the jade grove,
A pure wind scatters the purple clouds.
Gazing up, I behold the perfected ones,
Riding the void through the green dawn.
They descend from the vermilion-mist pavilion,
To visit this companion in the dust.
There is a natural meeting of the Way,
No need for the heart to strain."*

Perfected Master Feng then recited:

*"The great aurora swells beneath the purple canopy,
A scene wind stirs the feathered wheels.
Straight to the ford of dust I descend,
Myriad impurities drench this body.
Were he not a child who preserves the Way,
How could one meet such a man today?
Beyond this, before the year’s end,
I shall ride the light to the court of the Great Perfected.
Though karmic ties may be bound,
Virtue must be steadfastly cultivated."*

Immortal Minister Zhang recited:

*"I inscribe my hall of leisure,
Wandering where the dust’s clamor reaches.
I gallop through the flying clouds,
Seeking this bond among mortals.
How wondrous is Zhou—
Able to move the hearts of the mysterious ones.
Let not your soaring aspirations wither,
Lest they break beneath the frost’s severity."*

Master Hong recited:

*"A numinous wind fans the purple mist,
A radiant cloud scatters cinnabar light.
The Eight Simplicities are not distant,
The Nine Abysses are not so towering.
Though aspirations and deeds may... (one character missing)
Cultivation may yet refine them.
Exhort yourself in this present task,
For the golden gates shall be our shared return."*

The Youth of Huayang recited:

*"The suspended terrace pierces the purple Han,
The steep steps ascend the crimson clouds.
The radiant splendor flies like a torch,
The Seven Luminaries each in their course.
I inscribe this passage through the dust’s filth,
To reach that transcendent lord.
Exhort yourself within these two years,
Let not the gates of the profane age prevail.
When the time comes for our meeting,
Why trouble with lengthy words?"*

When the poems were finished, Perfected Master Feng said, "What each has composed is sufficient for mutual exhortation and admonition. Reflect on the turning of the green destiny and strive to refine your single-minded devotion." (*Yundan* should be *lidan*.) He continued, "There will be others who come. If one can contemplate deeply and enter the subtle, ride the dragon’s chariot upon the misty path, and sound the phoenix’s call along the clouded thoroughfare, with divine youths unfurling their banners and jade maidens attending his carriage—why wait for endless kalpas? Attaining the Dao lies entirely within the square inch of the heart; there is no need for bodily toil or spiritual depletion.

Yet mortals only know of consuming elixirs and swallowing talismans, clinging to what is not their lot—such efforts are in vain. They do not devote themselves to accumulating merit and virtue. Though the Dao may be discussed when merits are fulfilled, it is only attained by later generations, not in this present life. These words may also be shared with your family. Now you know."

Ziliang respectfully assented and complied.

Zhang said, "These words of the Perfected Lord may be called the ultimate teaching. If one could further transcend and surpass this, then even the two celestial bureaus would find it rare and difficult."

Would the Leisurely Hall become Master Zhou’s place of wandering?

Master Hong said, "If benevolent merits are accumulated, might one be selected as a minor attendant in the Court of the Perfected? Yet this may not be the limit."

The Attendant said, "Once merits are fixed, why must one be so diligent?"

The Youth said, "What the two of you speak of is also what others do—there is no need to press one another. If one can accumulate deeper karmic merit, then one may achieve the work of a Perfected. Even if one rests, one will still not lose this."

When the Attendant finished speaking, they bade farewell together, lingering at the doorway before vanishing.

The above passage was received as a record on the twelfth day, written on four sheets of white paper. Among these jade-like beings, three have already come: Perfected Feng, Attendant Le, and now descending. According to the *Declarations of the Perfected*, there is a Perfected of the Western Peak, Feng Yanshou—this is likely the same. Attendant Le, styled Changzhi, was a native of Chengyang and oversaw disasters as one of the Four Attendants. The poetic compositions of the immortals and Perfected, in their talent and diction, are all quite similar; the *Declarations of the Perfected* contains many such examples, none surpassing the others. Examining the meaning of the words received in this descent, it seems to vaguely hint at the elevation to the Eastern Florescence’s Protector of Dawn.

On the night of the thirteenth day of the sixth month in the *yiwei* year, the former commander came and said, "Recently, the wandering descent of the Perfected Immortals must have brought you great joy. I have been constantly occupied, thus becoming estranged. How have you been?"

Ziliang replied, "Of late, heaven and earth have been clear and serene, the Seven Luminaries all bright. I have been fortunate to receive the descent of lofty spirits several times, yet my impurities and filth make me unworthy to bear it."

The commander said, "This is the merit of your thousand autumns. Do not lament your impurities and filth. However, during the time your sixth-generation ancestor, Zhou Mei, served as governor of Qiao Commandery, he was particularly fond of hunting, killing and wounding countless beings. Fortunately, he occasionally cultivated merit and virtue, so his sins have already been absolved. You ought not to eat meat again, for doing so may provoke retribution from your ancestral source. Take heed. The herbs of the immortals are sufficient—why rush to consume this? Fearing you might not understand, I took this opportunity to come and inform you."

Ziliang respectfully received the instruction, and the commander departed.

The above passage was received as a record on the thirteenth day, written on a small sheet of green paper. The genealogy of the Zhou family of Runan has not been consulted, so it is unclear during which emperor’s reign of the Jin dynasty Zhou Mei served as governor of Qiao. The fault of slaughter is truly grave, yet since he himself was absolved, one now fears the calamity may extend to his descendants, making it difficult to resolve. One should also establish good merit, so that one’s own blessings may flow to one’s descendants. This commander had one attendant, whom I have not yet met.

On the night of the fifteenth day after the departure of the man from Mount Zhong, according to a separate record, on the fifteenth day of the sixth month, Master Hong of Mount Song bestowed the *Scripture of the Grotto Chamber*, and so forth. Upon examining the case, however, this transmission was not found. Perhaps it was due to the secrecy and solemnity of the cultivation practice that it was not inscribed on the document’s edge, or it may have been stored elsewhere. This likely pertains to the external *Dou* method, its affairs intersecting with the previous two stars, which explains its continuity.

Master Hong, who bestowed it, was heard to reside in Western Xian. Later, when he moved to Zhu Yang, he slept in a grove where no evil person could approach him, and he seldom mingled with others. At dusk, he would always retire outside the grove—this must be the method of sleeping in alignment with the *Dou* in cultivation. This method belongs to the middle-grade scriptures of the *Shangqing* tradition, not the teachings of lesser immortals.

Another person arrived, youthful and resplendent, dressed in white, and conveyed a message from Commander Fan: "I previously warned you about consuming meat—have you still not ceased? Why did you go to another’s place this morning to eat dried meat? From now on, do not repeat this." He urged Ziliang to heed the earlier admonition and fulfill today’s expectations.

Ziliang replied: "This morning, I went to my master’s abode, where he offered me food, claiming it was sweet fruit. I did not suspect deceit. Moreover, having received this command, how would I dare approach meat again?" The visitor departed after this exchange.

The above is a record received on the fifteenth day. Written on a single sheet of white rattan paper, its quality closely resembles that of Master Yang’s hand. On the morning of the fourteenth day, Ziliang had already informed his aunt that he could not eat meat. That evening, upon entering the mountain pass, he again heard the same admonition as Commander Fan’s, and he immediately assented. On the morning of the fifteenth day, he entered once more and proceeded to inquire of Pan Yuanwen. Pan performed a ritual with him and urged him to focus his resolve, after which this message was received at night. On the morning of the sixteenth day, he again encountered the earlier admonition. From then on, he completely abstained from evil.

In his response, he later explained: "What the master bestowed was merely expedient teaching to ease reproach." From the tenth month of last year until the third month of this year, he had strictly adhered to a vegetable diet, but the hardship left him emaciated. His aunt then advised him to gradually reintroduce food, and he had only just begun to do so when he again committed this transgression. Not only was he constrained by the impending calamity from past misdeeds, but his indulgence also violated the nurturing *qi* of living beings, which those with benevolent hearts must sever to cultivate their nature. Thus, the immortals and sages make it their essence to abstain entirely.

On the nineteenth day of the sixth month, five women arrived—these were the ones Li Feihua had mentioned on the eleventh night in the mountain pass, scheduled to meet at the Western Bank on the nineteenth. The first was Yi Qian’s disciple, the Immortal Consort Lady Zhao, styled Sutai, aged around thirty, clad in embroidered robes. She is recorded in the *True Records*. The second was Yi Qian’s left concubine, Lady Wang, who had changed her style name to Taiying, aged around twenty, dressed in purple. The *True Records* mention a Wang Jinxian; this may be her under a new name. The third was Yi Qian’s right concubine, Lady Liu, styled Xuanwei, aged around twenty, dressed in green. The *True Records* mention a Liu Chunlong, but this is not the same person—unless she had changed her name a hundred times, which seems unlikely. The fourth was Yi Qian’s Director of Studies, Lady Tao, who had changed her style name to Zhi’an, aged around forty, wearing a robe of green above and purple below, with tadpole-script embroidery—likely the same as Xu Yuanmu. The fifth was Yi Qian’s disciple, Li Feihua, aged around twenty, who had come before, dressed in green above and jade-green below. The *True Records* do not mention her.

The names, titles, and Li Feihua’s account of these five women were all as described. When the conversation ended, the four sat together, while Li remained standing. There were also eight attendant maidens: one carried a towel case, on which was an inscription; two wore large talismans at their waists, each about a foot square, inscribed in black on blue-green silk. Another held a case, covering it with its lid as she carried it, within which was a pouch bearing a yellow inscription—likely containing scriptures. Four others each held an ivory tablet, their characters so fine as to be unreadable. All were dressed in figured silk robes with purple and crimson sashes.

The immortals conversed among themselves for some time, seemingly discussing Ziliang’s affairs, though their meaning was not entirely clear. Lady Zhao then addressed him: "Your dark affinity has long been evident, enabling you to summon and receive the aid of true immortals with joy." Ziliang replied: "Though unworthy and common, I have from youth followed the registers of the Dao, fortunate enough to dwell in forests and valleys. How could I have anticipated that true immortals would descend in response? My heart is filled with both joy and fear, leaving me unable to find peace. If my past causes may be considered, I humbly request the essential secrets of immortality to achieve accomplishment."

Lady Zhao said: "Your name is inscribed on the purple tablets—why do you fear you will not become an immortal, and seek this from me? I am but an immortal myself." Lady Liu said: "Zhou, do you know from whence your accumulated deeds and planted causes have brought you to this day?" Ziliang replied: "I am but a speck of dust in the mortal world—how could I fathom such matters?" Lady Liu said: "I will briefly explain. When you were born in the household of Zhou Kui, you were already destined for the Dao, but your greed and impurity were too great, so you did not attain it. In your next life, born into the household of Liu Wei, you gained the fortune of diligently studying the Dao, which has carried over to your present existence. You have been recorded in the registers of the highest immortals three times, but on occasion, you violated the proper methods and fell away. This meeting has been recorded above for over seventy years, which is why you have endured cycles of life and death. I have consulted the Recorder of Records regarding this matter, and he informed me thus, so I now reveal it to you, that you may know the source of your circumstances."

Lady Wang said: "Lady Liu’s words have thoroughly explained the hidden and manifest aspects of your past lives. You should keep this knowledge in your heart and not reveal it to the careless common folk." Lady Tao said: "Zhou, you were born on the nineteenth day of the *dingchou* year, a person of the Water destiny." She then asked Lady Zhao: "To whom does this one compare?" Lady Zhao replied: "There is no fixed comparison."

Lord Zongzhen of the Perfected was born in a *dingchou* year, a person of the Water destiny, and holds the rank of High Perfected. Zhang Suan, also born in a *dingchou* year, has sunk into the Three Bureaus. This is not a fixed fate, but depends solely on one’s merits and deeds.

Lady Tao said: "Truly as Lady Liu has told you, and as I have told Ziliang: Though the divine immortals’ responsiveness to profound mysteries is swift and effortless, mortal sentiments are too insubstantial and faint to summon such resonance. Those of us who come here today seek only those with the Dao—we do not wander aimlessly without purpose. Take care that others do not learn of this. Even if they do, it may not be so, for such matters might breed doubt and reproach, turning your heart away. I bear no ill will toward them, but fear they may bring retribution upon themselves."

Ziliang said: "Having received the descent of the divine, how could I dare to doubt? I wished only to present this to my teacher’s wife from time to time, not to reveal it to the careless common folk." He added: "Nor should you tell those of the *jia* or *yi* ranks."

Lady Zhao further explained: "The Dao of immortals holds subtle and hidden delights. Now, let me roughly describe them. Those who attain the rank of True Immortal repose in the Mystic Palace, roam the Purple Han, their movements unfolding the twin radiance of sun and moon, their stillness calming the winds and clouds. Clad in kingfisher plumes and flying robes, they ride upon maple chariots and divine pines. They traverse seas and cross mountains, wandering the eight directions. Advancing, they suffer no peril of water or fire; retreating, they bear no burden of wood or stone. Is this not worthy of being called noble and exalted? Yet people see only the glory of carriages and caps, the pleasures of the inner chambers, and deem these the ultimate.
