On the night of the eleventh day of the seventh month, Xu and Deng of Tong Bridge arrived, dressed as before. Xu approached and said, “Your name has already been submitted to the Eastern Flower, and you have been appointed as an attendant in the Office of Dawn Protection. This is a great cause for celebration.”

Deng said, “This matter was foretold yesterday. Ziliang, you have already roughly explained it to the various Perfected. But you are of humble and unrefined nature—how dare you aspire to rely on the favor of divine Perfected?”

Xu said, “Recently, I saw Zhao Weibo, who serves in the Office of Life Protection. He said: ‘Zhou Ziliang, styled Yuansu, is now one person. His name is to be changed to Taixuan, styled Xuling. Born in the household of Zhou Kui, his name was first inscribed in the Purple Register. In his next life, he was born in the household of Liu Wei, and his name was again recorded in the Jade Register. Having endured hardships, he now strictly follows the celestial statutes and is to be reported as a minor immortal, appointed as Attendant of the Protective Register. His feathered regalia and attire remain as before. The Protector of Life will proceed to the Office of Determined Records to examine the matter at length, then compose a eulogy to be presented to the Eastern Flower, saying:

*‘Zhou Taixuan possesses refined virtue, his heart and will empty and pure. According to the Purple Register, his immortal name may be inscribed.’*

The Eastern Flower then decreed that on the seventh day of the seventh month, the immortal officials would convene to review the register of names. Thus, your rank and position were determined: you are to be a middle-grade immortal, and a further petition has been made to promote you to the rank of upper immortal, appointing you as Attendant of the Office of Dawn Protection under the Han Lord.”

The document further states: *“Zhou Taixuan, styled Xuling, once nurtured the aspiration for the Dao and has now cultivated a vast and untrammeled virtue. Above, he aligns with the celestial principles; below, he accords with the terrestrial order. According to the immortal statutes, he is fit for the upper rank of the middle grade. As the term of the current Attendant of the Office of Dawn Protection nears its end, we request that Taixuan be selected to succeed him.”*

Respectfully submitted to the Azure Lord, the decree reads as follows:

*“Whereas Zhou Taixuan, by virtue of his deeds, has earned the inscription of his name on the immortal tablets, he is hereby appointed as Attendant of the Office of Dawn Protection.”*

This Han Lord inscribed the purple jade tablet with characters of red gold, addressing the Supreme.

I have heard that this position is typically filled within one or two years, and you will likely be summoned then.

Ziliang asked, “What are the regalia for this position?”

Xu replied, “It cannot be fixed in advance, for it depends on the height of one’s merit. In principle, it may include a cinnabar dragon and green chariot, a canopy of black feathers, a staff of white plumes, five jade maidens in blue robes, seven jade lads in red, holding fans of swan feathers, wearing crowns of divine support, clad in robes of purple feathers and crimson clouds, girded with jade bells. The Six Dings will serve as messengers, and the myriad spirits will be under your protection.”

Here the Master revealed the arts of divine transcendents and the methods of their instruction—no longer the mere office of a mortal registrar of records.

Thus, he pointed to what would come in due course, though it could not yet be shown to those near or far, serving only as a model for later generations.

Deng said, “The True Lord of Tongwu wishes to come, but must first meet with the Supreme Void and the Two Perfected of the Ministry of Yin.”

After repeated departures, he had spent the entire night in close counsel with his two disciples, fearing that if others arrived the next day and saw them in such disarray, word might spread. Thus, he kept it secret, revealing it only in private report. This matter, in fact, was precisely what the Green One had previously summoned him for—perhaps a reprimand or censure was due, as recorded in the celestial registers. Steward Zhao clearly knew of it, yet it could not be contested.

Upon reflection, though he did not yet know whether he would assume this position, he felt no great desire for it, fearing it might be a mere illusion. Yet this reluctance arose from his devotion to the Dao, for he had examined Lord Lao’s teachings and understood that the nature of principle lies in forgetting. He no longer clung to all that is conditioned, and his resolve to seek the Dao had grown faint. Thus, he surmised that he would not greatly desire the office.

Now that he had forgotten distinctions of acceptance and rejection, he would not refuse the task. If only he could benefit sentient beings, he would gladly endure lowly or arduous stations.

Later, he admitted that though he wished to dissolve emotions and scatter thoughts, he had not yet fully succeeded. This was indeed a divine insight from his six or seven past journeys on the Dao—his afflictions were not yet exhausted, and he relied on this faith and forbearance, hoping to eradicate them entirely. Whether it took five years or ten, he would not regret hearing of it at dawn only to perish by dusk. It was his wish.

Since Zhou had already seen him relinquish the matter, he wished to hasten and seek him out, following the separate record’s catalog.

On the fifteenth of the month, he received the *Three Heavens’ Dragon Script* for life preservation, along with its commands, and was instructed to blend in with mortals without drawing attention to his movements.

This passage, written on three sheets of white official paper, was the record received on the night of the eleventh. Within it lay the confirmation of his appointment, stating that he would not assume office until his predecessor’s term was complete. For now, he remained a provisional registrar, awaiting the appointed time before departing—though it was unclear whether he would truly hold the title or merely wander freely.

This was not a matter of personal desire; only when his topknot and temples showed signs of spiritual resonance could it be known.

By his calculations, he must still be in the grotto.

On the night of the thirteenth, Steward Zhao of the Celestial Registers arrived with them. Zhao said, “Yesterday, I went with Sihe to the Palace of the Supreme Origin and then called upon the Southern Lady to discuss Tao’s case. It was resolved in a short while.”

Ziliang asked when the summons would be issued, but Zhao replied, “It is uncertain—perhaps five or ten years. Though the matter concerns me, I must first report to the Upper Palace. I have been assigned to assist the Ministry of Destiny, so I dare not make a definitive statement.”

Steward Zhao then said, “I have been ordered by the Eastern Palace to temporarily halt the summons of Tao.”

Ziliang asked whether the summons was for a celestial or ghostly office. Zhao answered, “It is for the position of High Radiance, Director of the Penglai Waterworks, who oversees water affairs. He was reprimanded, and it seems they wish Tao to replace him. However, the summons has been suspended, and another will be selected instead. This is a celestial office under the Ministry of Yin, overseeing water affairs. Tao is being considered for it due to his merits.”

“Since Tao is a transcendent, he may not be aware of this. You may inform him.”

After a moment, Zhao added, “Fortune and misfortune in life arise from causes, not from the will of the gods. Tao’s thoughts tonight—how could he recall such things? Though he speaks of dissolving emotions and scattering thoughts, he has not yet fully succeeded. How could he let them go entirely?”

He then spoke of alchemical matters, but the details were unclear—what a pity.

He also mentioned that the Great Lord of the Azure Youth would arrive when the moon was full, and that Hua would be exempted from the selection of transcendents under the *Yang* register.

This passage, written on a small sheet of white paper, was the record received on the night of the thirteenth. It aligned with what had been discussed two days prior, around the middle of the month.

On the fourteenth at dawn, Zhou entered the mountain pass and halted the previous summons, showing it to Tao. When asked his thoughts, Tao replied that he did not understand the reason, but his expression was grim. Ziliang dared not press further. Realizing the gravity of the matter, he ceased discussing it within the pass.

On the thirteenth night, during the first watch, Tao was suddenly visited by six or seven figures, all bearing staffs, who swiftly approached the steps. The foremost said, “

Tao the Recluse, having received the proclamation from Zhou, composed a memorial on the fifteenth to present upon their next meeting, framing it as a formal response. This would have served as a reciprocal declaration, yet Zhou ultimately did not regard it as an appeal to the Dao—perhaps because there was no clear affirmation or denial to proclaim.

At the time, the August Emperor, in his grace, granted two parcels of land for Daoist cultivation in Changsha of Song, along with adjacent vacant plots to the west of this site. He further ordered the construction of halls on either side of the front courtyard, which happened to occupy the former grounds of Director Xu. I privately feared that such proximity to the true transcendents might invite reproach, and thus I heard of this matter only indirectly, regretting that I could not compose a more eloquent petition in response—had I done so, it would surely have been met with a thousandfold reply.

On the night of the twenty-fifth, I dreamed of Attendants Tang and Zhao arriving. Zhao said, “Why do you persist in such toil, depleting your spirit, straining your ears and eyes? Depart now, and spare yourself further hardship.” Ziliang asked, “Is it favorable to reside in this sanctuary? Lately, I have been constantly anxious about banditry.” Zhao turned and said, “This concerns Attendant Tang.” Tang then replied, “Though it concerns me, I am not at liberty to decide. As for calamities, even spirits and gods cannot foresee them. You need not fret excessively over this sanctuary, for it wearies the mind. As for Ziliang’s mention of bandit raids, he relies on us deeply.” He answered, “Take care and do not worry overmuch,” then departed. “Our discussion of fate and destiny is not yet concluded; we shall visit again.” I rose to see them off, and they vanished as they followed one another away.

This passage, received in a dream on the night of the twenty-fifth, was recorded on a sheet of white official paper.

That summer, the drought had soured the people’s temper, and the mountain’s venerable elders feared only alarm and terror. Thus, I sought their counsel through this inquiry. Attendant Tang, named Gongfang, was one of the Four Attendants, said to govern life and death, and to calculate matters of banditry—though it should have been Attendant Le who held jurisdiction, I did not realize it concerned Tang. In past records, whenever Tang appeared, there were always introductory exchanges, as if we were meeting for the first time. Perhaps such details were already noted and need not be preserved here.

From this point onward, until now, I have enjoyed peace and security. According to a separate record’s catalog, on the twenty-eighth of this month, Attendant Tang again spoke of banditry, urging me not to worry, and so forth. This was not made explicit, so I feared it might not be transcribed.

From the third to the twenty-fifth of the seventh month, there were nearly seven entries, written on ten sheets of blue and white paper of varying sizes. One entry is missing from the catalog, but the rest are complete.

*Record of Zhou’s Communications with the Unseen, Scroll Three* concludes here.

*Record of Zhou’s Communications with the Unseen, Scroll Four*

This scroll begins with the first communication on the twenty-third day of the fifth month in the year *yiwei* and continues through the seventh month of the year *bingshen*, with a monthly catalog of all recorded communications. The fifth, sixth, and seventh months are fully documented in the preceding three separate scrolls. From the eighth month onward, only this year’s catalog remains, with no further records.

On the twenty-third day of the fifth month in the year *yiwei*, during the day, Attendant Zhao of the Life-Preserving Bureau delivered a proclamation. [Text omitted.]

On the twenty-third day of the fifth month in the year *yiwei*, at night, Marshal Fan of the Life-Preserving Bureau delivered a proclamation. [Text omitted.]

On the twenty-seventh day of the fifth month in the year *yiwei*, at night, Master Hong, an immortal of Mount Song, and two stellar attendants delivered a proclamation. [Text omitted.]

On the twenty-eighth day of the fifth month in the year *yiwei*, during the day, I dreamed of partaking in the Golden Liquid Offering. [Text omitted.]

The above four entries pertain to matters of the fifth month and are now compiled separately in the first fascicle.

111 entries record visions, while one records a dream.

On the first day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, Attendant Zhao of the Life-Preserving Bureau, the Jade Youth of the Hua-Yang Agricultural Office, and the Jade Youth of the Zi-Yang Inner Palace each delivered proclamations on the practice of cultivating the body. [Text omitted.]

On the fourth day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, the Hua-Yang Youth delivered a proclamation instructing that when insulted by others, one should not accept it in the heart. [Text omitted.]

On the sixth day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, Immortal Deng of Tong Bridge arrived to form a bond of unseen friendship. [Text omitted.]

On the eighth day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, the Jade Youth of Zi-Yang announced the decree of Lord Zhou, altering names. [Text omitted.]

On the ninth day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, Yin of the Wen clan delivered a proclamation regarding matters of reclining in the outer chamber. [Text omitted.] Additionally, Attendant Zhao of the Life-Preserving Bureau delivered a proclamation on the matter of sweating. [Text omitted.]

On the eleventh day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, while lodging at East Ridge, the female immortal Li Feihua of Yi-Qian announced that five female immortals wished to come. [Text omitted.]

On the twelfth day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, True Man Feng of Mount Song, Master Zhang of the Xiao-Xian Hall, Immortal Hong of Mount Song, Attendant Le of the Life-Preserving Bureau, and the Jade Youth of Hua-Yang—a total of five—delivered essential teachings on longevity. [Text omitted.]

On the thirteenth day of the year *yiwei*, Marshal Fan delivered a proclamation on abstaining from meat. [Text omitted.]

On the fifteenth day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, Master Hong of Mount Song transmitted the *Cavern Chamber Scripture*. [Text omitted.] This record is now missing.

On the fifteenth day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, Marshal Fan sent someone to reiterate the prohibition against eating meat, stating that [the proclamation] had been issued after departing from the mountain. [Text omitted.]

On the nineteenth day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, the five female immortals of Yi-Qian arrived to proclaim the fundamental causes of life and death. [Text omitted.]

On the twenty-first day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, Attendant Zhao dispatched Huang Yuanping to deliver a proclamation requesting rain. [Text omitted.]

On the twenty-fourth day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, Immortal Xu of Cangwu delivered a proclamation regarding coffin matters. [Text omitted.]

On the twenty-fourth day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, Attendant Zhao again dispatched someone to deliver a proclamation requesting rain, following the departure of Cangwu. [Text omitted.] This record is now missing.

On the twenty-fifth day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, Huang Yuanping delivered a proclamation stating that his name had been removed from the death register of Mount Tai. [Text omitted.]

On the twenty-seventh day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, the Hua-Yang Youth announced the decree of the Register of Destiny, transmitting the *Mysterious True Scripture*. [Text omitted.] This record is now missing.

On the twenty-ninth day of the sixth month in the year *yiwei*, Xu of Cangwu, holding a canopy, and Deng, announced that their names had been inscribed in the Eastern Flower Register. [Text omitted.]

The above seventeen entries pertain to matters of the sixth month and are now compiled separately in the second fascicle. Three entries are missing, leaving fourteen now extant, none of which mention dreams.

On the second day of the seventh month in the year *yiwei*, the two Perfected Ones Zhou and Wang of Zi-Yang, the two Perfected Lords of the Register of Destiny and the Life-Preserving Bureau, Minister Zhou, Sima of Kuo-Cang, and Attendant Le arrived together to discuss matters of great discourse, as well as matters of concealment and fragility. [Text omitted.]

On the third day of the seventh month in the year *yiwei*, a female immortal of Yi-Qian arrived, stating that her name had been inscribed on the Green Bamboo Slips. [Text omitted.]

On the ninth day of the seventh month in the year *yiwei*, the two Perfected Ones of the Zi-Yang Register of Destiny delivered a proclamation announcing their promotion to the Office of Morning Preservation, along with the submission of the number of names removed. [Text omitted.]

On the eleventh day of the seventh month in the year *yiwei*, Xu and Deng arrived to discuss the verification of names inscribed in the Eastern Flower Register and the submission of documents. [Text omitted.]

On the thirteenth day of the seventh month in the year *yiwei*, the Lord of the Register of Destiny and Attendant Zhao delivered a proclamation regarding the cessation of the summons for Tao De and related matters. [Text omitted.]

On the fifteenth day of the seventh month in the year *yiwei*, the Lord of the Life-Preserving Bureau transmitted the *Dragon Script of the Three Heavens*, instructing that one should simply blend into the mortal world, refraining from extraordinary conduct or manifestations. In movement and stillness, act as you will; in coming and going, follow your inclinations—only do not violate the true Dharma. When practicing the Perfected Dharma, act in silence and let no one know. The divine luminaries do not regard ten thousand *li* as distant, nor mountains and seas as obstacles. In response to inclinations, act freely as you will—do not let us hinder you. [Text omitted.] This record is now missing.

On the eighteenth day of the seventh month in the year *yiwei*, I saw the Lord of the Register of Destiny deliver Tao’s response and inquire about his dwelling. [Text omitted.]

On the twenty-fifth day of the seventh month in the year *yiwei*, Attendants Zhao and Tang delivered a proclamation advising against overtaxing the spirit or exhausting the body. [Text omitted.]

On the twenty-eighth day of the seventh month in the year *yiwei*, Attendant Tang delivered a proclamation regarding calamities of robbery and disaster, stating that no precautions were necessary and no worries should arise. [Text omitted.] This record is now missing.

The above nine entries pertain to matters of the seventh month and are now compiled separately in the third fascicle.

Two entries are missing, and now seven remain, some witnessed in waking vision and others in dreams. Together with the thirty entries above, all have detailed records. Only five are missing. From this point onward, no further records exist, which is deeply regrettable.

On the first day of the eighth month in the year *yiwei*, Attendant Fan arrived with a proclamation, stating: "Today, the various Perfected Ones gathered to discuss and celebrate, and from now on, they wish for you to come freely and wander wherever you please." This visitation was not a dream.

On the fifth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I entered through a vermilion gate and towering palace, where I saw the Lord of Life’s Register. He bestowed upon me a luminous zhi fungus. The luminous zhi is one of the five varieties of zhi from Mount Gouqu.

On the seventh day of the eighth month, in a dream, I entered Huayang, first passing through the Palace of Life Preservation, then proceeding to the Office of Destiny to inquire about the whereabouts of the Celestial Dragon’s zhi in Xiaoxian. This journey went from north to south. The Celestial Dragon’s zhi is also one of the five varieties of zhi.

On the ninth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I arrived at the Office of Destiny and was questioned upon seeing them, asking whether I had joined others in a purification fast. That day, in the central hall, Wang Faming conducted a *tutan* fast for the imperial family.

On the twelfth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I rode in a carriage with the Lord of Destiny within Huayang, accompanied by thirty jade maidens playing celestial music. We visited the Southern Perfected in the Cinnabar City, where the Southern Perfected delivered a proclamation. They then reported to the Supreme Prime, who showed me the registers of immortality. Both Perfected residences are located on Great Mount Huo.

On the fifteenth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I traveled with the Lords of Destiny and Life Preservation to the abode of the Lady of Purple Tenuity. The Lady of Purple Tenuity governs the Dark Dragon Palace, which should lie in the north.

On the sixteenth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I arrived at Fangzhu and saw the residence of the Azure Lord, though I did not see the Azure Lord himself. Instead, I met Han Taihua, and Lady Song of the Vermilion and Azure Pavilion appeared, instructing me on the essentials of divine transcendence and the art of relinquishing form. Han Taihua was initially appointed this year to the Eastern Palace, where he received the books of the Vermilion Palace as a companion to the Jade Consort Han, as recorded in the *True Annals*.

On the nineteenth day of the eighth month, in another dream, I visited Fangzhu and encountered the Azure Lord on an outing, accompanied by Lord Yang Jiuhua and Immortal Marquis Xu. I then visited Marquis Han, who informed me of matters concerning the celestial registers. This Han is the same as the one previously mentioned in the records as the Keeper of Registers in the Eastern Palace, named Huiqi.

On the twenty-first day of the eighth month, in a dream, I traveled with the Lord of Life Preservation to Penglai, where I saw Minister Zhou. We then arrived at a vermilion terrace with towering gates, green eaves, and purple chambers. It was said that this was the Office of the Yin Bureau, where a certain Tao was recently appointed to govern this northeastern dark palace. Continuing on, I saw a person with a golden complexion, of medium stature, dressed in soaring-cloud robes and cap. He instructed me on matters of the Dao and its methods. The Lord of Life Preservation said: "This is Minister Zhou, a minor celestial official of the Dao. He has also expounded on many causes and conditions of the Dao’s work." Minister Zhou is the same as the Grand Guest. The *True and Unadorned* also states: "On Penglai, the Lord of the Yin Bureau oversees the world’s water affairs," as recorded in the earlier traditions of Master Ma. It is unclear whether his governance lies in the lesser Fangzhu of Penglai. Many matters of the Dao also appear in the *True and Unadorned Pavilion*.

On the twenty-fifth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I traveled with Attendants Fan and Zhao to Great Mount Heng, where I saw Minister Xue of Nanling and Minister Du of the Central Yellow. They bestowed upon me the method of concealment and transformation. Proceeding further, I saw a thatched hut, exceedingly tall and vast, with sweet springs and various flowers growing around it. Attendant Fan said: "This is the abode of wandering immortals." We entered together and sat beneath the hut, discussing matters of divine transcendence. Neither Minister Xue nor Minister Du appear in the *True Annals*.

On the twenty-fifth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I entered Huayang and presented myself at the *Dinglu* Register, where I inquired whether I might secure an extension until the tenth month of the coming year. The answer came: "It may be so." This still reflected an intention to remain in the world. The reason for making this request—though the initial response was affirmative—was the fear that further entreaties might follow. If, upon careful reconsideration, the extension were granted, then it would not be so; indeed, by the tenth month, I would depart.

On the night of the twenty-sixth day of the eighth month, in a dream, the *Dinglu* Register’s Protector of Life came to see me and announced: "Tomorrow, I shall again journey to Donghua to consult the Controller of Destinies. Since this is a matter of heavenly decree, I cannot act in accord with you. I shall instead seek out Lord Han to discuss the matter. There will be no further discrepancies." Some details regarding names and records were repeatedly mentioned, but these cannot be fixed, for advance or retreat still depend on the balance of merit and transgression.

On the twenty-ninth day of the eighth month, I received a summons to the appointed audience, where the decree of the *Dinglu* Register was proclaimed: "Lord Han holds you in deep regard; the records remain contingent." This encounter was not a dream.

The appointed audience was with a prominent figure of Huayang, named Jing Shangqi.

Of the thirteen entries above, two from the eighth month were real encounters, while eleven were dream journeys.

On the second day of the ninth month, I dreamed of arriving at the midst of Huayang, where I saw two lords.

On the fifth day of the ninth month, I dreamed again of journeying to Penglai. First, I visited the Controller of Destinies, who informed me: "To consume the divine elixir, your name must first be inscribed in the register of immortals; only then may you partake of it." Thereafter, I reached Penglai and met with Minister Zhou. He offered me a herb, resembling sophora blossoms but of a purple hue, and said: "You have not yet tasted this. Once you do, you shall become like me." He also spoke of fire dates and intertwined pears—these appear in the *True Reports*, though I remain uncertain of their wondrous nature.

On the eighth day of the ninth month, I dreamed of wandering through Yiqian with Minister Zhao, visiting the two palaces of Tongchu. The two palaces stood some five or six *li* apart. Yiqian was the palace of female immortals, while Tongchu was that of male immortals. Yet I remain unsure whether they were arranged east-west or north-south.

On the tenth day of the ninth month, I dreamed of accompanying the Protector of Life to a mountain, its form smooth and rounded, unlike those of the mortal realm. The mountain was called Danlong, and within its clouds lay a grotto inhabited by many immortals. Danlong, I was told, lay south of Yangluo and served as the administrative palace of the Southern Perfected.

On the fifteenth day of the ninth month, I dreamed of traveling alone to Tongqiao Mountain, where I beheld the Golden Court Lodge, resplendent with pearls and treasures. Its halls and chambers were arranged in orderly rows, their hues of blue and yellow all alike. I was further told that the Golden Court Grotto Palace existed beyond what I saw—this was merely a place of leisure for the assembled immortals, where their stewards conducted affairs, not the residence of Perfected King. When the Great Lord of the East arrived, a separate palace would be prepared, though I did not witness it. Tongxiang and Youbi, the domains governed by Perfected King, were said to have palaces both within and beyond the mountain.

On the twenty-third day of the ninth month, I dreamed that the *Dinglu* Register came to Zhuyang and led me to the Bureau of Destinies. Along the way, I encountered the Two Ladies, Xuanqing and Ziwei, who rode upon cloud-cakes accompanied by over twenty jade maidens. They addressed the *Dinglu* Register, saying: "The Controller of Destinies, Ziyang, has been delayed by mortal dust. His coming now is also due to this." This implied that I, a mortal, was the cause of his delay—though they did not refer to me as Chen Sheng. The *Dinglu* Register responded accordingly.

At that moment, I knew not where I was—only that I moved without conscious will. Upon reaching the Gate of the Bureau of Destinies, I beheld Ziyang, and we met together. He spoke at length of matters too vast to record in full. This must have been an extraordinary event.

On the twenty-fifth day of the ninth month, I suddenly dreamed of Zhang Li, the Master of Prohibitions and Decrees, reciting the *Daode* in full. The two chapters of the *Daode* are indeed the ultimate essence of Daoist scriptures. The Perfected One of the Great Ultimate also said: "Recite them ten thousand times, and you shall ascend to heaven in broad daylight." From the preceding account to this point, all were written in ink on large sheets of western hemp paper, nearly seven hundred in total.

On the twenty-ninth day of the ninth month, I dreamed of a thing in the northwest of the heavens, dozens of *zhang* in length, blue and red in hue, its head and tail of equal girth, resembling a rainbow. I went to Zhang Li’s place of prohibitions and asked what this thing was. He replied: "It is called the Beast of Dark Radiance, or sometimes the Water Mother—truly a cause for sorrow. That which is non-being within being is not as profound as non-being within non-being. The principle of emptiness and nothingness is difficult to fathom. This is the manifestation of the calamity of the nine-six, yet who among men knows it?" Zhang, as the Lord of Prohibitions of the Bureau of Life Preservation, was in charge of petitioning for rain and water, hence my question to him.

This matter is recorded in the *True Records of the Infant*. Zhang was skilled in discoursing on emptiness and nothingness, and his words always entered into such realms. The Recluse said: "Non-being within being is the emptiness of self-nature; non-being within non-being is the emptiness of ultimate truth." Yet these are mere verbal explanations—what do they truly point to?

The above eight entries record the events of the ninth month, all noted in dreams.

On the second day of the tenth month, I dreamed of Master Hong, who instructed me to recite the *Tai Su Invocation*. The source of this text remains unclear. On the fifth day, I dreamed of the Lord of Life Register, who said: "Recently, there have been many offerings to the throne. You must restrain yourself and not indulge your desires." This likely should read "indulge" (恣), for though there have been frequent promotions and demotions, one ought to remain diligent. On the eleventh day, I saw Ziyang, the Lord of Life Register, and Tongwu of the Bureau of Life Preservation, as well as matters concerning the relocation to Zhu Yang. The details are unclear, and I do not know whether this discussion was appropriate. On the eighteenth day, I saw the Lord of Life Register again, who said: "Zhu Yang is not a place for you to dwell. If you cannot move far away, even the left side of Zhu Yang would be better than staying here, though I fear you may not be able to remain there." On the nineteenth day of this month, the Recluse first moved to reside in Zhu Yang, and Zhou also came with him. Since this is an official residence, one must consider the possibility of future events that might prove obstructive.

On the twentieth day, I dreamed of the Southern Perfected One of the Purple Tenuity. On the twenty-seventh day, I dreamed of Minister Zhao, Master Hong, and matters concerning the stars. This likely pertains to the affairs of the Two Stars. On the twenty-ninth day, I dreamed of arriving at a place called the Palace of the Shade City, where many immortals dwelled, though I did not recognize them. The origin of the Shade City Palace remains unknown.

The above seven entries record the events of the tenth month: two describe visions, and five describe dreams.

On the third day of the eleventh month, I dreamed of Lord Hong and Minister Tang, who said: "The stars in the clouds have vanished; you should gaze only toward the southern mountain. Though this may be worth observing, it is not the true essence of seeking the Dao." On the third day, since the affairs of the Two Stars had been mentioned, one should not simply rest. On the eighth day, I dreamed of the Lord of Life Register and explained my desire to build a small hut in the eastern part of Zhu Yang, but I was unsure whether this was permissible. He replied: "The eastern side is a good location, but burial there would be inconvenient. A proper dwelling should be a four-sided courtyard; otherwise, you must at least construct a main hall with eastern and western wings. If you do not, it will be called a 'lonely and inauspicious abode.' Build it as you see fit, then depart, leaving it for those who come after. I have observed Tao’s intentions—he greatly wishes to test you. Do not fear others’ disbelief; if they disbelieve, it will bring me joy."

On the eastern ridge, there are two large hollows, both suitable for constructing a tomb. Initially, I intended to build a vast structure in the western hollow, but it would be better to erect an observation platform near the western hollow, closer to Zhu Yang. Zhou has now decided to bury in the eastern hollow, facing due south.

On the thirteenth day, I dreamed of Lord Zhou, who said: "Tao may or may not believe you, for he often likes to test people. Recently, you have also been troubled by many distracting thoughts; you must restrain yourself." He repeatedly warned: "Tao may or may not believe you and wishes to test you." Upon reflection, I realize there have indeed been instances of disbelief, stemming from my own wandering thoughts. All conditioned phenomena are ultimately without regret.

In Zhou’s affairs, I have been both modest and compliant, never acting contrary to his wishes. Yet at times, I have seen him preoccupied, acting carelessly, which seems inconsistent with the proper demeanor of one who attends to the spirits. When Zhou wished to build a separate dwelling, I readily agreed and even offered to survey the land, providing ten thousand coins. He initially planned to construct a three-bay hall with two bays for eastern and western wings. However, when the trees and bamboo were planted and the Daoist’s intentions were not yet settled, disputes arose, and the plan was abandoned. Only a three-bay hall was built. Today, I see how matters have unfolded so closely—clearly, this was not my original intention. Though I had some preliminary plans and still wished to proceed, the remaining instructions stated that only one bay should be retained, as it was a place for former companions. Now, everything is to be repaired to prevent it from falling into disarray.

On the fifteenth day, I dreamed of Lord Hong, who came to tell me: "The northwest side of your intended residence has residual qi. I will go with you to examine it." We went there and saw a man of extremely ugly appearance. The Lord said: "This is the Great Capital. It is inauspicious for people to dwell here; you will certainly suffer hardship."

After Zhu Yangwan and the others had surveyed the site, two or three coffin-like structures resembling ancient tombs were discovered. Though overgrown with brambles and weeds, the place had once been trodden by people, its buried dust now unseen. There was a site for shamanic rituals, said to hold residual *qi*—precisely the abode of wandering spirits. Yet since it posed no suffering, it was deemed harmless.

On the twentieth day, I saw a woman of extraordinary beauty, attended above and below by two maidservants in blue-green robes. She stood at the threshold but spoke no word.

On the twenty-sixth day, I dreamed of Zhou Penglai, who said: "The Northern Dipper has vanished once more, and prayers were offered to the two stars," and so on. This was the twenty-seventh, the day when the two stars were to be observed. But as the evening had turned overcast, they would certainly not be visible.

On the twenty-ninth day, I dreamed of the two Lords Mao and the two Lords Zhou, all riding in a carriage, roaming over Leiping. They went straight to Fulong, where the Record-Keeper raised his hands in greeting, as if bidding farewell. Leiping lies to the southeast of the bend, while Fulong is to the northwest. Ascending into the sky from the bend at ten degrees, they could thus gaze upon one another.

Of these seven entries, the events of the eleventh month: one records a sighting, six record dreams.

On the third day of the twelfth month, I saw Xu Deng—*Deng* should have been written as 邓. The two Lords said they were departing.

On the twenty-ninth day, the Tongwu Prefecture’s registry of penal servitude was found to contain errors, and three men were punished for the oversight of the guilty in the ledgers. And so on. Thus, the matter remained unresolved.

On the seventh day, I dreamed of going to the Bureau of Destiny to report matters concerning the Jade Purity and Dark Mystery. *And so on.* The discourse here was exceptionally profound, [lacuna] and thus not briefly recounted.

On the eleventh day, I dreamed of seeing Lady Han, who said: “Of late, my thoughts and aspirations have grown ever more detached, deepening into the true form.” *And so on.* This must have been Han Taihua, who was first initiated into the Eastern Palace as a consort in the seventh month.

On the nineteenth day, I saw a man driving a great carriage, his appearance most imposing, followed by ten attendants. He came only to bow before Wen Dong and then departed.

On the twenty-first day, the Record-Keeper announced: “The one who came to pay respects earlier was Cai Zijian, the Enforcer of the Deng Capital.” He had come merely to report that you were now overseeing his superior office. *And so on.* The officials of the Bureau of Life Protection all hold concurrent posts in the Deng Terrace Chancellery, which is closely connected to the Upper Palace—this pertains to the duties of the register of life.

On the twenty-fifth day, I saw Attendant Zhao, who said: “The immortal register is now empty—you need not worry.” Thus, in the seventh month, the Record-Keeper’s lament that “the immortal register has no one” was also a cause for concern.

On the twenty-eighth day at dusk, I saw the Record-Keeper, Attendant Zhao, and Marshal Fan. Ziliang asked what message had been conveyed, but the Lord had not yet received it. The Lord said he had just obtained it, then told the Attendant: “You may simply state the matter directly—say nothing more.” *And so on.* There seemed to be some hidden intent in this, which could not be fully disclosed; it was likely due to the Marshal’s lingering grievance.

Of these seven entries, the events of the twelfth month: five record sightings, two record dreams.

On the third day of the intercalary month, I dreamed of seeing Lady Han, who said: “In the world below, there are no longer any traces like this.” *And so on.* Lady Han was still likely Taihua.

On the sixth day, I saw Master Hong, who said: “Exert yourself diligently—encourage yourself in all matters, past and present.” *And so on.* This, too, was merely to urge and admonish.

On the fifteenth day, I saw the Lord of Life-Preservation, who said: “Do not let the matter of your house weigh on your mind, lest it harm your spirit and qi. The person in question will soon come to you of their own accord. In the first month, when you wished to build a house but hesitated, the master never came. Then you said you would draft a petition to inform the marshal of the county’s administration, and that he would surely come of his own accord—this is the reason for the present notice.”

On the eighteenth day, I dreamed of the Great Lord of Life-Command, who asked: “Do you wish to attain the Dao?” I did not answer, but in truth I did wish it. He said: “If you wish to attain the Dao, why do you not study the Way of immortality?” *And so on.*

On the twenty-third day, I saw Master Hong again, who said: “The one you asked about—the man who sailed the boat—was Gan Pu, an immortal of Mount Song. In a former life, he had dealings with Tao of such-and-such, but you did not know him in this life. How could he have come here? Last winter, a man named Gu Daodu returned from the outer river. He said that at Dalei, he suddenly encountered a man in a small boat no larger than a deer’s neck, poorly crafted and barely holding one person, who emerged from the waves and called out Gu’s name. The man said: ‘I am going to the capital and wish to send a letter to Tao Yinju of Maoshan. Yinju had promised to assist me in my efforts to present something to the Lord. The Lord was just then drafting a letter to bestow upon me, but suddenly said: “Since you will not go to the mountain, I will come down myself.”’ The man claimed to be surnamed Peng. Gu hurried to Guangling on his way to the capital to deliver this message, but when he inquired at Hua’s office, he missed the opportunity. He then entrusted the matter to the Daoist Qiang, a disciple of Sizhen, who recorded the details and sent them back. Yinju merely listened to the account without questioning its source. It seems Qiang had privately inquired in the unseen realm. Since this was the report given, the man should no longer come down of his own accord.”

On the twenty-fifth day, I saw the Record-Keeper and the Lord of Life-Preservation. The Lord of Life-Preservation said: “You have labored much this year, driving away and suppressing spirits and gods. The Three Offices have memorialized that you have committed many transgressions, but I have already rejected their claims. You should not repeat such conduct three times over.” *And so on.* How fortunate I am to receive such protection and favor from the divine perfected.

The memorial from a single office concerns but mediocre men—each of you should tread as though on thin ice.

On the twenty-sixth day, I saw Lord Zhou, who said: “At the eastern reaches of Mount Ge’s ridge, the waters have risen eighty-one zhang. The western flank of Mount Heng in the south has suddenly collapsed into an abyss.” *And so on.*

On the twenty-eighth day, I saw Lord Xu, who said: “Han Zhong has resumed his affairs. Now he and Deng will go to observe them.” *And so on.* This must refer not to Huiqi but to Zhong—also called Huolin, the Controller of Destinies.

On New Year’s Eve, I dreamed of the Controller of Destinies and the Southern Perfected. The Southern Perfected handed me a child, large as a goose egg, and bade me swallow it. The Controller of Destinies said: “The Dao is not yet complete; you have not obtained the Ninefold Transformed Flower. For now, eat this—it will suffice to brighten your vision.” *And so on.*

The above eight entries pertain to matters of the intercalary month. Six are accounts of visions; two are dreams.

From the beginning of the eighth month to the end of the intercalary month—nearly six months in all—fifty-one entries were recorded. Sixteen describe visions; fifteen, dreams. From the twenty-ninth day of the ninth month onward, all were inscribed in vermilion on large, pale paper, with one sheet bearing additional yellow-script text.

On the second day of the first month of the bingshen year, I dreamed of ascending to the Lesser Heavenly Realm, where I saw Lord Wang. He said: “Why do you rush so restlessly among men? Your name is already fixed—do not falter on the worldly path.” *And so on.* This was Lord Wang of Pure Emptiness of Mount Wangwu, chief of the Twenty-Four Perfected who transmit the lower teachings.

On the tenth day, I saw Lord Hong, commander of the Fan host, who said: “The coming year is wuyin, when the Supreme Mystery’s governance begins. You may don the cap of office.” He added: “Only the dwelling is not yet properly situated.” Lord Hong replied: “Even the great cosmos is ever inconstant—what constancy can human life claim? This place will do well enough.” He also spoke of matters concerning the *Cave Scriptures*. *And so on.* Though I had intended to don the cap that day, the master did not arrive. A light rain fell besides, so the ceremony was not performed. It was not until the dinghai day that I was finally able to assume it.

On the eleventh day, I saw Lord Zhou, the Peach Record-Keeper, and the Lord of Life-Preservation. Lord Zhou said: “Will you no longer pursue the true Dao? I am about to leave you.” Before I could respond, the Record-Keeper said: “His heart is not so—it is only his body that has failed. Perhaps Ziyang is testing him.” The Lord of Life-Preservation asked: “Why did you suddenly take three hundred *hu* of grain from someone?” I answered: “I did not.” He repeated: “Why did you take it?” I again replied: “I did not.” He continued: “If you did not take it, then why say so? There must be some other matter you cannot explain.” During these past ten-day periods, I have been constantly anxious and unsettled over the construction of the house. Fearing both bodily failure and mental agitation, the Record-Keeper was surprised. As for the grain, I heard nothing of it—this was the first I had heard of such a claim. Three hundred *hu* of grain amounts to one hundred thirty *hu* of rice, enough to feed an ordinary person for six years. I suspect this refers to grain meant for the master’s sustenance. Since I have long served as the master’s disciple, providing for his clothing and food, it would be improper to hold me accountable for this. I said: “I did not take it.” The divine witness declared: “To take or not take—neither should be falsely claimed.” He added: “You must reflect further on this.” This answer I did not understand.

On the fourteenth night, I dreamed of Xu Xianhou and four others conversing among themselves. Xu said: “This dwelling of mine has not been long established—barely two hundred years or so.” Another replied: “Cosmic kalpas pass in the blink of an eye; what is this to speak of as distant?” I did not know who it was, but someone mentioned that Changshi Li had built his residence on the mountain during the Yonghe reign of Emperor Mu of Jin—only a hundred and sixty or seventy years ago.

On the seventeenth night, I saw Attendant Dinglu and Tang Cheng arrive. The Middle Lord said: “What Lord Xu said recently was most profound.” Tang Cheng discoursed at length on the affairs of the Northern Terrace—too much to inscribe in full. The Northern Terrace is the Terrace of the Northern Emperor in Dengdu.

On the twenty-fourth night, Attendant Dinglu said: “When thoughts are not kept secret, impure qi cannot be distinguished—he spoke of refining and polishing, and so on.”

On the twenty-seventh day, I saw the Lord of Life-Preservation and Lord Hong. Lord Hong said: “Do not speak lightly of others’ affairs.” And so forth. This must be some kind of trial, though I know not what.

The above seven entries pertain to matters in the first month of the *bingshen* year. Four entries record visions; two, dreams.

On the third day of the third month, I dreamed of Master Hong speaking of the Northern Dipper. And so forth. This again concerns the two stars he oversees, for Hong was the one who transmitted the teaching, hence his repeated mention of them.

On the seventh day, I dreamed that Attendant Dinglu said: “In the mountains of Linhai, where the forests have burned, a transcendent wanders among the people, calling himself Master Peng. In truth, he is Zheng Xuan, styled Ziyin, the immortal of Luhun. Zhu Jiaofu sent him to observe the dispositions of men and those who cultivate the Dao. He may come seeking you soon—he has already gone to Jian’an. A man of Linhai wrote to the Daoist Zou Yao, saying: ‘Master Peng is here, and I, Yao, have not yet been able to withdraw into quietude, so others have been able to meet him.’ The man swiftly boarded a small boat with a single oar. He sang:

*How vast and dark the Great Empyrean,
The numinous ones descend in timely flight.
They charge me to sweep the dust from the path,
To seek and examine the companions of the clouds.
The world’s roads are steeped in defilement,
True sincerity cannot be fathomed.
I urge my carriage back to Lu Ridge—
In the human realm, none are my match.*

He also chanted this while walking. If he comes, do not receive him.” The man appeared of middling stature, with a purple mark on the left side of his face. He wore a yellow silk cap, had a full beard, and was missing his front teeth. This entry is recorded in such detail, perhaps to provide a sign for later generations. The “burned mountain” is Red Water Mountain, now part of Yongning District, though it may lie at the border of three counties. I do not know where Zou Yao is from, but his appearance and attire are so distinctive that he should be easy to recognize—though I fear he may alter his form if he knows others can identify him.

On the ninth day, I saw Attendant Zhao, who said: “Lately, your spirit and will—why are they so listless?” And so forth.

On the fourteenth day, I saw Attendant Dinglu, who said: “The Lord of Life will come in the middle of next month, and the West Palace’s Attendant Shu will also arrive together—thus I forewarn you.” And so forth. This likely refers to the eighteenth day of the third month, as I have seen a written record of his words from that day.

On the twentieth day, I dreamed of the Lord of Life. Upon meeting him, he ordered me to fetch a green *ci*-chapter—this single character is blurred beyond recognition. I presented it to the Lord of Life, who said: “This will do, but your heart is not yet true. You must further refine and polish it.” Later, I saw Attendant Jingshang, who said: “The two lords have now gone to Tortoise Mountain. I pass this on so you may know. Your emotions stirred, and after jesting with someone earlier, you allowed demonic influences to encroach. Fortunately, Senior Overseer Gao intervened, or it might have led to disaster. I heard Zhou was in the capital and suddenly suffered from pain and fear—this was likely the reason.” I do not know who Senior Overseer Gao is; he is not among those in the grotto. He also said: “The man who wraps his house and claims not to be a Daoist is an agent of the Northern Star’s Ghost Official—do not trust him. His perverse desires swiftly delude people and corrupt their true *qi*. Hurry to Xu; he has already departed far and cannot stay long—leave at once.”

Zhou remained in the capital and stayed with Wang Faming in the Daoist lodge of the Southern Yushu Residence, sleeping in the outer chamber. Was this to consult the wooden divination blocks? That is how he came by this. I told him that many others had inquired about the blocks, but he said nothing in the capital—this matter truly requires discretion.

On the twenty-fifth day, Attendant Tang Zhao arrived and said he had returned to his former residence. Together, we felt a profound emptiness and discussed the Ninefold Refinement at length. And so forth—both lords instructed him to convey this. And so forth. It was the twenty-second or twenty-third day when he returned to the mountain, but he was utterly unwilling to entertain visitors’ questions. No word of the Ninefold Refinement reached me—how lamentable!

The above six entries were recorded in the second month: five describe encounters, and one a dream.

On the third day of the third month, I saw the Lord of Longevity, who warned against eating the heart of grass and other matters. And so forth. The *Purple Text of the Immortals’ Taboos* states this, though it refers only to this single day.

On the eighth day, I saw Attendant Zhao, who spoke of the world’s demonic spirits and urged caution in all things. And so forth.

On the twenty-ninth day, I saw the Lord of Longevity, who warned: “Do not violate the mist and dew.” And so forth.

The above three entries pertain to the third month, all describing encounters.

On the ninth day of the fourth month, I saw Attendant Dinglu, who said: “The earlier memorial’s language was most refined, though I fear your heart may not fully align with it.” And so forth. I have not seen the original text of this memorial.

On the fifteenth day, I saw the Three Attendants and Lord Hong arrive, who said: “We wish to descend to the capital to expel evil, but do not fail to return to the mountains.” The various individuals conversed among themselves, much of it unclear. At that time, I intended to leave the capital to settle matters below, and indeed departed in the sixth month [gap in text].

The above two entries pertain to the fourth month, both describing encounters.

On the ninth day of the fifth month, I dreamed of the Lord of Life Span, Attendant Dinglu, the Lord of Longevity, and a host of perfected beings, all of whom tested me regarding matters of karmic obstructions. And so forth. Their countenances were displeased, and they also spoke of concerns about theft, saying they would come to my aid at the time.

On the fifteenth day, I dreamed of arriving at the Eastern Palace, where I paid respects to the Azure Lord. Though I did not meet the Azure Lord face-to-face, his sentiments were conveyed through messengers, showing great compassion. Lord Han received and conversed with me as usual. Such an account suggests that the previous Lord Han and his retinue were not Huixi.

On the twenty-ninth day, I dreamed of the Three Lords of Life Span, who said: “Previously, we dispatched ten guards from the outer defenses of Red City to assist you, but you were unable to reach the capital.” This passage is written in hasty script and is illegible. It also states: “It may suffice.” I do not understand what this refers to. If it concerns the earlier matter of theft and the promise of aid, then it should not have said, “It may suffice.”

At that time, the capital was indeed in a state of tranquility.

*(The preceding three entries pertain to events of the fifth month. All were said to have been seen from the first month to this point, written on yellow paper with fine-grade paper for details, totaling four and a half sheets. The first sheet bore a vermilion inscription from the end of the previous year.)*

On the tenth day of the sixth month, while sleeping on the road, I dreamed of Marshal Fan, who said: “Malevolent spirits rampage unchecked—do not take them lightly. Though they are not human, why should your relations with them be so poor?” And so on.

Zhou briefly left the capital on the ninth day of this month at dawn, lodging by the ferry after exiting the mountains. He departed early on the tenth, and by that evening, he should have been near Hushu and Fangshan. He is expected to return within this month, though warm-illnesses have been prevalent of late.

On the nineteenth day, while at home, I dreamed of abstaining from meat and eating only goose fat—its meaning remains unclear. Upon reviewing this day’s events, I recall that Wang Faming’s son stayed overnight at the guesthouse, and Yanling’s Ji Maoxian also arrived with many provisions. In the food prepared by Guo Yi’s household, goose fat must have been used for frying or boiling.

On the evening of the twenty-eighth day, I dreamed of wandering through the Purple Forbidden Enclosure. And so on.

Here follows the translation:

---

The above three entries pertain to matters of the sixth month. One records what was seen, and two record dreams.

On the first day of the seventh month, I met with Master Hong, who said: "Beyond the eightfold radiance, your dwelling has already been arranged. There is no need to prepare the bundled herbs." And so on—much of it cannot be fully recorded. Herein should be discussed matters of departure and staying, and the gathering of texts.

On the eighth day, I dreamed again of Marquis Han, the Purple Forbidden Enclosure, Master Yang, and the Register of Destiny. Much was said concerning the subtleties of nature and life, tracing the roots of sin and fortune. Had it been written down, it would have filled three or four sheets of paper. Not to have heard it is a deep regret.

On the seventeenth day, I met with Attendant Zhao of the Preservation of Life. Much was discussed regarding the calamities and disasters of Heaven and Earth—too much to record. The principles of these matters are difficult to expound.

On the twenty-third day, I saw a gathering of immortals, thirty in all. Much was said on the fundamentals of human cultivation and the methods of averting misfortune. They also discussed the work of the Ninefold Transmutation. And so on. This entry, being unclear, is the deepest regret.

The above four entries pertain to matters of the seventh month. Three record what was seen, and one records a dream. Since the beginning of the sixth month, all together they fill one large sheet of white *zhan* paper.

From the first month to the end of the seventh month of the *bingshen* year, nearly seven months have passed, comprising twenty-eight entries in total. Eighteen record what was seen, and ten record dreams.

The above is the table of contents. It is written in three colors—black, vermilion, and yellow—on large white and fine paper, totaling sixteen folios: eight white and eight colored.

From the initial communication on the twenty-third day of the fifth month of the *yiwei* year to the end of the seventh month of the present *bingshen* year, there are altogether one hundred and nine entries: sixty-three recording what was seen, and forty-six recording dreams.

From the eighth month to the twenty-seventh day of the tenth month, when I departed this world, a span of three months, the written records are no longer clearly preserved.

Reviewing the entries made month by month since the beginning of this year, I have been careless and do not know if they are complete. Perhaps the times have grown sparse, and so I have not recorded everything.

Recorded by Zhou Ziyang, *The Elixir Formula of the Jade Fluid of the Nine Perfected*.

It is said to be lighter than the Ninefold Transmutation and easier than the Ninefold Transmutation. This is on a separate sheet, without date.

One *jin* of the nine-stemmed purple fungus, *langge* zhi. It comes from southern Min, and is also found north of Juqu.

Two *dou* of cinnabar-red jade nectar. It comes from southern Min, and is also found in this region.

For the above two ingredients, finely chop the fungus, then soak it overnight in one *dou* of jade nectar. Bury it on the yang side of a shaded wall, three *cun* from the wall and one *chi* deep in the earth. Use a white ceramic vessel holding about four *dou* to contain it, and cover it with a ceramic plate. Seal it tightly with wax, then cover it with two *cun* of earth. Bury it at noon today and retrieve it at noon tomorrow. Carry it southward to a point twelve paces from the door of your dwelling, and place it at the head of a sleeping grove.

From the time of retrieval until noon the following day, boil it in a bronze vessel, ensuring the fire is level with the bottom of the vessel and does not flare beyond its edges. After three boilings, add the remaining *dou* of jade nectar, then increase the fire by about five *fen*, using mugwort or thatch as fuel. Reduce it until only one *dou* remains, then dry the dregs and seal the liquid for three days. After three days, open it: a purple radiance should shine forth, visible even at night without lamplight. This indicates the elixir is complete.

Next, place the dregs in a wooden mortar and pound them three hundred and twenty times. Wrap them tightly in paper. If thrown into water, the water will halt in its flow. If used to seal a house, ten thousand men could not open it. If used to bind bandits, a mob could not move. If used to seal a mountain, the mountain will open; if used to seal a person, the person will submit.

If one wishes to ascend to Heaven swiftly, one may consume both the liquid and the dregs together—though this will result in death. If one wishes to remain in the world for a time, one should consume them gradually, and in the end, one will attain immortality.

Do not share this with others or let anyone witness its use. It may only be known in the heart and consumed in secret. If others learn of it, this medicine will be wasted in vain.

The above is one formula, without year, month, or day. It is not known when it was written, but it fills one sheet of white *zhan* paper.

Respectfully corrected.

The name of this medicine is also said to be "known only in the heart," making it difficult to ponder in detail. I have inquired of all those living with me, young and old alike, and none recall seeing the medicine buried within the wall, nor hearing the sound of pounding in the wooden mortar. Perhaps it was prepared elsewhere—no matter. It is said that consuming it results in death, which gives me pause. Even if warm wine is offered, it may be a ruse to confuse.

In all, there are four volumes of the original text, written in various colors, totaling sixty-five folios, some in standard script, some in cursive.

*Comprehensive Records of the Zhou Clan, Volume Four* ends here.

chunks.original_text: 周氏冥通记 经名:周氏具通记。 四卷。 陶弘景撰。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞真部记传类。 周氏冥通记卷之一 玄人周子良，字元稣，茅山陶隐居之弟子也。 本豫州汝南郡汝南县都乡吉迁里人，寓居丹阳建康西乡清化里，世为冑族，江左有闻。 晚叶雕流，沦胥以瘁。 祖文朗，举秀才，宋江夏王国左常侍。 所生父耀宗，小名金刚，文朗第五子，郡五官缘，别住余姚，天监二年亡，年三十四，仍假葬焉。 所继伯父耀旭，本州主簿，扬州议曹从事。 母永嘉徐净光，怀娠五月，梦一切仙室中圣皆起行，四面来绕己身，乃以建武四年丁丑岁正月二日人定时生於余姚明星里。 期岁，为姨宝光所摄养，同如母之义。 子良幼植端惠，立性和雅，家人未尝见其愠色。 十岁随其所养母还永嘉。 天监七年，隐居束游海岳，权住永宁青幛山Q隐居入束，本往余姚，乘海舫取晋安霍山。 平晚下浙江，而潮来掣船，直向定山，非人力所能制。 因仍上东阳，欲停永康。 忽值永嘉人谈述彼山水甚美，复相随度娇至郡。 投永宁令陆襄。 陆仍自送憩天师治堂，而子良始已寄治内住，於此相识。 今讨窍绿由，如神灵所召，故其得来此山。 不尔，莫测其然。 于时子良年十二，仍求入山伏节为弟子。 始受《仙灵录》、《老子五千文》、《西岳公禁虎豹符》，便专心於香灯之务。 凡好书画，人问杂技，经心则能。 后随往南霍。 及反木溜，日一夕承奉，必尽恭勤。
chunks.translated_text:
*The Record of Zhou’s Communication with the Unseen*
*Sutra Title: The Comprehensive Record of Zhou’s Spiritual Communication*
*Four fascicles. Composed by Tao Hongjing.*

**Fascicle One**

The transcendent Zhou Ziliang, styled Yuansu, was a disciple of Tao the Recluse of Mount Mao. Originally from Jiqian Village, Du Township, Runan County, Runan Commandery in Yuzhou, he later resided in Qinghua Village, West Township of Jiankang in Danyang. His family was of illustrious lineage, renowned along the Jiangzuo region. In later generations, their fortunes declined, and they fell into hardship.

His grandfather, Wenlang, was nominated as a Filial and Incorrupt Candidate and served as Left Attendant in the household of the Prince of Jiangxia under the Liu-Song dynasty. His birth father, Yaozong, childhood name Jingang, was Wenlang’s fifth son. Yaozong held the post of Assistant in the Commandery and resided separately in Yuyao. He passed away in the second year of the Tianjian reign (503 CE) at the age of thirty-four and was provisionally interred there.

His adoptive uncle, Yaoxu, served as Registrar of the Prefecture and later as Consultant in the Yangzhou Administration. His mother, Xu Jingguang of Yongjia, dreamed during her fifth month of pregnancy that all the sages in a celestial chamber rose and circumambulated her from all sides. Thus, on the second day of the first month in the ding-chou year of the Jianwu reign (497 CE), at the hour of *ren ding*, he was born in Mingxing Village, Yuyao.

At the age of one, he was taken in and raised by his aunt, Baoguang, who treated him as her own son. From childhood, Ziliang was upright and intelligent, his nature gentle and refined. His family never witnessed him display anger. At ten, he followed his adoptive mother back to Yongjia.

In the seventh year of the Tianjian reign (508 CE), the Recluse journeyed eastward to the sacred mountains. Temporarily residing at Mount Qingzhang in Yongning, the Recluse entered the east. Originally bound for Yuyao, they boarded a sea vessel to Mount Huo in Jin’an. As they descended the Zhe River at dusk, the tide surged, dragging the boat toward Dingshan—a force beyond human control. They thus proceeded to Dongyang, intending to stay in Yongkang. Suddenly, they encountered a man from Yongjia who extolled the beauty of the local mountains and waters, so they followed him to the commandery. There, they sought out Magistrate Lu Xiang of Yongning. Lu personally escorted them to rest at the Hall of the Celestial Master, where Ziliang had already been lodging. Here, they first met. The circumstances of his arrival seemed divinely ordained, as if summoned by numinous spirits. Otherwise, the reason would remain unfathomable.

At the time, Ziliang was twelve years old. He sought to enter the mountain, submit to discipline, and become a disciple. He first received *The Register of Immortals and Spirits*, *The Five Thousand Character Scripture of Laozi*, and *The Talisman of the Western Marchmount for Suppressing Tigers and Leopards*, thereafter devoting himself wholeheartedly to the duties of incense and lamp offerings. Whatever he took interest in—calligraphy, painting, or miscellaneous arts—he mastered with focused attention.

Later, he followed the Recluse to Southern Huo. Upon returning to Muliu, he served with utmost reverence and diligence, day and night.

chunks.original_text: 十一年，从还茅岭。 此后进受《五岳图》、《三皇内文》十二年秋，其家中表亲族来投山居，乃出就西阿别癣住。 以十四年乙未岁五月二十三夏至日於癣忽未中寝卧，弥沦良久乃起出。 姨母不解所以，深加辩切，乃颇说所见，具如别记。 自尔於四五旬中大觉为异，恒垂帘掩扉，断人入室，烧香独住，日中止进一升蜜餐。 周家本事俗神，姨舅及道义咸恐是俗神所假，或谓欲染邪气，亟相蹙问，唯答云：许终是娄罗梦，无所知究，自怀愁虑，为复断隔耳。 於是众人莫测可否，相与纵置，听看趣向。 ．其七月中乃密受真旨，令外混世迩，勿使疑异。
chunks.translated_text:
In the eleventh year, he followed [the Recluse] back to Maoling. Thereafter, he advanced to receive *The Charts of the Five Marchmounts* and *The Esoteric Writings of the Three Sovereigns*.

In the autumn of the twelfth year, his maternal relatives came to reside in the mountains, so he moved out to dwell separately in a western hermitage. On the summer solstice of the fourteenth year, the twenty-third day of the fifth month in the *yiwei* cyclical year, he suddenly fell into a deep sleep at noon in the hermitage. After a long while, he arose and emerged. His aunt, not understanding the reason, pressed him severely. He then recounted in detail what he had seen, as recorded separately.

From then on, for forty or fifty days, he felt profoundly altered. He constantly lowered the blinds, shut the doors, and barred others from entering his chamber, burning incense in solitude. At midday, he consumed only a *sheng* of honey. His family had long worshipped common spirits, and his maternal uncle and Daoist companions all feared this was a deception by mundane deities or suspected he had been afflicted by perverse *qi*. They repeatedly questioned him in alarm, but he only replied: "Perhaps it was merely a dream of *vārttā*—I know nothing for certain. I am troubled and anxious, so I have cut myself off." Thus, none could discern the truth, and they let the matter rest, observing his inclinations.

In the seventh month, he secretly received the true teachings, which instructed him to blend into the world outwardly while drawing near, so as not to arouse suspicion.

chunks.original_text: 从此趋走执事，乃过於常日。 其年十月从移朱阳。 师后别居束山，便专住西馆，掌理外任，应接道俗，莫不爱敬。 本性君子，讷言敏行，所可云为，默而能济。 清修公正，纤毫无私。 去冬欲，潜依冥旨。 逆须别字，托以方便，冒求构立。 虽建三问赢屋，经时未毕。 入此年十月便密自成，辨窗户状帘。 至十九乃竟亲属道义资其上。 果要往看之，觉其潜形侧容，并莫知所以。 至二十六日密封题束西馆诸户阁癣处磨洗，以文簿器物料付何文幸。 尔夕自移袅枕出所住癣，云当暂斋。 或云暂行。 二十七旦独在住家察，及还馆中，言色平然，了无一异。 更香汤沐浴，着诸净衣，与文幸暮博读书，而屡瞻晷景。 至日映后便起，云时至矣。 即束带烧香，往师经堂中遍礼道众，径出，还所住癣。 住癣住屋唯有三问，住束一问，西二问亦安两高坐，并有香火也。 众人正言应就斋去，日哺问其弟名子平往看，正见於仙屋烧香出，还住户，问子平何以来。 答云：姨娘气发，唤兄还合药煮汤。 语云：我体亦小恶，即时欲服药，竟当还。 若未即还，汝可更来。 仍见铛中温半升酒。 子平驰还说此，姨母惊怪，亟令走往，已正见偃外。 子平不敢便进，俄顷所生母及姨母续至，见便悲叫，问何意何意。 唯闭眼举手三弹指，云：莫声叫莫声叫，误人事。 其母欲捧头起而蹴巾转，犹举手再过正巾，须臾气绝。 时用香炉烧一片熏陆如狸豆大，烟犹未息，计此正当半食顷耳。 时年二十。 先已装束，内衣上止着眠衣，加以法服，并坚结其带，脱草懦卷辟之。 容质鲜净，不异於生。 一切闻见，莫不叹骇。
chunks.translated_text: From then on, his diligence in service surpassed even his usual devotion. In the tenth month of that year, he followed his master to Zhu Yang. Later, when the master moved to reside separately at Shu Mountain, he remained solely at the Western Lodge, overseeing external affairs, receiving both Daoists and laypeople—all held him in love and reverence. By nature a gentleman, reticent in speech yet swift in action, whatever he undertook was accomplished in silence. His cultivation was pure and upright, utterly free of self-interest. Having long since cast off worldly desires, he secretly followed the hidden decree. Anticipating the need for a posthumous name, he devised a pretext to request construction. Though he built three modest chambers, the work remained unfinished for some time. By the tenth month of this year, he had quietly completed it himself, arranging windows, doors, and curtains. On the nineteenth, he invited his relatives and Daoist companions to contribute to its furnishing. Those who came to inspect it sensed his concealed form and sidelong demeanor, yet

suspected he had been afflicted by perverse *qi*. They repeatedly questioned him in alarm, but he only replied: "Perhaps it was merely a dream of *vārttā*—I know nothing for certain. I am troubled and anxious, so I have cut myself off." Thus, none could discern the truth, and they let the matter rest, observing his inclinations.

In the seventh month, he secretly received the true teachings, which instructed him to blend into the world outwardly while drawing near, so as not to arouse suspicion.

chunks.original_text: 以二十九日映后殡，仍造珑冢於束冈。 十一月三日丙寅日映后定，即捧土成坟。 此后音影寂寥，未通寤寐，将同人神之隔，为机会俟时乎？ 其得道原由、品号自具显所受《记》中，今略疏在世事迹，共所闻见如此，故载之《记》前。 又尔日：於书案上得四函书，并封题上皆湿，一函与师，一函与后癣姨母等，一函与舅徐普明，一大函有四纸与南馆束山诸道士，并是告别，同云二十七日。 计此，当时是从朱阳还，仍作书。 作书竟，便烧香也。 又检温铛中犹如常酒气，瓦盆中已被水荡，无气，都不见药踪迩，竟不测何所因托。 检《记》中得药方，或疑脱是此。 师既惋慨此事，追恨不早研究函，今人委曲科检诸筐蕴，庶睹遗《记》，而永无一札文，幸云一十六日烧两束书，可百余纸，不听人见。 意疑此必皆已焚毁，懊惜弥切，心犹未弭。 十一月旦甲子试自往燕口山洞寻看，果见封投一大函。 登崎岳钩取，拜请将还，开视，即是从来受旨五月，唯有夏至日后四事，六月七月并具足，从八月后至今年七月末止。 疏目录略举事端，称云而已，未测亦并．有事，如六七月而不存录，为当不复备记，止径略如此邪？ 今以意求，恐是不复疏之。 何知尔？ 寻初降数旬中，已得闲静，后既混揉，怛亲纷务，不展避人，题之纸墨，直止录条领耳。 想此十余月中训谕何限，惜乎弗问，此师之咎矣。 所封函中皆散纸杂揉，今依日月次第相连如法也。 又从今年八月至十月都不复见一条。 又寻所烧者，定当非此例，无容一封一焚故也。 亦可是焚不可显出者也。 又从来有令师及姨母知者止有数条，一者初夏至日昼眠，内外怪责，不得不说。 二者断不食脯肉，亦被怪，不得不说。 三者与师共辞请雨真旨，令改朱用墨，此不得不说。 四者师得停召真旨，令告知，此不得不说。 所可指的。 唯此四事。 自余或有访问，皆依违末略，初不显诏。 又师经一过，因辞访移朱阳。 及有所当事后，屡问蒙答，以不每云，未报，遂不显言。 今料视，定已有答。 寻此当是恐问便有酬者，则人人因托不少。 若不为问，则被人责，若悉为问，便作冥旨，是以皆匿隐之。 此《记》中多有真仙讳字，并诸教戒，便同依经诰之例，皆须诤案诤巾沐浴烧香，乃看之。 若欲传写，亦应先关告众真及玄人，不得皆悠悠外书记也。 周所住癣，庭坛有数株大相树，其户前一树甚丰茂，甲午年腊月望日忽见有如糖洒褊树上下，中问尤多。 于时哺许，华阳都讲丁景达来看徐普明，并见之，惊问。 见此甘露降下，家人不欲显此事，仍戏言：向小儿以糖沃之耳。 因共值尝，正如密味，亟折两枝见示，以插户帘上，十余日犹在。 按《瑞图》：甘露降竹梧，乃是瑞气降。 按说寻此庭坛边诸树略育，唯此对户者独浓，必当是欲显已应有神灵降引之事故也。 又周所住屋南步廓夹两边种竹，竹根穿入廊下。 乙未年五月十八日共其舅徐普明在中堂为谢家大斋三日，竟，散斋。 日中后其舅暂还癣，忽见步廊竹根生一笋，三寸已上分，为二条，并抽筠摔齐长九寸。 昨都不见，而今忽有，普明知是异，恐小兄拔弄，仍折取来中堂，遍示诸道士，咸共嗟叹未尝有此。 隐居深恨不置令成竹，又恐烂坏，乃炙乾录之，即日犹在。
chunks.translated_text:
On the twenty-ninth day, he was interred at dusk, and a tomb of fine jade was constructed on the eastern ridge. On the third day of the eleventh month, the *bingyin* day, he was again interred at dusk, and earth was heaped to form the grave. Thereafter, his voice and form vanished into silence, leaving no trace in waking or dream—was this the boundary between man and spirit, a moment awaiting its time?

The origins of his attainment of the Dao and his posthumous title are fully recorded in the *Account* he received, while the present text briefly outlines his deeds in this world as witnessed and heard, hence its placement before the *Account*.

That same day, four sealed letters were found upon his writing desk, their seals and covers damp. One was for his master, one for his stepmother and maternal aunt, one for his uncle Xu Puming, and a large one—containing four sheets—for the Daoists of the Southern Lodge and Eastern Mountain. All were farewells, each dated the twenty-seventh. Judging by this, he must have returned from Zhuyang and written them then. After finishing the letters, he burned incense.

Upon inspection, the warm wine pot still held the usual scent of alcohol, but the clay basin had been rinsed with water, leaving no trace of qi, nor any sign of medicine. The cause remained unfathomable. A prescription was later found in the *Account*, leading some to suspect it might have been the one. His master, lamenting the matter, regretted not having examined the letters sooner. Now, others meticulously searched through chests and boxes, hoping to find the lost *Account*, yet not a single note remained. Fortunately, it was recalled that on the sixteenth day, he had burned two bundles of writings—over a hundred sheets—allowing no one to see them. It was suspected these had all been destroyed, deepening the sorrow, which lingered unresolved.

On the first day of the eleventh month, the *jiazi* day, a trial journey was made to the cave at Yankou Mountain, where a large sealed letter was indeed found. Climbing the rugged slope, it was retrieved with a hook, and upon returning, it was opened with reverence. It contained instructions received five months prior, detailing only four matters after the Summer Solstice, with June and July fully recorded. From August onward to the seventh month of this year, entries ceased. The table of contents briefly listed events, merely noting their occurrence, leaving it unclear whether other matters—like those of June and July—had been omitted or simply not recorded in full. Perhaps they were intentionally left unelaborated. How could one know?

In the first few dozen days after his descent, he had found leisure and tranquility, but later, entangled in worldly affairs and the burdens of kinship, he could not escape others’ notice. What he committed to paper was only the barest outline. One can only imagine how much instruction he must have given in those ten-odd months—what a pity it was not inquired after! This was his master’s failing.

The sealed letters contained scattered and disordered papers, now arranged in chronological order. From the eighth to the tenth month of this year, not a single entry was found. As for the burned writings, they were surely of a different kind, for he would not have incinerated them one by one. Perhaps they were texts meant to remain hidden.

Previously, only a few matters had been disclosed to his master and maternal aunt. The first was his midday nap on the Summer Solstice, which drew strange rebukes from within and without, leaving him no choice but to explain. The second was his refusal to eat dried meat, which also provoked suspicion, forcing an explanation. The third was the true decree to change from vermilion to ink when jointly petitioning for rain, which he could not conceal. The fourth was the decree to halt his master’s summons, which he was instructed to reveal. These were the only clear instances. For all other inquiries, he remained evasive, never issuing explicit commands.

Earlier, after his master had perused the scriptures once, he had declined further visits and moved to Zhuyang. Later, when matters arose, he was repeatedly questioned and answered, but as he did not always respond, no replies were recorded, and thus nothing was made known. Now, upon reflection, it seems certain there were answers. Perhaps he feared that responding would invite endless requests, while silence would draw reproach. To answer fully would risk exposing hidden decrees, so he concealed them all.

The *Account* contains many taboo names of true immortals and various teachings, akin to sacred scriptures. It must be approached with the same reverence: washing hands, donning clean robes, burning incense, and only then reading it. If one wishes to copy it, one must first inform the assembled immortals and adepts—it is not to be treated like ordinary writings.

Around the dwelling where he resided, the courtyard altar was shaded by several large *xiang* trees. The one before the door was especially lush. On the fifteenth day of the twelfth month in the *jiawu* year, something like sugar was suddenly seen scattered all over the tree, with the middle portion particularly dense. Around dusk, Ding Jingda, the lecturer of Huayang, came to visit Xu Puming and witnessed it as well, asking in astonishment. Seeing this sweet dew descend, the household wished to conceal the matter and jested, “The children must have poured sugar on it.” They tasted it together—it was like honey—and hastily broke off two branches to display, hanging them on the door curtain, where they remained for over ten days. According to the *Illustrated Record of Auspicious Omens*, sweet dew falling on bamboo and *wu* trees is a sign of propitious qi. Upon reflection, of all the trees near the altar, only this one before the door was so luxuriant—surely this was meant to reveal that divine spirits had descended to guide him.

To the south of the dwelling, a covered walkway was flanked by bamboo planted on both sides, their roots creeping beneath the veranda. On the eighteenth day of the fifth month in the *yiwei* year, he and his uncle Xu Puming were in the main hall conducting a three-day grand vegetarian feast for the Xie family. After its conclusion, during the dispersal of the fast, Xu Puming briefly returned to the dwelling. Suddenly, he saw a bamboo shoot sprouting from the roots beneath the walkway, already over three inches tall and split into two stalks, both shooting up with tender shoots nine inches long. Yesterday, nothing had been there—now, it had appeared in an instant. Xu Puming, recognizing the marvel, feared his young nephew might pluck it, so he broke it off and brought it to the main hall, showing it to all the Daoists, who gasped in amazement, having never seen the like. The recluse deeply regretted not letting it grow into bamboo and, fearing it would rot, dried it by fire. It remains preserved to this day.
