chunks.original_text: 总真王君丁丑生，水命人，位为高真。 张酸亦丁丑生，乃沉沦三官。 此不可为定，但论功业何如耳。 陶日：实如来告刘夫人，又告子良日：夫神仙虽通玄感彻则易，但凡情虚微，不能招其感耳。 我等今来者，直寻有道者耳，非浮游无着，泛滥而行也。 幸勿令人知，知亦未然，此事或生疑诮，以回尔心。 我乃无怪於彼，但恐自招其罪耳。 子良日。 已蒙神降，岂敢自有疑，但欲时呈师母耳，不敢以告悠悠者。 又曰：亦勿甲乙告之。 赵夫人又告日：仙道有幽虚之趣，今粗为说之。 夫为真仙之位者，偃息玄官，游行紫汉，动则二景舒明，静则风云息气，服则翠羽飞裳，乘则枫输灵松。 浮海历岳，游陌八方。 进无水火之患，退无木石之忧，岂不足称高贵乎。 人唯见轩冕之荣，嫔房之乐，便为极矣。 所以真道不交乎世，神仙罕游人问，正为此耳。 纵有知者，亦不能穷而修之，或修而不久，或久而不精，诸如此事，良亦可悲。 周生，尔勿效此，凡庸之畴也。 王夫人告曰：夫一志直往无回还应作环字。 之虑，潇洒任理无累着之心者，此乃保贤之子也。 傥有穷幽测远，远求师友，书夜辛勤，积以岁月，或直坐一山，修经用法，吞符翕景，处七元者，亦皆能致道，终不及积业用功果之快耳。 尔可以此事告於来子，令勤之也，修此不止，不患身后，徒空尔自己，定无烦於其问矣。 陶夫人日：若能守道不动，服气吞景以镇五藏者，亦能得地仙，长生不死。 若无金丹五芝，终不能飞游太极，动静无方也。 吾今犹是仙之中者，未及上仙下真也。 前服气诸事，往亦为之，而得如今日耳。 周生，尔营之乎。 言语粗悉，入四更中。 赵日：星已疏矣，行当应曙，相与去，和诸人同应去。 赵又日：方当去来，不为久别。 王日：赵夫人来当无不相随。 ．刘日：来月三日，当往东华，呈学簿，当学陶夫人相过。 子良问：何学簿。 日：是易迁中教仙人学业有进退之簿。 二月，日多一呈，呈束华大司命，入月三是，此二月之最，至九月复呈。 如此周而复始。 陶日：且作十余日别。 李日：其问动静，赵夫人当见使来去，不复辞别。 便悉下林而去，侍女随次而灭。 右一条十九日夜所受记，书六小青栈纸。 寻此诸夫人所说，并无义旨，非必止在周生，亦以兼戒学者，明智功德之义，过於专修，观夫议理亦闻，则其理可见也。 六月二十一日夜，梦一人，年可三十许，白布椅褶平上绩，执手版，版黑色，形容乃端雅见敬，自称赵丞使下官相闻而言日：昨所与陶隐居，共有辞，欲须雨事国主忧民，乃至，但时运应尔。 比诸处屡有章辞，皆不与报陶。 既有功行周，方来於此，当为验二人之德，不烦谦谦，恐浥望，故遣报。
chunks.translated_text:
Lord Zongzhen of the Perfected was born in a *dingchou* year, a person of the Water destiny, and holds the rank of High Perfected. Zhang Suan, also born in a *dingchou* year, has sunk into the Three Bureaus. This is not a fixed fate, but depends solely on one’s merits and deeds.

Lady Tao said: "Truly as Lady Liu has told you, and as I have told Ziliang: Though the divine immortals’ responsiveness to profound mysteries is swift and effortless, mortal sentiments are too insubstantial and faint to summon such resonance. Those of us who come here today seek only those with the Dao—we do not wander aimlessly without purpose. Take care that others do not learn of this. Even if they do, it may not be so, for such matters might breed doubt and reproach, turning your heart away. I bear no ill will toward them, but fear they may bring retribution upon themselves."

Ziliang said: "Having received the descent of the divine, how could I dare to doubt? I wished only to present this to my teacher’s wife from time to time, not to reveal it to the careless common folk." He added: "Nor should you tell those of the *jia* or *yi* ranks."

Lady Zhao further explained: "The Dao of immortals holds subtle and hidden delights. Now, let me roughly describe them. Those who attain the rank of True Immortal repose in the Mystic Palace, roam the Purple Han, their movements unfolding the twin radiance of sun and moon, their stillness calming the winds and clouds. Clad in kingfisher plumes and flying robes, they ride upon maple chariots and divine pines. They traverse seas and cross mountains, wandering the eight directions. Advancing, they suffer no peril of water or fire; retreating, they bear no burden of wood or stone. Is this not worthy of being called noble and exalted? Yet people see only the glory of carriages and caps, the pleasures of the inner chambers, and deem these the ultimate. This is precisely why the True Dao does not mingle with the world, and why divine immortals seldom wander among men. Even those who know of it cannot fully cultivate it—some cultivate but do not persist, others persist but do not refine their practice. Such matters are truly lamentable. Zhou, do not follow the path of the common herd."

Lady Wang said: "One whose will is single-minded, who proceeds without turning back, whose thoughts are unburdened by attachments, and whose heart is free and unencumbered—this is a disciple who preserves the worthy. If one delves into the hidden and probes the distant, seeking teachers and friends, toiling day and night for years on end; or if one sits alone in the mountains, practicing scriptures and methods, swallowing talismans and absorbing radiance, dwelling in the Seven Primes—all may attain the Dao. Yet none compare to the swiftness of accumulating merit and perfecting deeds. You may convey this to the younger generation, urging them to diligence. If they persist without cease, they need not fear for their future, nor will they waste their own efforts or trouble others with their concerns."

Lady Tao said: "If one can guard the Dao without wavering, practice *qi*-absorption and radiance-swallowing to stabilize the five viscera, one may attain earthly immortality and live forever. Without the Golden Elixir or the Five Mushrooms, however, one cannot soar through the Great Ultimate or move without constraint. I am still but a middling immortal, not yet among the High Perfected or Lesser Realized. I too once practiced *qi*-absorption and other arts, and thus have reached my present state. Zhou, will you strive for this?"

Their words grew more detailed as the fourth watch approached. Lady Zhao said: "The stars have grown sparse; dawn is near. We should depart, and all of you should leave as well." She added: "This parting is not a long farewell."

Lady Wang said: "When Lady Zhao comes, she will not fail to accompany us."

Lady Liu said: "On the third day of next month, I shall go to the Eastern Flower, present the Learning Register, and visit Lady Tao." Ziliang asked: "What is the Learning Register?" She replied: "It is the register of immortals’ progress in the teachings of *Yiqian*, recording their advances and setbacks. Every two months, on the third day, it is presented to the Great Director of Destinies of the Eastern Flower. The second month is the most important; it is presented again in the ninth month. This cycle repeats endlessly."

Lady Tao said: "Let us part for ten days or so."

Li said: "Regarding your activities, Lady Zhao will send messengers to and fro. There is no need for formal farewells."

Then they all descended into the grove and vanished, the attendants following in order. This record was received on the night of the nineteenth and written on six small sheets of green-striped paper.

The teachings of these ladies contained no fixed doctrine, not limited to Zhou alone but serving as a general admonition to cultivators. They clarified the meaning of wisdom and merit, showing that their virtue surpassed mere specialized practice. Observing their discourse, one may glimpse the principles therein.

On the night of the twenty-first day of the sixth month, I dreamed of a man around thirty years old, dressed in a plain white cloth robe with a black tablet in hand. His bearing was refined and dignified, inspiring respect. He identified himself as an emissary of Vice-Minister Zhao and said: "Yesterday, I had words with Tao Yinju. There are matters requiring attention to the lord’s concerns and the people’s welfare, so I have come only now. Recently, petitions have arrived from many places, but none have been answered except Tao’s. Since your meritorious deeds have come full circle, I have come here to verify the virtue of you both. Do not be overly modest, lest expectations be dampened. Thus, I have come to report."

Lady Wang said: "Lady Liu’s words have thoroughly explained the hidden and manifest aspects of your past lives. You should keep this knowledge in your heart and not reveal it to the careless common folk." Lady Tao said: "Zhou, you were born on the nineteenth day of the *dingchou* year, a person of the Water destiny." She then asked Lady Zhao: "To whom does this one compare?" Lady Zhao replied: "There is no fixed comparison."

chunks.original_text: 子良日：比风日赫烈，塘湖缟竭，五谷隽枯，草木雕落，方虑饥乏，故冒共投辞，希垂沾润。 此人日：当不虑不雨，恐不得洪溢耳。 前辞言语乃好，但请雨应墨书，请晴应朱书，并青纸上人，唯言神重丹青，不知丹青有不会处。 诸如此者，世问非一，但无人报其此意。 其既不自知，反云神而无灵，愿更作墨书辞，勿同前语。 子良答：辄从要旨。 又问：圣灵何姓，可得闻不。 此人日：问下官耶。 答曰：姓黄，字元平，东海人，犹散在保命赵丞间，无位任。 仍日：不得久停，或当更来。 敛手而去。
chunks.translated_text:
Lord Ziliang said: "Of late, the wind and sun have blazed fiercely, the ponds and lakes run dry, the five grains wither, grasses and trees fade and fall. Fearing famine and want, I have ventured to submit this petition, hoping for a drop of moisture to bestow."

The man replied: "You need not fear the absence of rain—only that it may not come in torrents."

"The words of the previous petition were fine, but requests for rain should be written in ink, and requests for clear skies in vermilion, both on blue paper. The gods value cinnabar and ink, yet do not realize that cinnabar and ink have their limits. Such cases are not uncommon in the world, yet no one has ever explained this intent. Since the petitioners themselves remain unaware, they instead claim the gods lack efficacy. I urge you to compose another petition in ink, and avoid repeating the former words."

Lord Ziliang answered: "I shall follow your essential instructions."

He then asked: "May I know the sacred spirit’s surname?"

The man replied: "Are you asking me, the subordinate official?"

When Lord Ziliang assented, he said: "The surname is Huang, the given name Yuanping. He is from Donghai, and still serves as an attendant among the life-preserving officials under Vice-Minister Zhao, holding no formal rank."

He added: "I cannot linger long; perhaps I shall return again." With that, he clasped his hands and departed.

chunks.original_text: 右一条二十一日夜所受记，书一白麻纸。 按此年夏旱不雨，积旬。 诸道士恒章奏永，无云气，隐居是与周共作辞，依常朱书青纸。 二十日晴，后共周於静中奏之。 故二十一日夜得此梦。 周二十二日夜，乃作墨辞於其应，廷坛自奏。 二十三旦，周向家云：昨夕有人报云：今日中当雨。 尔旦，天清赤热，了无雨意。 至禺中，周来入岭，至上便见东边风云卒起，末达隐居，问於路便雨地得好溜，唯在一山周过左右耳。 此一事，即共宣显，只疏云梦不知定梦定觉耶。 华阳隐居甲道士周子良，辞窃寻下氏之命，粒食为本，农功所资，在於润泽，顷亢早积旬，苗稼焦个，远近嗷嗷，瞻天崔息。 百姓祈请，永无感降，伏闻水雨之任有，所司存愿哀愍黔首，妇垂沾迟，呼风召云，肤寸而合，使洪潦滥川，水陆咸济，则白鹤之咏，复兴於今，共申至诚，稽类辞请馑辞。 天监十四年太岁乙未六月二十一日，辞诣句曲华阳金坛洞天张理，禁赵丞前。 此是前所朱书辞者，隐居制周书，始检得，后近写，又寻觅周所易木，末见。 六月二十四日，昼外南林，梦一人，年可六十许，着飘风冠，披毛被紫罗裳，手执玉铃，腰带大符，以丹书黄上，不似笔迹当是织成。 未尝来也。 侍者两人，皆绛衣。
chunks.translated_text:
The above entry, received in a vision on the night of the twenty-first, was inscribed on a sheet of white hemp paper.

That summer, a drought had persisted for weeks without rain. The various Daoist masters had repeatedly submitted memorials, yet no clouds gathered. The Recluse and Zhou jointly composed a petition, following the usual practice of writing in cinnabar on blue-green paper. On the twentieth day, the sky cleared, and that night, together with Zhou, they presented the petition in meditation. Thus, on the night of the twenty-first, this dream was received.

On the night of the twenty-second, Zhou composed a petition in ink in response and submitted it himself at the court altar. On the morning of the twenty-third, Zhou told his family: "Last night, someone reported that it would rain at midday today." That morning, the sky was clear and scorching, with no sign of rain. By midday, Zhou entered the mountain pass and, upon reaching the summit, saw wind and clouds suddenly rise from the east. Before he could reach the Recluse, he was met on the road by a downpour that soaked the ground, though it fell only on the mountain where he had just passed.

This matter was later widely recounted, though some merely noted the dream without confirming whether it was truly a dream or reality.

Hua Yang Recluse, Daoist Zhou Ziliang, humbly observes: The mandate of the lower realm depends on grain as its foundation, and farming relies on moisture. For weeks now, drought has parched the seedlings, and the cries of distress echo far and near as all gaze upon the heavens in despair. Though the people have prayed ceaselessly, no response has descended. We have heard that the office responsible for water and rain exists, and we beseech its compassion for the common folk, that it may swiftly send down moisture. Let it summon wind and call forth clouds, gathering them from every direction, so that floods may overflow the rivers and all—whether on land or water—may be saved. Then shall the ode of the white crane be revived in our time. With utmost sincerity, we submit this petition, modeled on past examples.

*Tianjian 14th year, cyclical year yiwei, sixth month, twenty-first day.* The petition is presented before Zhang Li, Keeper of the Golden Altar Grotto-Heaven of Juqu Hua Yang, and Vice-Minister Zhao of the Prohibitions.

This was the former petition written in cinnabar. The Recluse later drafted Zhou’s petition, and upon reviewing it, transcribed it anew. The wooden tablet Zhou had altered was later sought but not found.

On the twenty-fourth day of the sixth month, during the afternoon, in the southern woods, the Recluse dreamed of a man of about sixty years, wearing a fluttering wind crown and a purple robe lined with fur. He held a jade bell in hand and bore a great talisman at his waist, inscribed in cinnabar on yellow silk—not in brushstrokes, but woven into the fabric. He had never appeared before. Two attendants accompanied him, both clad in crimson.

chunks.original_text: 进坐，乃言曰：德秀之美，感乎幽冥。 吾久欲来，碍以诸务，遂不即果。 邓生前亦应为说我来。 子良日：邓仙人备述神灵应垂降意，比恒洗心洁念，仰候真仙。 乃笑日：邓亦寻应来。 良久，许乃自悲叹日：昔为孤栖独往，贤莫过焉，我尝学道於嵩高，积八十余年，蒙得神芝，服之而化。 虽得神涉仙阶，而尸宅无寄，今犹在嵩高南石室中，顾之眷恋，心未能豁，子当不忧此事。 人言得道不复念形，我念形之切，裂於肝心，可得无棺椁乎。 吾今乃桐梧金庭琳宫之师，领苍梧仙人，镇朱台之内，姓徐，字玄真。 故令知位字有在耳，寻当与邓生俱来，别更委曲，不为远别。 便不复见。 须臾，复梦见二人，乃赵丞前所使黄元平者。 云昨雨恨不多来，月中当更作。 昨往太山，见尊府君送人夕来，乃始得除君死录，更纪生名，如此辈六人。 尊府君言，今还北宫，君傥至子良处，道我今来此，今故来为宣之。 如此便去。 右一条，二十四日昼寝梦所受记，书两青纸。
chunks.translated_text:
They invited him to take a seat, whereupon he spoke: "The excellence of Dexiu has moved the unseen realms. I have long wished to come, but was hindered by various duties, and so did not immediately fulfill my intent. Master Deng had previously also spoken of my coming."

Ziliang replied: "The Immortal Deng fully described how the divine spirits deigned to descend, and I have constantly purified my heart and thoughts, reverently awaiting the arrival of the true immortals."

The visitor smiled and said: "Deng will soon come as well." After a long pause, he sighed in sorrow and said: "In the past, I wandered alone in reclusion, and no worthy surpassed me. I once studied the Dao on Mount Song, accumulating over eighty years, until I was granted divine lingzhi. Consuming it, I transformed. Though I attained the divine and ascended the immortal ranks, my bodily form had no resting place, and to this day it remains in the southern stone chamber of Mount Song. Gazing upon it, I am filled with longing, and my heart cannot let go. You need not worry about this matter. People say that those who attain the Dao no longer think of their form, yet my longing for my form is so intense it tears at my liver and heart. Can I truly be without a coffin?"

"Now I am the master of the Paulownia-Wu Golden Court and Jasper Palace, leading the immortals of Cangwu and presiding within the Crimson Terrace. My surname is Xu, and my style is Xuanzhen. Thus I let you know that my name and style remain—soon I shall come with Master Deng, and we will speak further in detail. It is not a distant parting."

With that, he vanished from sight. After a moment, two men appeared in another dream—those sent by Vice-Minister Zhao, Huang Yuanping among them. They said: "We regret that yesterday’s rain did not last longer; next month we shall do more. Yesterday, we went to Mount Tai and saw your esteemed father escorting someone at dusk. Only then was your name removed from the register of the dead and your name of life recorded anew, along with five others. Your esteemed father said he would return to the Northern Palace, and if you were to visit Ziliang, you should tell him of my coming here, which is why I have come to announce it."

With these words, they departed.

This account was received in a dream during the afternoon nap on the twenty-fourth day and recorded on two sheets of blue paper.

chunks.original_text: 按邓是此月六日来，徐与邓同在桐梧，故相称引。 后二十九日，仍共来也。 惟如徐说，虽得化，化犹恋於委形，况在余神鬼中乎。 棺椁之事，便弗无矣。 此徐君《真拙婴所无，而不知何处人，何时得道。 云周父还北宫，则是隶邓都所使去。 五月，赵丞云，明年春当生王家，今则已去，一得受生，便连逮绝也。 又按前刘夫人云：尔名上仙镰已七十余年，而今方云太山始除．死记生名、寻此则仙简鬼簿，各各有名，仙简虽有，而鬼簿不除，犹为未定，是故得上仙名函，有落除或仙鬼两名俱正，便无复黜斥还民问，或充鬼役，若是则周生今日之化，永保品矣。 乙未年六月二十九日夕，桐梧有二人来，一则桐相金庭宫上师苍梧仙人徐玄真，衣服如前持玉铃，侍者二人，《真诰》无。 一则桐梧仙人邓灵期。 衣服亦如前，但持玉铃耳，侍者亦二人，《真诰》无。 邓先言曰：久欲相诣，碍以此。 二十七日，蒙受书为帝晨，执盖御史，治桐梧山南青中馆，领华阳学仙，禁四宫中事，以此，故致乖爽。 徐君前来，善得接赏耳。 子良答曰：蒙徐君垂顾，欢仰无已，复蒙今降，庆莫过此。 徐君曰：向过茅定录处，云始授《子玄真经》，甚助欣然。 子良答曰：谬荷灵启垂受真法，但肉人顽疏，修行多替。 又曰：闻子名已入束宫青简，尚审其事，比当与邓生往为参之。 答曰：赐与参访，实是所希。 徐仍指邓日：此君学道来已数百年，始今得任。 子乃坐地获之，故知功夫久有在。 邓笑曰：周生绿业，果始韩侯所说，当可言乎。 徐日：周子虽禀仙绿，未得便知前身之事。 子良因曰：鄙塞尘陋，岂得知此不，韩侯是谁。 邓日：是束华仙侯韩惠期，领束宫诸简录，治方丈第八玄宫中。 向云欲参子事者，正诣此人耳。 徐曰：今日匆匆，不得久停，寻当得与邓生俱来，不为远别。 下席同出户，侍者随从而灭。 右一条二十九夕所受记，书一大度白麻纸。 按徐玄定录，授子玄经检别目云。 六月二十七日，华阳童宣定录君旨，授《太霄隐书》、《玄真内诀》云云。 而今函中亦无此事，恐与同房俱别封也。 论桐梧中仙乃不应相关，当邓领华阳四宫仙禁，故得往来四宫者，当谓男则童初萧闲，女则易迁含真也，参简之事，别在七月中。 右起六月一日至二十九日，几有十三条事，书青白大小合二十三纸。 其洞房玄真二条事於目录中，唯阙此余悉具足。 周氏冥通记卷之二竟 周氏冥通记卷之三
chunks.translated_text:
Here follows the translation:

---

According to Deng, he arrived on the sixth day of this month. Xu and Deng were together at Tongwu, which is why they referred to each other. On the twenty-ninth day, they came again. As Xu said, though one may attain transformation, the transformed still cling to their bodily forms—how much more so for those among the remaining spirits and ghosts? The matter of the coffin and outer coffin cannot be dispensed with.

This Xu Jun—*Zhenzhuo* records nothing of his origins, nor does it state where or when he attained the Dao. He said that Zhou’s father had returned to the Northern Palace, which means he was under the command of Deng’s capital office. In the fifth month, Vice-Minister Zhao said that next spring he would be reborn into the Wang family; now he has already departed, and once rebirth is received, all former ties are severed.

Furthermore, recalling what Madam Liu had previously said: "Your name has been on the register of immortals for over seventy years," yet now it is only said that Mount Tai has just removed your name from the register of the dead and recorded your name of life. From this, it appears that the ledgers of immortals and the rolls of ghosts each have their own records. Though the immortal ledger may list one’s name, if the ghostly roll is not expunged, the matter remains unsettled. Only when the name on the immortal register is confirmed and the ghostly roll is likewise corrected—so that both names are properly aligned—does one escape demotion or expulsion back to the mortal realm, or conscription into ghostly service. If so, then Zhou’s transformation today ensures his rank is eternally secured.

On the evening of the twenty-ninth day of the sixth month in the *yimao* year, two men arrived at Tongwu. One was Xu Xuanzhen, Master of the Jinting Palace at Tongxiang, an immortal of Cangwu, dressed as before and holding a jade bell, accompanied by two attendants—*Zhen Gao* makes no mention of this. The other was Deng Lingqi, an immortal of Tongwu, also dressed as before but holding only a jade bell, likewise attended by two—*Zhen Gao* omits this as well.

Deng spoke first: "I have long wished to visit you, but this has hindered me. On the twenty-seventh, I received an imperial decree appointing me as *Dichen*, Umbrella-Bearing Censor, to govern the Southern Green Lodge at the foot of Tongwu Mountain, and to oversee the study of immortality in Huayang, as well as the affairs of the Four Palaces. This is why I have been delayed. Xu Jun’s earlier visit allowed for some pleasant exchange."

Ziliang replied: "I am deeply honored by Xu Jun’s gracious regard, and my joy knows no bounds. To receive your descent now brings a happiness beyond measure."

Xu Jun said: "Earlier, I passed by Mao Dinglu’s place, where he had just been granted *The Scripture of the Mysterious True One*. I was greatly pleased to hear it."

Ziliang answered: "I am unworthy of such divine favor and the transmission of true teachings. As a dull mortal, my cultivation has been lax and inconsistent."

Xu then said: "I have heard that your name has entered the green bamboo slips of the Eastern Palace. I shall verify this matter and, before long, will go with Deng to investigate it."

Ziliang replied: "To be granted such an inquiry is indeed my greatest hope."

Xu then pointed to Deng and said: "This gentleman has studied the Dao for several hundred years and has only now attained his position. You have obtained it while still seated upon the earth—this shows that long-standing effort has borne fruit."

Deng smiled and said: "As for Zhou’s karmic affinity, it was indeed as Marquis Han described. May I speak of it?"

Xu said: "Though Zhou bears the karmic affinity of an immortal, he has not yet come to know the matters of his past lives."

Ziliang then asked: "How could one as base and worldly as I comprehend such things? Who is this Marquis Han?"

Deng replied: "He is Han Huiqi, the Immortal Marquis of Donghua, who oversees the registers of the Eastern Palace and governs the Eighth Mysterious Palace of Fangzhang. When I spoke earlier of verifying your affairs, it is to him we must go."

Xu said: "Today is rushed, and I cannot stay long. Before long, Deng and I shall come together again—it will not be a distant parting."

They rose from their seats, exited the door together, and vanished as their attendants followed. The attendants disappeared as well.

This account was received in a dream on the evening of the twenty-ninth and recorded on one large sheet of white hemp paper.

According to Xu Xuan’s *Dinglu*, in the separate index of *The Scripture of the Mysterious True One*, it states: "On the twenty-seventh day of the sixth month, by decree of the Lord of Xuan Dinglu of Huayang, *The Hidden Book of the Grand Empyrean* and *The Inner Secrets of the Mysterious True One* were conferred," and so on. Yet this matter is not found in the present letter, likely because it was sealed separately with others in the same chamber.

As for the immortals of Tongwu, they should not be connected to one another. Since Deng oversees the immortal prohibitions of the Four Palaces of Huayang, he is permitted to travel among them. These would be, for men, Tong Chu and Xiao Xian, and for women, Yi Qian and Han Zhen. The matter of verifying the registers will be addressed in the seventh month.

From the first to the twenty-ninth day of the sixth month, there are thirteen entries in all, recorded on twenty-three sheets of blue and white paper, large and small. Of the two entries concerning the *Cavern Chamber* and *Mysterious True One* in the catalog, only these are missing; the rest are complete.

*Records of Zhou’s Communication with the Unseen, Scroll Two* ends here.
*Records of Zhou’s Communication with the Unseen, Scroll Three* begins.

chunks.original_text: 七月事 一依本写即事有隐者今朱注诠记。 乙未年，七月二日夜，七人来。 一人姓周，着玄华冠，服绿毛被丹霄飞裳，佩流金铃。 年可五十许，《真诰》有侍者四人，执黄毛节。 一人姓王，衣服似周，服紫羽被，佩流金铃。 年可四十许，《真诰》有侍者四人，执绿毛节。 一人姓茅，着远游冠，玄毛被，紫锦衣，佩流金铃。 年可六十许，《真诰》有，侍者三人，执玄毛节，又捧一白牙箱。 一人亦姓茅，着芙蓉冠，丹毛被，玄绣衣，佩玉铃。 年可六＋许，《真诰》有，侍者二人，无所执。 一人姓周，着华盖冠，服云锦衣，佩玉铃。 年四十余，《真诰》云名太宾侍者五人执紫毛节。 一人姓司马，着芙蓉冠，服素羽，被紫锦衣，佩玉铃。 年四十许，《真诰》有，侍者二人，执青毛节。 一人则乐丞公服如前。 侍者五人，《真诰》有，凡此前衣服并丞，后见诰令识之。 丞曰：今真人来，何不拜。 子良即起再拜，顿首稽颗，乞神仙之诀。 茅定录君曰：功名已着，无烦苦名，并录我所关。 周。 紫阳曰．．一与尔别便数百年，我当知如一日尔。 萦之经生死，一何苦哉。 司马括苍曰：学道不勤，而得道者，乃周生乎。 茅保命曰：勤苦之弊，何可备言，所谓先苦后乐。 王紫阳曰：岁月易积，功业难显。 昔闻周生之名，今见周生之德，宿昔犹固，良可知矣。 应是嘉字。 周大夫曰：周生年稚而德奥，识浅而智深，已三生如此。 我昔微游於世数经，诣之，乃能倾襟布诚而施仁也。 我因欲示之要言，而其未堪受法，故不授之，今得相见，良亦为欣。 周紫阳曰：卿知其根由，不乃吾之弟孙也。 音与其於南海相遇便别，别来已二百余年矣。 丞曰：将告卿众真之第一。 紫阳左真人，治葛衍山。 周君第二，紫阳古真人，治蟠冢山。 王君周君传乃云，．紫阳有左右真人，亦不显右是王君，不知何名字。 第三，定录茅中君第四，保命茅小君第五，蓬莱右大夫周君第六，括苍真人司马先生第七，吾也。 此前六等，并真人前后来者，皆仙人。 唯冯君是黄庭真人，治中岳耳。 保命问曰：粗悉此位不，子良答：蒙承垂告，已解。 定录君曰：前遣景上期授子《玄真内诀》，遂未修之邪。 子良曰：蒙赐《玄真经》，即应修用，但洪君前受《洞房》，欲且营之成业，故未暇耳。 ．又告曰：《洞房》乃好得益迟，修《玄真》专勤者，五年中，便得太玄玉女侍，犹劝先营之，并修亦不相妨。 子良应尔。 王君曰：子勤励之，名籍虽定，中问纵息，亦未必得全此功尔。 勿轻示人今夕来事。 周大夫曰：得仙者年年月月皆有，但人不知耳。 尔申年当得，上拜太极，不者，则酉年也。 此期非远，而亦复为遥，子勤此中问也。 司马君曰：子保举既强，得业亦美，道必可谐但其流行之必不息也。 子良受旨一二，谨依。 丞曰：陶隐居事近，亦不无此议。 卿姨屡有脆请二君，乃无异，但恐余处不必允耳。 定录曰：陶某名录多阙，穿处不的，由纵见由我，我亦不得自任。 中旬，问当与思和，此保命字也。 往诸司命问论之意，此必无苦勿卒忧浥。 仍云：吾等今去，或复寻更来，其问有信书、疏亦可相通。 因以相随而去。 右一条，七月二日夜受记，书四小青栈，又一片续后。
chunks.translated_text:
Seventh Month Matters—All entries are transcribed as they occurred, with hidden details now annotated in red by Zhu.

In the year *yiwei*, on the second night of the seventh month, seven persons arrived.

One surnamed Zhou wore a *Xuanhua* crown and a green feathered robe with a *Danxiao* flying garment, bearing golden bells. He appeared to be around fifty years of age. As recorded in the *Zhen’gao*, he had four attendants holding yellow-feathered staffs.

One surnamed Wang was dressed similarly to Zhou, but with a purple feathered robe and golden bells. He appeared to be around forty. The *Zhen’gao* notes he had four attendants holding green-feathered staffs.

One surnamed Mao wore a *Yuanyou* crown, a black feathered robe, and a purple brocade garment, bearing golden bells. He appeared to be around sixty. The *Zhen’gao* records he had three attendants holding black-feathered staffs, one of whom carried a white ivory box.

Another surnamed Mao wore a *Furong* crown, a red feathered robe, and a black embroidered garment, bearing jade bells. He appeared to be around sixty or older. The *Zhen’gao* notes he had two attendants, who carried nothing.

One surnamed Zhou wore a *Huagai* crown and a cloud-brocade garment, bearing jade bells. He was in his forties. The *Zhen’gao* states his name was Taibin, with five attendants holding purple-feathered staffs.

One surnamed Sima wore a *Furong* crown, a plain feathered robe, and a purple brocade garment, bearing jade bells. He appeared to be around forty. The *Zhen’gao* records he had two attendants holding blue-feathered staffs.

The last was the Minister of Music, dressed as before, with five attendants. The *Zhen’gao* confirms this; their attire was previously described, and the *Zhen’gao* commands recognition of it.

The Minister said: "Now that the Perfected Ones have arrived, why do you not bow?"
Ziliang immediately rose and bowed twice, kowtowing and knocking his head to the ground, entreating the secrets of immortality.

Lord Mao, Registrar of Destinies, said: "Your merit and fame are already manifest; do not trouble yourself with further striving. Record all that concerns me."
Zhou Ziyang said: "...It has been hundreds of years since we last parted, yet to me it feels like a single day. How bitterly you have entangled yourself in the cycles of life and death!"
Sima of Kuocang said: "Is it not Zhou who has attained the Dao without diligence in study?"
Mao, Preserver of Life, said: "The hardships of striving cannot be fully described—what is called 'first suffering, then joy.'"
Wang Ziyang said: "Time accumulates easily, but meritorious deeds are difficult to manifest. I once heard of Zhou’s name; now I see his virtue. His resolve has long been firm—this is truly evident."
This must refer to his courtesy name, Jia.

The Zhou Grand Master said: "Zhou is young in years but profound in virtue, shallow in knowledge yet deep in wisdom. He has been thus for three lifetimes. In my past travels through the world, I visited him several times, and he was always able to open his heart in sincerity and extend benevolence. I wished to impart essential teachings to him, but he was not yet ready to receive the methods, so I did not transmit them. Now that we meet again, I am truly delighted."
Zhou Ziyang said: "Do you know his origins? He is none other than my grandnephew. I last met him at the Southern Sea, and we parted. It has been over two hundred years since then."

The Minister said: "I shall now announce the ranks of the foremost Perfected Ones among you.
The Left Perfected One of Ziyang governs Mount Geyan.
Second is Zhou, the Ancient Perfected One of Ziyang, who governs Mount Panzhong. (Wang and Zhou’s traditions state that Ziyang has Left and Right Perfected Ones, but it is unclear whether the Right is Wang; his name is unknown.)
Third is Mao, Registrar of Destinies.
Fourth is Mao, Preserver of Life.
Fifth is Zhou, Right Grand Master of Penglai.
Sixth is Sima, Perfected One of Kuocang.
Seventh is myself.
The first six ranks, including those who have come before and after, are all immortals. Only Feng is the Perfected One of the Yellow Court, governing the Central Marchmount."

The Preserver of Life asked: "Do you roughly understand these ranks?"
Ziliang replied: "I humbly receive your instruction and now comprehend."
The Registrar of Destinies said: "Previously, I sent Jing to arrange the transmission of the *Inner Secrets of the Mysterious Perfected*—have you not yet cultivated it?"
Ziliang said: "Having received the *Scripture of the Mysterious Perfected*, I should have cultivated it, but Master Hong previously bestowed the *Cavern Chamber* upon me, and I wished to first complete its practice, so I have not had the leisure."
He further instructed: "The *Cavern Chamber* yields benefits slowly. If you cultivate the *Mysterious Perfected* with single-minded diligence, within five years you will obtain the attendance of the Jade Maiden of the Great Mystery. I still advise you to prioritize it; cultivating both will not hinder one another."
Ziliang assented.

Wang said: "You must strive diligently. Though your name is recorded in the registers, if you slacken midway, you may not fully attain this merit. Do not lightly reveal tonight’s affairs to others."
The Zhou Grand Master said: "Those who attain immortality appear year after year, month after month—only people do not know it. In the year *shen*, you will ascend to the Grand Ultimate; if not, then in the year *you*. This appointed time is neither distant nor far—you must strive without ceasing."
Sima said: "Your protection and advancement are strong, your attainments fine. The Dao will surely be harmonized—only ensure its circulation does not cease."
Ziliang received these one or two instructions and respectfully complied.

The Minister said: "Master Tao’s affairs are recent, and this discussion is not without basis. Your aunt has repeatedly made earnest requests to the two Lords, and there is no objection—only I fear my own position may not permit assent."
The Registrar of Destinies said: "Tao’s name is recorded with many gaps, and the flaws are not definitive. Since he indulged himself through me, I cannot take sole responsibility."
Mid-month, he asked to consult with Sihe (the courtesy name of the Preserver of Life). He intended to visit the various Controllers of Destiny to discuss the matter, assuring that there would be no hardship—do not worry hastily.
He further said: "We depart now, but may return to visit again. If you have letters or memorials, they may also be conveyed."
They then departed together.

This entry, recorded on the second night of the seventh month, was written on four small blue slips, with an additional piece appended later.

chunks.original_text: 按：紫阳两真，句曲二君，此日若始自降，o前六月，唯遣侍童耳。 《真诰》云：周太宾善鼓一弦琴； 是教孙登者为蓬莱右夫人，即应是也。 司马括苍，内外书传都不见，又不应是季主，乃可季主儿法育耳。 唯见此一来，自后无复所出，隐居。 此年四月，自得梦应被召云，官府已整，唯作印未，成意甚恻恻，径向周说。 周登向其姨母道如此，姨母乃密营脆信，告潘渊文为条疏，作辞牒，令周共奏请，后天窗洞隐居，都不知。 后方问有此，亦不复问周可否。 至七月十三日，事诀。 十四日旦，周疏受见，示方具耳，止闻此一过，而云屡有脆请，是所未究。 乙未年七月三日夜有九女人来。 齐着青衣，绛绿衣，．下紫为腰带，佩金铃，铃下有大符，黑。 为文书，青。 上手并执板，板白色，似玉见衣缝，缝皆有如织文缀之。 每缝际，并有小铃子着之，行辄有声。 其一女则刘玄微，一则陶智安，余者皆不识，亦不见。 与语j刘夫人曰：比修学稍得新业邪，吾旦往东华，今始还。 文书事粗得了见，尔名已度上东华青简，甚助为庆。 陶夫人曰：闻近斋而俟北斗，大不可言，讶尔标心，乃至於此星，亦未可卒见，积以岁月，所不论耳。 刘夫人因唤诸女曰：此周生有凌云之秀，将可与共语。 一人应曰：下仙未敢与高人语。 刘曰：高下未必可定，伊犹沉滞尘喧，共启悟之耳，何高之有。 此女笑．曰：别当相造，今未容言。 陶曰：此段易迁中有柳妙基，谓应作姬字，受口语音不得字体也。 孙芳华，阮惠香，此三女，（真拙，》中皆无。 此三子学有功夫，得度方诸第八朱台中受书，并为仙妃，故今知之。 刘.曰：周生，尔欲之乎。 答曰：凡虫乌非所敢希。 曰：尔得希之，所以相告。 陶曰：夜已深，宜去。 便欲去。 诸女曰：待侬。 因相随而灭。 右一条，三日夜所受记，书两小青纸。 按：此即是前月所云，送学簿，呈东华，还过而下，见赵王。 乃更有余人兼申嘲谠，欲希之辞夫，以涵育两仪，照临日月，山泽通气，阴阳离会，莫不皆须匹偶，共相映协。 自高真以下，减周斯义。 既已久表昔记於令差非嫌惑。 但长幼贵贱，年月赊促，各有终运，不必日均耳。 如其道超域外，心凝化表者，时或边应，作非复体谐。 接文殊之感，现净名之室，作宾友称寄，对扶桑谅，别有旨矣。 七月九日夜，见紫阳周王二真人，定录君三人，衣服并如前，侍者共可有十许人。 紫阳童亦在中，自共语良久。 定录君乃语子良曰：比劳用心，吾天事频烦，以疲我神，此六日，往东华，见尔名已上青简，乃位为保晨司，始吾徒也，不亦巍巍乎。 此乃冥符宿契，虽非此问之职，要应先当成就。 周紫阳仍曰：尔自应得此位，诸局司故不以明德相显，直奏功夫事，致使移时。 夫涉真境，便多有试，好固心力，勿弱於其问，王紫阳曰：得如此甚好，但恐以试为难耳。 子良因请问：不审几试，试若大小，恐肉人邪僻，能不忧惧。 王曰：当两小试，或为虎狼，或为殊声异形，以怖於人，尔见此时，但整心建意，勿悼惶也。 若不过者，怪应作壤字。 人功夫俄顷耳。 周少来神瞻强正，小儿时，独宿空屋，夜行林草，了无忌惮，未尝魇惊。 及来茅山，至移朱阳，晨夜间路去来，恒独行耳。

**Annotation:**
On this occasion, the Two Perfected of Ziyang and the Two Lords of Juqu seemed to descend for the first time. Yet in the previous sixth month, they had only dispatched their attendants. *The Declarations of the Perfected* states: "Zhou Taibin was skilled at playing the one-stringed zither; the one who instructed Sun Deng was the Right Lady of Penglai—this must refer to her." Sima Kuocang appears neither in internal nor external records, nor is he the same as Ji Zhu; rather, he must have been Ji Zhu’s son, Fayu. Only this single visitation is recorded, after which he withdrew into seclusion. In the fourth month of this year, he dreamed of being summoned, saying that the official bureau was already prepared, save only for the seal, which had not yet been made. His heart was heavy with concern, and he went directly to Zhou to speak of it. Zhou then told his aunt of this, and she secretly arranged a delicate missive, instructing Pan Yuanwen to draft a memorial. Together with Zhou, they submitted the petition. Later, he retreated into seclusion in the Tianchuang Cavern, and nothing more was known. Only afterward did they learn of this, though they did not inquire whether Zhou had approved. By the thirteenth day of the seventh month, the matter was resolved. At dawn on the fourteenth, Zhou received the memorial and was shown the details. He had heard of this only once, yet it was said that there had been repeated delicate petitions—this remains unexplained.

On the third night of the seventh month in the year *yiwei*, nine women arrived. They wore dark green robes with crimson-green skirts, their waists girded with purple sashes, and golden bells hanging from their belts. Beneath the bells hung large black talismans. Their documents were written on blue slips. Each held a tablet in hand, white as jade, with seams resembling woven patterns, and small bells sewn into the stitching, chiming as they walked. One of the women was Liu Xuanwei, another Tao Zhi’an; the rest were unknown and unseen. Speaking to Lady Liu, one said: "Have you recently cultivated new studies? I have just returned from Donghua. The documents are roughly settled, and your name has been inscribed on the Azure Slips of Donghua—this is most fortunate." Lady Tao said: "I have heard that those who fast and await the Northern Dipper achieve greatness beyond words. I marvel at your resolve, yet even this star cannot be swiftly attained—it requires years of accumulation." Lady Liu then called to the other women: "This Zhou has the soaring elegance of clouds; he may be worthy of conversation." One replied: "A minor immortal dares not speak with one so exalted." Liu said: "High and low are not so easily fixed. He remains mired in the dust and clamor—we merely seek to awaken him. What exaltation is there?" The woman smiled and said: "We shall visit another time; now is not the occasion for words." Tao said: "In this passage, *Liu Miaoji* should be written as *Ji* (姬), as the oral transmission misrendered the character." Sun Fanghua and Ruan Huixiang—these three women—are absent from *The Declarations of the Perfected*. These three have cultivated diligently and attained transcendence, receiving their texts in the Eighth Vermilion Terrace of Fangzhu. They have become immortal consorts, which is how we now know of them. Liu said: "Zhou, do you desire this?" He replied: "I, a mere worm or bird, dare not aspire to such heights." She said: "You *can* aspire—that is why I tell you." Tao said: "The night grows late; we should depart." As they prepared to leave, the women said: "Wait for us." Then they vanished together.

This entry, recorded on the third night, was written on two small blue slips.

**Annotation:**
This refers to the previous month’s account of delivering the study register to Donghua, then descending after an audience with the King of Zhao. There were others who added playful or earnest words, expressing aspirations to harmonize the Two Modes, illuminate the sun and moon, and unite the qi of mountains and marshes, the convergence of yin and yang—all requiring pairing and mutual resonance. Even among the loftiest Perfected, this principle holds. Though long recorded in past accounts, the present discrepancy is not a matter of confusion. Yet distinctions of seniority and rank, of time’s length or brevity, each follow their own destined course—uniformity is not required. For those whose Dao transcends the mundane and whose minds congeal beyond transformation, responses may arise at the margins, no longer bound by conventional harmony. Like the resonance of Mañjuśrī or the manifestation in Vimalakīrti’s chamber, where guest and host exchange roles beneath the Fusang tree—this carries a different significance.

On the ninth night of the seventh month, the Two Perfected of Ziyang and Lord Zhou, along with the Registrar of Destinies and three others, appeared. Their attire was as before, and they were accompanied by some ten attendants. The Ziyang youth was also present, and they conversed at length. The Registrar of Destinies then said to Ziliang: "You have labored diligently. Heavenly affairs have frequently wearied my spirit. Six days ago, I went to Donghua and saw your name inscribed on the Azure Slips—you have been appointed as Controller of the Dawn, the first among my disciples. Is this not magnificent? This accords with the hidden tally of past vows. Though not strictly within this office’s purview, it should be fulfilled first." Lord Zhou of Ziyang added: "You were destined for this position. The various bureaus did not promote you based on manifest virtue but directly reported your cultivation—hence the delay. Entering the realm of the Perfected entails many trials. Steady your resolve and do not falter." Lord Wang of Ziyang said: "This is excellent, though I fear the trials may prove difficult." Ziliang then asked: "May I inquire how many trials there will be, and whether they are great or small? As a mortal, I fear I may falter in fear." Wang said: "There will be two minor trials: you may encounter tigers and wolves, or strange voices and forms to frighten you. When you see these, compose your mind and fortify your intent—do not be alarmed. If you do not falter, the apparitions will crumble like dust. Such trials are but a moment’s effort." Zhou had long possessed a strong and upright spirit. As a child, he slept alone in empty houses and walked through forests and grasses at night without fear, never suffering nightmares. Since coming to Maoshan and moving to Zhuyang, he often traveled the roads at dawn and dusk, always alone.

chunks.original_text: 始近问人说，从今八九月以来，绾察往反，必须一两人相伴，小侵闻。 则便执刀杖，人问何忽尔，亦为作伊呜相答，此当是去期。 近密防诸试，只二十六夕移东癣宿，亦使一道士，窗下伴眠。 道士觉其不得眠，数起，坐诵诸呎，说此复是临时，犹虑有异於平日，致惊怖耳，而遂得免过，当由功力强。 定录又曰：昨东华集诸司命，及土地神灵典司之徒，检课简录，见天下民人为善者，五十分无一，而况於神仙，万万之不过两三耳。 其中功夫已成而复落除者，亦不少。 吾将忧仙籍，无复人也。 兼运度已逼灾世，益难见。 束华上簿紫录内格中，有上上真录者五人，已落二人，补地解无复进补者，上中真者，二十八人，一落七人，二人补下仙，五人复还人中，唯上一人补耳。 上下真者三百人，一落二十六人，十一人补地解，十五人还民，中都复上八人耳。 上上仙者二百十一人，一落四十二人，十二人补三官中职，六人成尸解，二十四人成贱民，都成五十人耳。 上中仙者，二百九十三人，一落七十人，十人退成下仙，八人得尸解，五十一人还生民中。 复上十一人耳。 上下仙者，四百三人，一落七十八人，二十人为邓都所引，四人被考＇三官，五十四人还民间，复上十九人耳。 始今月标落，此诸人须至分节，当上言太极，更记死录於太山，见此辈良为可悲。 并皆修法不勤，或先亡引逮，所行乖道，或先勤后息，失此功夫，一何苦哉。 亦有垂登云天者，日月不空，并下教真人降授之，其或处在深山，或学道历年，人并不知此，吾等亦时时教授如尔，今日人谁知邪。 周君曰：茅定录说此者，是戒尔之深矣，勿怠惰於其问。 尔乃近在下品仙人耳，尔乃当登中仙之上； 得游行太极，控驾龙鳞，不亦快乎。 王君曰：茅定录及周紫阳所诚，实为深矣，足为 子之实录也。 此句曲山中，亦有三四人，入下仙品，欲知之乎。 子良因问家师陶公何如，答曰：假令尔如其者，则期真不难也。 陶久入下仙之上，乃范幼冲等也。 一本作中仙之中，后农墨点□，下仙之上，未解所以。 既云久入，今当由息替致降二阶邪。 范幼冲为童，初监出《真诰》中，未知真仙品，与都水监何如耳。 已说句曲有四人，欲知之乎，而竟不得问是谁，甚为可恨。 今以耳眼所闻见者，在男人中，有蒋薛，女人中，有蒋宋，并久就修学j其长少男女，南北亦复数人，或有德行，或有信识，但於学功未深耳。 许灵真虽先圣之胤，而有家累亦未得涉学。 杨超，远今虽在林屋，先是旧句曲道士，甚有才意，今未知谁当会此三人之数者，但应各加精勤，庶充此限耳。 子良又问子良姨何如，答曰：乃得无大过，但令勤之，后身或取耳，今生且未可言。 其姨母本钱塘人，姓张，三岁失父，随母重适永嘉徐家，仍冒徐姓。 十岁，便出家，随师学道，在余姚立精舍，性至真正，唯摄妹兄子良一人。 至年三十五，公制所逼，诸道义劝令其作方便，出适上虞朱家，而遂陷世法，以此耻慨，致结气病涉四年，育一男，便擭还永嘉，从此离绝。 至今十有一年，乃云，小来手未尝杀虫蚁，妄折花草，唯日中一食，而恨性过严治於目下刻急，如今所言，乃得无大过，独是不无小失，当以不能遂固节取命，兼挫辱於神鬼。

At first, when Zhou inquired of others, he was told that from the eighth or ninth month onward, he had been observed coming and going only with one or two companions, which was unusual for him. At the slightest disturbance, he would grasp a blade or staff. When asked why, he would merely respond with vague sounds—this was surely a sign of his impending departure. Recently, he had taken secret precautions against the trials: on the twenty-sixth evening, he moved to sleep in the eastern chamber, where a Daoist was arranged to keep vigil by the window. The Daoist noticed Zhou could not sleep and rose several times to sit and recite incantations, saying this was a critical moment—lest anything unusual occur to startle him. Yet he passed unscathed, surely by the strength of his cultivation.

The *Dinglu* further stated: Yesterday, the Eastern Flower gathered all the Directors of Destiny, the local earth deities, and their subordinates to review the records. They found that among the people of the world, not even one in fifty did good, let alone those pursuing immortality—scarcely two or three in ten thousand. Even among those whose cultivation had nearly succeeded, many later fell away. I fear the registers of immortals will soon have no names left. Moreover, the kalpa of disaster draws near, making it even harder to attain. In the Purple Register of the Eastern Flower’s ledgers, among the highest tier of Perfected, five were listed—two have already fallen, and no replacements have advanced to take their place. Among the upper-middle Perfected, twenty-eight were recorded; one fell, seven were demoted to lower immortals, five returned to the mortal realm, and only one advanced. Among the lower Perfected, three hundred were listed; twenty-six fell, eleven were demoted to earthbound immortals, fifteen returned to the people, and only eight advanced. Among the highest immortals, two hundred eleven were recorded; forty-two fell, twelve were demoted to mid-level offices in the Three Bureaus, six achieved corpse-liberation, twenty-four became lowly mortals—altogether, fifty fell. Among the upper-middle immortals, two hundred ninety-three were recorded; seventy fell, ten were demoted to lower immortals, eight achieved corpse-liberation, fifty-one returned to the mortal realm, and only eleven advanced. Among the lower immortals, four hundred three were recorded; seventy-eight fell, twenty were claimed by the Dark Capital, four were examined by the Three Bureaus, fifty-four returned to the mortal realm, and only nineteen advanced.

This month’s marked demotions will soon reach their appointed time. They must be reported to the Supreme Ultimate, and their names recorded in the ledgers of Mount Tai. Seeing such cases is truly lamentable. All failed due to lax cultivation: some were led astray by the recently deceased, others strayed from the Dao in their conduct, or began diligently but later slackened, losing their progress—how bitter! Yet there are those on the verge of ascending to the heavens, their days and months not spent in vain. All were instructed by descending Perfected Ones. Some dwell deep in the mountains, others have studied the Dao for years, yet none are known to the world. We, too, often teach as we do you—who among today’s people would recognize this?

Zhou said: What the *Dinglu* of Mao recounts is a profound warning to you. Do not grow idle in your inquiries. You now stand among the lowest immortals, yet you may ascend to the upper ranks of the middle immortals—able to roam the Supreme Ultimate, riding the scales of dragons. Is that not joyous?

Master Wang said: The admonitions of the *Dinglu* of Mao and Zhou Ziyang are indeed profound, sufficient to serve as your true record. Here in the mountains of Juqu, there are three or four who have entered the ranks of lower immortals. Would you like to know of them?

Ziliang then asked about his teacher, Master Tao. The reply: If you were like him, attaining Perfection would not be difficult. Tao has long stood at the upper ranks of lower immortals—such as Fan Youchong and others. (One version reads: "middle ranks of middle immortals," but later, a note in black ink marks it as "upper ranks of lower immortals," though the reason is unclear.) Since it is said he has long held this rank, has he now slackened, causing his demotion by two stages? When Fan Youchong was a child, he first supervised the transcription of the *Zhen’gao*, unaware of the ranks of true immortals—how did he compare to the Director of Waterways?

It was said there are four in Juqu—would you like to know who they are? Yet the question was never asked, which is most regrettable. From what I have seen and heard, among men there are Jiang and Xue; among women, Jiang and Song. All have long pursued cultivation, young and old, male and female, from north and south—some for their virtue, others for their faith and insight, though their study is not yet deep. Xu Lingzhen, though descended from a former sage, has not yet engaged in study due to family burdens. Yang Chao, though now at Linwu, was once a Daoist of old Juqu, possessing great talent and ambition. I do not yet know who among these three will meet the count, but all should redouble their diligence to fulfill this limit.

Ziliang further asked about his aunt. The reply: She has committed no great transgressions, but if she remains diligent, she may yet attain it in a future life—nothing can be said of this one. His aunt, originally from Qiantang, was surnamed Zhang. At three, she lost her father and followed her mother to remarry into the Xu family of Yongjia, taking their surname. At ten, she left home to study the Dao under a master, establishing a hermitage in Yuyao. Her nature was utterly sincere, and she cared for no one but her nephew, Ziliang. At thirty-five, pressed by imperial decree and urged by fellow Daoists to make concessions, she married into the Zhu family of Shangyu, thus entangled in worldly affairs. Ashamed and resentful, she fell ill with qi stagnation for four years, bore a son, then fled back to Yongjia, severing all ties. To this day—eleven years later—she claims never to have killed an insect or ant in her life, nor carelessly plucked flowers or grass, eating but one meal a day. Yet she regrets her nature was too severe, her discipline too harsh. What she has said shows no great faults, though she is not without minor failings. She should have steadfastly preserved her integrity to fulfill her destiny, rather than suffering humiliation before gods and ghosts.

chunks.original_text: 故也学业既浅，岂望今身有果，但两三生得以为幸矣。 周君更问子良·尔姓何等。 子良仓卒不得道前赐名字，直云姓周名子良。 君勃然曰：何以谬滥，汝乃道士周太玄，字虚灵，而比於世中周子良邪。 汝名书玉简皆作周太玄，勿复胜。 应作称字。 子良唯於世上名子良耳，勿以隐名示於俗人。 天下人应得道者，何限而偏依依於尔。 非直以挺命感真，亦如以亲逮故耳。 昔有杨许者，杨恒有神真往来，而许永不得见。 所以尔者，许心徒勤谦犹，欲想未除，故不得见。 杨位亦不大於许，其神凝志安，万邪不能干，其正华绮不能乱其心，故受语於杨，今以示许也。 尔今得见吾等，亦如杨之用行耳。 凡此事莫轻示人，吾昔与裴清灵去来华侨处，受其言语，令以示许侨宿本俗民，性气虚疏，不能隐秘。 告其一法，回而加增，逢人不问愚贤辄敢便说之。 如此既多，便回受於扬耳。 侨乃流沉河水，身没异方，得脱以来始十四年耳。 今犹在鬼伍，昼夜辛勤，诸如此事，可不慎乎，尔勿示人此事也。 扬许及华侨事皆出《真诰》中也。 定录曰：昨见杨在束华，吾乃要来，其云欲来，碍以诸事，别当看之耳。 王君曰：此月初，乃见许侯与紫微夫人及右英，共辔龙车，往诣南真。 紫微问我，见有周太玄已刻紫录，将应得道，比欲观其德业，君见之不。 吾因答已经诣之，乃有萧然之德，甚可启悟紫微。 言别往看之，明年秋事令得去。 紫微夫人主下教者。 定录曰：言语粗悉，足为周生保试，今且去，天务繁多，明日望定。 因相随而去，此二更中来，入四更乃去，言语多亦不能尽得记忆也。 右一条，九日夜所受记，书五白官纸。 此条中，多说上落及宣漏诸事，全是欲严相诚，防恐脱言说，便致谴黜，既如此，伊何由敢显，虽复王威加逼，金帛满堂，亦当杜口道义等。 故自息求而此中引杨许之谕一亦何必不别有所指，追恨不知早相共理，令阙佚渐加钻访，必不徒然往矣。 如何犹冀於冥途之中，既更通感耳。 七月十一日夜，见桐桥徐邓二人来，衣服皆如前，徐至，便言曰：名已果上束华，定为保晨司，甚助欣庆。 邓曰：昨已应有说此事者，子良答尔诸真，亦粗说其事，但子良庸陋，岂敢仰希恃蒙神真提拂不论耳。 徐曰：近见赵威伯，作事上保命，曰：周子良，字元稣，右一人，改名太玄，字虚灵。 以其生周逵家，巳上紫录，次生刘伟家，复书玉编，既经历辛勤，今谨依上科，报以下仙为保籍丞，羽仪衣服如故法。 保命仍将往，共定录省察良久，乃作赞，上束华曰：周玄秀德，心志虚清，谨按紫格，可刻仙名。 束华乃更命，以七月七日，会仙官检名薄，因得尔品目位，合中仙，更奏上仙，为保晨司韩侯。 仍作事曰：周太玄，字虚灵，右一人，昔标怀道之志，今建荡然之德，上合乾纲，下应地纪，依如仙格，合中品之上，伏见保晨司年限欲满，请选太玄以补之。 谨上青君，命云如牒，仍作简文曰： 惟周太玄因业树兹刻名仙简为保晨司。 此韩侯刻紫玉之简，赤金为文，以上言太上也。 吾闻此位，寻满不出一二年中，应相召也。 子良问：不审此位，若为羽仪。 徐答曰：亦不可为定，更由功业之高下，理有丹龙绿车玄羽之盖，素毛之节，青衣玉女五人，朱衣玉童七人，执鸿翮之扇，建扶灵之冠，服紫羽之被，绛霄之衣，带宝玉之铃，六丁为使，万神受保。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, with my learning so shallow, how could I hope for fruition in this life? To achieve it in two or three lifetimes would already be fortunate.

Master Zhou further asked Ziliang, “What is your surname?”

Flustered, Ziliang could not recall the name previously bestowed upon him and simply replied, “I am surnamed Zhou, named Ziliang.”

The master grew stern: “How dare you be so careless? You are Daoist Zhou Taixuan, styled Xuling—how could you be confused with the worldly Zhou Ziliang? Your name is inscribed on jade tablets as Zhou Taixuan. Do not presume to use it lightly. You should address yourself by your style.”

Ziliang said, “In the world, I am only known as Ziliang. I would not reveal my hidden name to common folk.”

The master replied, “Those in the world who are destined for the Dao are without limit—why should they cling solely to you? It is not merely because your fate moves the Perfected, but also because of the bond of kinship. Long ago, there were Yang and Xu: Yang Heng was visited by divine Perfected, yet Xu Yong never saw them. The reason was that Xu’s heart, though diligent and humble, was not free of desire and attachment, so he could not behold them. Yang’s rank was no higher than Xu’s, but his spirit was serene and steadfast, untroubled by the myriad distractions. His mind was not swayed by the splendor of the world, so he received the teachings from Yang and later conveyed them to Xu.

“That you now see us is akin to Yang’s role. Do not lightly reveal these matters to others. Once, I traveled with Pei Qingling to Hua Qiao’s abode, where we received his instructions to convey them to Xu Qiao. But Xu was of common stock, his nature careless and undisciplined, unable to keep secrets. When taught a single method, he would embellish it and, without discernment, reveal it to anyone he met. After many such incidents, he was punished by Yang. Xu was cast into the river and drowned in a foreign land. Only fourteen years have passed since his escape, yet he remains among the ranks of ghosts, toiling day and night. Matters such as these—can you not be cautious? Do not reveal these things to others.”

The stories of Yang, Xu, and Hua Qiao all appear in the *True Reports*.

The *Record of Determinations* states: “Yesterday, I saw Yang in the Eastern Flower and invited him to come. He said he wished to, but was hindered by various matters and would visit another time.”

Master Wang said, “At the beginning of this month, I saw Lord Xu riding a dragon chariot with the Lady of Purple Tenuity and the Lady of Right Radiance, journeying to the Southern Perfected. The Lady of Purple Tenuity asked me if I had seen Zhou Taixuan, whose name is already inscribed in the Purple Register and who is destined for the Dao. She wished to observe his virtue and deeds. Have you seen him?”

I replied that I had visited him and found him possessed of a refined and solitary virtue, well-suited to enlighten the Lady of Purple Tenuity. She said she would visit him again next year, and by autumn, his affairs would be settled so he could depart.

The Lady of Purple Tenuity oversees the instruction of those below.

The *Record of Determinations* said, “Your words are rough but sufficient to serve as a trial for Zhou. For now, depart. Heavenly duties are many, and I shall await your return tomorrow.”

They left with me, arriving at the second watch and departing at the fourth. Their words were too numerous to recall in full.

---

This entry was received on the night of the ninth day and recorded on five sheets of official paper. Much of it concerns comings and goings, as well as proclamations and admonitions—all intended to impress caution, lest careless speech lead to punishment and demotion. Given this, how could they dare to reveal such matters? Even if pressed by the authority of kings or halls filled with gold and silk, they would seal their lips and uphold the Dao.

Thus, I ceased my inquiries, though this passage citing Yang and Xu’s admonition may well have another purpose. I regret not having discussed these matters with them earlier, for now, gaps remain, and though I continue to seek answers, it will not be in vain. How can I still hope for communication in the unseen realm? Yet there is still resonance.

---

On the night of the eleventh day of the seventh month, Xu and Deng of Tong Bridge arrived, dressed as before. Xu approached and said, “Your name has already been submitted to the Eastern Flower, and you have been appointed as an attendant in the Office of Dawn Protection. This is a great cause for celebration.”

Deng said, “This matter was foretold yesterday. Ziliang, you have already roughly explained it to the various Perfected. But you are of humble and unrefined nature—how dare you aspire to rely on the favor of divine Perfected?”

Xu said, “Recently, I saw Zhao Weibo, who serves in the Office of Life Protection. He said: ‘Zhou Ziliang, styled Yuansu, is now one person. His name is to be changed to Taixuan, styled Xuling. Born in the household of Zhou Kui, his name was first inscribed in the Purple Register. In his next life, he was born in the household of Liu Wei, and his name was again recorded in the Jade Register. Having endured hardships, he now strictly follows the celestial statutes and is to be reported as a minor immortal, appointed as Attendant of the Protective Register. His feathered regalia and attire remain as before. The Protector of Life will proceed to the Office of Determined Records to examine the matter at length, then compose a eulogy to be presented to the Eastern Flower, saying:

*‘Zhou Taixuan possesses refined virtue, his heart and will empty and pure. According to the Purple Register, his immortal name may be inscribed.’*

The Eastern Flower then decreed that on the seventh day of the seventh month, the immortal officials would convene to review the register of names. Thus, your rank and position were determined: you are to be a middle-grade immortal, and a further petition has been made to promote you to the rank of upper immortal, appointing you as Attendant of the Office of Dawn Protection under the Han Lord.”

The document further states: *“Zhou Taixuan, styled Xuling, once nurtured the aspiration for the Dao and has now cultivated a vast and untrammeled virtue. Above, he aligns with the celestial principles; below, he accords with the terrestrial order. According to the immortal statutes, he is fit for the upper rank of the middle grade. As the term of the current Attendant of the Office of Dawn Protection nears its end, we request that Taixuan be selected to succeed him.”*

Respectfully submitted to the Azure Lord, the decree reads as follows:

*“Whereas Zhou Taixuan, by virtue of his deeds, has earned the inscription of his name on the immortal tablets, he is hereby appointed as Attendant of the Office of Dawn Protection.”*

This Han Lord inscribed the purple jade tablet with characters of red gold, addressing the Supreme.

I have heard that this position is typically filled within one or two years, and you will likely be summoned then.

Ziliang asked, “What are the regalia for this position?”

Xu replied, “It cannot be fixed in advance, for it depends on the height of one’s merit. In principle, it may include a cinnabar dragon and green chariot, a canopy of black feathers, a staff of white plumes, five jade maidens in blue robes, seven jade lads in red, holding fans of swan feathers, wearing crowns of divine support, clad in robes of purple feathers and crimson clouds, girded with jade bells. The Six Dings will serve as messengers, and the myriad spirits will be under your protection.”

chunks.original_text: 知天下神仙功夫之事，教学之方，非复人间保籍丞也。 故指来相报，未可示人身之遗迩，乃后人之所效耳。 邓曰：桐梧真君，乃欲来，须见太虚，司阴二真。 既累去后，与两／J ’儿竟夕拼档，恐明日人来，见纵边於是，内外无知者，以至于今，唯密以启闻耳，寻此便是前绿所招，或咎谴应至定录，赵丞灼然知见，而不可校也。 寻既未知，应为此位，那言不大欲为，恐是悬照。 此意自发上道心，察老君诚解，其性理习忘，相怀於一切有为，无复执着。 与时求道之志，便有浓淡，故以推心，知当不大欲为耳。 今既忘言於取舍，便亦不辞此任。 但令得在能利益众生，处虽卑虽苦，甘心为之。 后云虽欲荡情散虑，亦未能都去，此实神察六七往道中，犹烦恼未尽，泛此信忍，望都除邪。 五年十年，非但未定朝闻夕殡，亦是所愿，周生既已见舍，便欲促往寻之，依别记目录。 此月十五日，保命授三天龙文并令，且混人勿异边行来动静，但意云此一条不显出，恐是与龙文别封也。 右一条，十一日夜所受记，书三白官纸。 此条中便是定位，即云待前人满，则未便到职。 但未知犹且领丞，任俟期而去，为不成称丞，直游散住邪。 此非可意求，须有通感髻鬃，乃可知耳。 计今必应，犹在洞中也。 十三日夜，定录赵丞俱来。 定录曰：昨与思和至太元府，仍诣南夫人，论陶某事，乃得由少时。 子良问申几时，又曰：未测几时，或五年十年，事虽关，我亦由上府，继束华隶司命，未敢为定。 赵丞仍曰：且已被束宫命令且住召陶某事子良。 问召为何职仙官鬼官，丞答：蓬莱都水监高光，坐治水事，被责，似欲以陶代之。 既且停召，当更选耳。 此是仙官隶司阴府掌水事，以陶有劳，故得补之。 如陶意似不大欲为此位，既仙，陶当不知卿可以事白陶也。 少许时，又曰：夫人生祸延福赓，皆有因而至，非神明之所，如陶今夕心意，岂复忆此，虽云欲荡情散虑，恐亦未能，都去如何。 复言合丹事云云。 不知此所道弗闻，可恨也。 又言青童大君，月未当来，华当脱阳字检选仙事云云。 右一条，十三日夜所受记，书一小白纸。 按此告，即符前二日所云，中旬问共为论也。 周以十四清旦，来入岭止疏前停，召事见示，即问周何意，有今夕心意语，答云：亦不解所以，见意色甚不好，子良，亦不敢问，于时，既密解此意，便止不更重论岭裹以。 十三夕一更，忽被冠似有六七人，皆执杖奄至阶前，前一人，唤言在御仗中，蒙假还，束畔等数人乏资粮，故来就先生乞，于时已闭户，未眠闻此，便开户当对呼进，随意所须衣服物器，一皆舍与，别屋雨小儿并被录置。 既从来未尝见此，不能不惧，而犹向其道，但各取重担，徐去必无告讨，正恐君劫道士罪重，我当作好意，相与使后也。 十八日夜，见定录，曰：陶乃答吾前语年限犹未定，别更报尔。 所云欲住雷平山后，此亦不胜，今居论灾，厉刀兵水火之事，乃为好耳。 此地本非可隐居寂处，直可以避灾害，住与不住，无胜否也。 又论方托形何处，此由人心，心既未发，吾宁得知方将而言，唯句曲可住，昊越名山乃不少，未见有大胜地，犹劝陶居此山。 右一条，十八日夜所受记，书一白藤纸。

Here the Master revealed the arts of divine transcendents and the methods of their instruction—no longer the mere office of a mortal registrar of records.

Thus, he pointed to what would come in due course, though it could not yet be shown to those near or far, serving only as a model for later generations.

Deng said, “The True Lord of Tongwu wishes to come, but must first meet with the Supreme Void and the Two Perfected of the Ministry of Yin.”

After repeated departures, he had spent the entire night in close counsel with his two disciples, fearing that if others arrived the next day and saw them in such disarray, word might spread. Thus, he kept it secret, revealing it only in private report. This matter, in fact, was precisely what the Green One had previously summoned him for—perhaps a reprimand or censure was due, as recorded in the celestial registers. Steward Zhao clearly knew of it, yet it could not be contested.

Upon reflection, though he did not yet know whether he would assume this position, he felt no great desire for it, fearing it might be a mere illusion. Yet this reluctance arose from his devotion to the Dao, for he had examined Lord Lao’s teachings and understood that the nature of principle lies in forgetting. He no longer clung to all that is conditioned, and his resolve to seek the Dao had grown faint. Thus, he surmised that he would not greatly desire the office.

Now that he had forgotten distinctions of acceptance and rejection, he would not refuse the task. If only he could benefit sentient beings, he would gladly endure lowly or arduous stations.

Later, he admitted that though he wished to dissolve emotions and scatter thoughts, he had not yet fully succeeded. This was indeed a divine insight from his six or seven past journeys on the Dao—his afflictions were not yet exhausted, and he relied on this faith and forbearance, hoping to eradicate them entirely. Whether it took five years or ten, he would not regret hearing of it at dawn only to perish by dusk. It was his wish.

Since Zhou had already seen him relinquish the matter, he wished to hasten and seek him out, following the separate record’s catalog.

On the fifteenth of the month, he received the *Three Heavens’ Dragon Script* for life preservation, along with its commands, and was instructed to blend in with mortals without drawing attention to his movements.

This passage, written on three sheets of white official paper, was the record received on the night of the eleventh. Within it lay the confirmation of his appointment, stating that he would not assume office until his predecessor’s term was complete. For now, he remained a provisional registrar, awaiting the appointed time before departing—though it was unclear whether he would truly hold the title or merely wander freely.

This was not a matter of personal desire; only when his topknot and temples showed signs of spiritual resonance could it be known.

By his calculations, he must still be in the grotto.

On the night of the thirteenth, Steward Zhao of the Celestial Registers arrived with them. Zhao said, “Yesterday, I went with Sihe to the Palace of the Supreme Origin and then called upon the Southern Lady to discuss Tao’s case. It was resolved in a short while.”

Ziliang asked when the summons would be issued, but Zhao replied, “It is uncertain—perhaps five or ten years. Though the matter concerns me, I must first report to the Upper Palace. I have been assigned to assist the Ministry of Destiny, so I dare not make a definitive statement.”

Steward Zhao then said, “I have been ordered by the Eastern Palace to temporarily halt the summons of Tao.”

Ziliang asked whether the summons was for a celestial or ghostly office. Zhao answered, “It is for the position of High Radiance, Director of the Penglai Waterworks, who oversees water affairs. He was reprimanded, and it seems they wish Tao to replace him. However, the summons has been suspended, and another will be selected instead. This is a celestial office under the Ministry of Yin, overseeing water affairs. Tao is being considered for it due to his merits.”

“Since Tao is a transcendent, he may not be aware of this. You may inform him.”

After a moment, Zhao added, “Fortune and misfortune in life arise from causes, not from the will of the gods. Tao’s thoughts tonight—how could he recall such things? Though he speaks of dissolving emotions and scattering thoughts, he has not yet fully succeeded. How could he let them go entirely?”

He then spoke of alchemical matters, but the details were unclear—what a pity.

He also mentioned that the Great Lord of the Azure Youth would arrive when the moon was full, and that Hua would be exempted from the selection of transcendents under the *Yang* register.

This passage, written on a small sheet of white paper, was the record received on the night of the thirteenth. It aligned with what had been discussed two days prior, around the middle of the month.

On the fourteenth at dawn, Zhou entered the mountain pass and halted the previous summons, showing it to Tao. When asked his thoughts, Tao replied that he did not understand the reason, but his expression was grim. Ziliang dared not press further. Realizing the gravity of the matter, he ceased discussing it within the pass.

chunks.original_text: ．陶隐居既得周所宣事，以十五日疏作辞语，与周令接觐之日为申陈，如此，即是相酬之告，周竟不以此见向道，当是无正可否以宣也。 于时至尊垂恩，为置宋长沙道士二癣，并左右空地於此癣西，复为起观前左右，即是许长史旧基窃恐则近真纵。 或以致谴，故二三因闻耳，追恨不得作方富通辞方富通辞则亦应方万酬答也。 二十五日夜，梦见唐赵二丞来。 赵曰：近何意恒劳苦，损人精神，僭人耳眼，今去勿复遇辛苦。 子良问：不审住此癣中好否，比者恒忧与盗事。 赵回头曰：此事关唐丞。 唐丞仍曰：虽见关，亦不得自由，夫灾祸，亦非鬼神所知。 此癣自不须多忧，疲人心虑，子良言劫盗事，深以仰凭。 答曰：自保勖，不须过忧，便去。 君论期运事竟，应相造也。 我等且去，寻复相过。 子良起送，相随而灭。 右一条，二十五日夜梦所受，记书一白官纸。 此夏旱，人情恶，山有尊长，但虑惊怖富。 故以此祈访也。 唐丞，名公房，亦四丞之一，云主死生，计劫盗事，正应由乐丞不知关唐也。 记中从来见唐来事，今若始遂，应有始相识语，恐前已有，不必存记耳。 西应此后，至今顾蒙安隐也。 依别记目录，此月二十八日，唐丞又云劫盗事，不令忧云云。 此不显，恐是不录也。 右起七月三日至二十五日，几有七条事，书青白大小合十纸。 於目录中阙一条，余悉具足也。 周氏冥通记卷之三竟 周氏冥通记卷之四 此卷从乙未年五月二十三日初通，至丙申年七月末，月月悉记所通目录。 其五六七月并具有，即前别三卷。 自八月后，至今年七月末，止有此年目录，无更别记。 乙未年五月二十三日昼，保命府赵丞告。 云云。 乙未年五月二十三日夜，保命范帅告。 云云。 乙未年五月二十七日夜，中岳仙人洪先生告伺二星。 云云。 乙未年五月二十八日昼，梦食合金液醮。 云云。 右四条，五月中事，今别撰在第一巷。

Tao the Recluse, having received the proclamation from Zhou, composed a memorial on the fifteenth to present upon their next meeting, framing it as a formal response. This would have served as a reciprocal declaration, yet Zhou ultimately did not regard it as an appeal to the Dao—perhaps because there was no clear affirmation or denial to proclaim.

At the time, the August Emperor, in his grace, granted two parcels of land for Daoist cultivation in Changsha of Song, along with adjacent vacant plots to the west of this site. He further ordered the construction of halls on either side of the front courtyard, which happened to occupy the former grounds of Director Xu. I privately feared that such proximity to the true transcendents might invite reproach, and thus I heard of this matter only indirectly, regretting that I could not compose a more eloquent petition in response—had I done so, it would surely have been met with a thousandfold reply.

On the night of the twenty-fifth, I dreamed of Attendants Tang and Zhao arriving. Zhao said, “Why do you persist in such toil, depleting your spirit, straining your ears and eyes? Depart now, and spare yourself further hardship.” Ziliang asked, “Is it favorable to reside in this sanctuary? Lately, I have been constantly anxious about banditry.” Zhao turned and said, “This concerns Attendant Tang.” Tang then replied, “Though it concerns me, I am not at liberty to decide. As for calamities, even spirits and gods cannot foresee them. You need not fret excessively over this sanctuary, for it wearies the mind. As for Ziliang’s mention of bandit raids, he relies on us deeply.” He answered, “Take care and do not worry overmuch,” then departed. “Our discussion of fate and destiny is not yet concluded; we shall visit again.” I rose to see them off, and they vanished as they followed one another away.

This passage, received in a dream on the night of the twenty-fifth, was recorded on a sheet of white official paper.

That summer, the drought had soured the people’s temper, and the mountain’s venerable elders feared only alarm and terror. Thus, I sought their counsel through this inquiry. Attendant Tang, named Gongfang, was one of the Four Attendants, said to govern life and death, and to calculate matters of banditry—though it should have been Attendant Le who held jurisdiction, I did not realize it concerned Tang. In past records, whenever Tang appeared, there were always introductory exchanges, as if we were meeting for the first time. Perhaps such details were already noted and need not be preserved here.

From this point onward, until now, I have enjoyed peace and security. According to a separate record’s catalog, on the twenty-eighth of this month, Attendant Tang again spoke of banditry, urging me not to worry, and so forth. This was not made explicit, so I feared it might not be transcribed.

From the third to the twenty-fifth of the seventh month, there were nearly seven entries, written on ten sheets of blue and white paper of varying sizes. One entry is missing from the catalog, but the rest are complete.

*Record of Zhou’s Communications with the Unseen, Scroll Three* concludes here.

*Record of Zhou’s Communications with the Unseen, Scroll Four*

This scroll begins with the first communication on the twenty-third day of the fifth month in the year *yiwei* and continues through the seventh month of the year *bingshen*, with a monthly catalog of all recorded communications. The fifth, sixth, and seventh months are fully documented in the preceding three separate scrolls. From the eighth month onward, only this year’s catalog remains, with no further records.

The above four entries pertain to matters of the fifth month and are now compiled separately in the first fascicle.

chunks.original_text: 阙二条，今见有七条，并或见或梦。 并右三十条，并有具记。 唯阙五条。 从此后，并无别记，实为深恨。 乙未年八月一日，范监来告云：此日诸真相就论说欢已毕，自今已后，欲令自来，处处游观。 云云，此云来则非梦。 八月五日，梦从一朱门崇阙入，见司命君，见授夜光芝。 云云，夜光芝是句曲五种芝限。 八月七日，梦入华阳中，先经保命府，后至定录问次往萧闲探龙仙芝。 云云。 此则从北入而向南也。 龙仙芝亦见五种芝限。 八月九日，梦至定录，问见，问云乃同人斋邪。 云云。 尔日在中堂，王法明为皇家涂炭斋。 八月十二日，梦与定录君於华阳内共乘车，侍玉女三十人，奏天乐，造南真於丹城，南真见告。 云云。 因又告太元，太元示以仙籍。 云云。 二真府并在大霍也。 八月十五日，梦与定录保命，共往紫微夫人处。 云云。 紫微治玄龙宫，应在北方。 八月十六日，梦至方诸，见青君府，不见青君。 乃见韩太华，丹青馆宋夫人见，告神仙之要，委形之术。 云韩太华，始以今年度束宫，受书朱宫玉妃之宾友韩，出《真诰》也。 八月十九日，又梦造方诸，正见青君出游，杨君九华及许仙侯皆从。 因造韩侯见告簿籍事。 云云韩即前卷所云东宫典录籍者，名惠期也。 八月二十一日，梦与保命至蓬莱，见周大夫。 又至一朱台巨阙青轩紫房，云是司阴府陶某近正应肩治此束南一玄宫中。 因复行，见一人，面金色，长短中形，人着飞霄衣冠，见告道法之事。 云云保命曰：此是小天奉法人周大夫，仍告道业因绿甚多。 云云.周大夫，即大宾。 《真拙婴亦云：在蓬莱，司阴君主天下水事，事出马君传前，不知那治在蓬莱小方诸，多事道事，亦出《真拙阁》。 八月二十五日，梦与范监赵丞至大衡山，见南陵薜大夫，中黄杜大夫，见授隐变方。 因尔又行，见一草屋，甚高大绝，有甘泉，杂生众华。 范监云：此是游仙之庐，因共入，坐屋下谈神仙事。 云云。 薛杜二大夫《真诰》中无也。

Two entries are missing, and now seven remain, some witnessed in waking vision and others in dreams. Together with the thirty entries above, all have detailed records. Only five are missing. From this point onward, no further records exist, which is deeply regrettable.

On the first day of the eighth month in the year *yiwei*, Attendant Fan arrived with a proclamation, stating: "Today, the various Perfected Ones gathered to discuss and celebrate, and from now on, they wish for you to come freely and wander wherever you please." This visitation was not a dream.

On the fifth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I entered through a vermilion gate and towering palace, where I saw the Lord of Life’s Register. He bestowed upon me a luminous zhi fungus. The luminous zhi is one of the five varieties of zhi from Mount Gouqu.

On the seventh day of the eighth month, in a dream, I entered Huayang, first passing through the Palace of Life Preservation, then proceeding to the Office of Destiny to inquire about the whereabouts of the Celestial Dragon’s zhi in Xiaoxian. This journey went from north to south. The Celestial Dragon’s zhi is also one of the five varieties of zhi.

On the ninth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I arrived at the Office of Destiny and was questioned upon seeing them, asking whether I had joined others in a purification fast. That day, in the central hall, Wang Faming conducted a *tutan* fast for the imperial family.

On the twelfth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I rode in a carriage with the Lord of Destiny within Huayang, accompanied by thirty jade maidens playing celestial music. We visited the Southern Perfected in the Cinnabar City, where the Southern Perfected delivered a proclamation. They then reported to the Supreme Prime, who showed me the registers of immortality. Both Perfected residences are located on Great Mount Huo.

On the fifteenth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I traveled with the Lords of Destiny and Life Preservation to the abode of the Lady of Purple Tenuity. The Lady of Purple Tenuity governs the Dark Dragon Palace, which should lie in the north.

On the sixteenth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I arrived at Fangzhu and saw the residence of the Azure Lord, though I did not see the Azure Lord himself. Instead, I met Han Taihua, and Lady Song of the Vermilion and Azure Pavilion appeared, instructing me on the essentials of divine transcendence and the art of relinquishing form. Han Taihua was initially appointed this year to the Eastern Palace, where he received the books of the Vermilion Palace as a companion to the Jade Consort Han, as recorded in the *True Annals*.

On the nineteenth day of the eighth month, in another dream, I visited Fangzhu and encountered the Azure Lord on an outing, accompanied by Lord Yang Jiuhua and Immortal Marquis Xu. I then visited Marquis Han, who informed me of matters concerning the celestial registers. This Han is the same as the one previously mentioned in the records as the Keeper of Registers in the Eastern Palace, named Huiqi.

On the twenty-first day of the eighth month, in a dream, I traveled with the Lord of Life Preservation to Penglai, where I saw Minister Zhou. We then arrived at a vermilion terrace with towering gates, green eaves, and purple chambers. It was said that this was the Office of the Yin Bureau, where a certain Tao was recently appointed to govern this northeastern dark palace. Continuing on, I saw a person with a golden complexion, of medium stature, dressed in soaring-cloud robes and cap. He instructed me on matters of the Dao and its methods. The Lord of Life Preservation said: "This is Minister Zhou, a minor celestial official of the Dao. He has also expounded on many causes and conditions of the Dao’s work." Minister Zhou is the same as the Grand Guest. The *True and Unadorned* also states: "On Penglai, the Lord of the Yin Bureau oversees the world’s water affairs," as recorded in the earlier traditions of Master Ma. It is unclear whether his governance lies in the lesser Fangzhu of Penglai. Many matters of the Dao also appear in the *True and Unadorned Pavilion*.

On the twenty-fifth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I traveled with Attendants Fan and Zhao to Great Mount Heng, where I saw Minister Xue of Nanling and Minister Du of the Central Yellow. They bestowed upon me the method of concealment and transformation. Proceeding further, I saw a thatched hut, exceedingly tall and vast, with sweet springs and various flowers growing around it. Attendant Fan said: "This is the abode of wandering immortals." We entered together and sat beneath the hut, discussing matters of divine transcendence. Neither Minister Xue nor Minister Du appear in the *True Annals*.

chunks.original_text: 八月二十五日，梦入华阳，造定录，谘来年十月可保得申延不。 答云：可尔。 云云此其犹欲留世意。 所以发此请，虽初云可尔，恐后复相请，却审得申者，则不应，十月果去也。 八月二十六日夜，梦定录保命来见，告云明当复往东华过司命问，既是天事不复得同，当更为访韩侯论尔，不更回异不。 些刖及复屡道名简事，此则不可为定，进退皆复由功过故也。 八月二十九日，见上期来宣定录旨云：韩侯甚有怀於尔，简录犹因。 云云。 此云见来，则非梦也。
chunks.translated_text:
On the twenty-fifth day of the eighth month, in a dream, I entered Huayang and presented myself at the *Dinglu* Register, where I inquired whether I might secure an extension until the tenth month of the coming year. The answer came: "It may be so." This still reflected an intention to remain in the world. The reason for making this request—though the initial response was affirmative—was the fear that further entreaties might follow. If, upon careful reconsideration, the extension were granted, then it would not be so; indeed, by the tenth month, I would depart.

On the night of the twenty-sixth day of the eighth month, in a dream, the *Dinglu* Register’s Protector of Life came to see me and announced: "Tomorrow, I shall again journey to Donghua to consult the Controller of Destinies. Since this is a matter of heavenly decree, I cannot act in accord with you. I shall instead seek out Lord Han to discuss the matter. There will be no further discrepancies." Some details regarding names and records were repeatedly mentioned, but these cannot be fixed, for advance or retreat still depend on the balance of merit and transgression.

On the twenty-ninth day of the eighth month, I received a summons to the appointed audience, where the decree of the *Dinglu* Register was proclaimed: "Lord Han holds you in deep regard; the records remain contingent." This encounter was not a dream.
chunks.overlap_context: Mount Heng, where I saw Minister Xue of Nanling and Minister Du of the Central Yellow. They bestowed upon me the method of concealment and transformation. Proceeding further, I saw a thatched hut, exceedingly tall and vast, with sweet springs and various flowers growing around it. Attendant Fan said: "This is the abode of wandering immortals." We entered together and sat beneath the hut, discussing matters of divine transcendence. Neither Minister Xue nor Minister Du appear in the *True Annals*.

chunks.original_text: 上期是华阳重姓，景名上期也。 右十三条，八月中事二条是来，十一条是梦往。 九月二日，梦至华阳中见二君。 云云。 九月五日，梦又至蓬莱，先过司命。 司命见告：服神丹应，先须名上仙籍，乃得服之。 云云乃至蓬莱见周大夫，食一草，状如槐香而紫色，见告云：子未得食此，得食此，便如吾耳，及火枣交梨事？ 云云火枣交梨出《真诰》中亦竟不知此果是何神奇。 九月八日，梦与赵丞共游易迁，童初二宫，二宫相去可五六里。 易迁，女仙宫。 童初，男仙宫。 而未知东西列为南北列耳也。 九月十日，梦与保命到一山，山形平团，异於人问，山名为丹龙，云中有洞，多仙真。 丹龙云在阳洛之南，是南真所治之宫也。 九月十五日，梦独往桐桥山，见金庭馆，珠宝焕丽，宫室行列殊多。 亦有青黄，尽相似。 复云有金庭洞宫，自所见者，非其限，乃众仙之游憩，典司之所治耳，非王真人所居。 束方大君来时，别复有宫，虽云有而自不见。 桐相右弼，王所治之处，亦云山内外并有宫府。 九月二十三日，梦定录来於朱阳，见携到司命府，道逢玄清，紫微二夫人，乘云饼，从二十余玉女，语定录云：司命紫阳正相迟尘生，今来，亦是其冥。 意言见笑为尘生，不言是陈生。 定录答语。
chunks.translated_text:
The appointed audience was with a prominent figure of Huayang, named Jing Shangqi.

Of the thirteen entries above, two from the eighth month were real encounters, while eleven were dream journeys.

On the second day of the ninth month, I dreamed of arriving at the midst of Huayang, where I saw two lords.

On the fifth day of the ninth month, I dreamed again of journeying to Penglai. First, I visited the Controller of Destinies, who informed me: "To consume the divine elixir, your name must first be inscribed in the register of immortals; only then may you partake of it." Thereafter, I reached Penglai and met with Minister Zhou. He offered me a herb, resembling sophora blossoms but of a purple hue, and said: "You have not yet tasted this. Once you do, you shall become like me." He also spoke of fire dates and intertwined pears—these appear in the *True Reports*, though I remain uncertain of their wondrous nature.

On the eighth day of the ninth month, I dreamed of wandering through Yiqian with Minister Zhao, visiting the two palaces of Tongchu. The two palaces stood some five or six *li* apart. Yiqian was the palace of female immortals, while Tongchu was that of male immortals. Yet I remain unsure whether they were arranged east-west or north-south.

On the tenth day of the ninth month, I dreamed of accompanying the Protector of Life to a mountain, its form smooth and rounded, unlike those of the mortal realm. The mountain was called Danlong, and within its clouds lay a grotto inhabited by many immortals. Danlong, I was told, lay south of Yangluo and served as the administrative palace of the Southern Perfected.

On the fifteenth day of the ninth month, I dreamed of traveling alone to Tongqiao Mountain, where I beheld the Golden Court Lodge, resplendent with pearls and treasures. Its halls and chambers were arranged in orderly rows, their hues of blue and yellow all alike. I was further told that the Golden Court Grotto Palace existed beyond what I saw—this was merely a place of leisure for the assembled immortals, where their stewards conducted affairs, not the residence of Perfected King. When the Great Lord of the East arrived, a separate palace would be prepared, though I did not witness it. Tongxiang and Youbi, the domains governed by Perfected King, were said to have palaces both within and beyond the mountain.

On the twenty-third day of the ninth month, I dreamed that the *Dinglu* Register came to Zhuyang and led me to the Bureau of Destinies. Along the way, I encountered the Two Ladies, Xuanqing and Ziwei, who rode upon cloud-cakes accompanied by over twenty jade maidens. They addressed the *Dinglu* Register, saying: "The Controller of Destinies, Ziyang, has been delayed by mortal dust. His coming now is also due to this." This implied that I, a mortal, was the cause of his delay—though they did not refer to me as Chen Sheng. The *Dinglu* Register responded accordingly.

chunks.original_text: 云云当尔时，亦不知在何所，但觉不然而行耳。 到司命门，即见紫阳，共见。 告大有所言，非可具记。 此应有奇事也。 九月二十五日，忽梦见张理禁令，诵《道德》云云。 《道德》二篇，实道书之宗极，太极真人亦云：诵之万过，白日升天。 右从前来至此，并墨书大度西麻，几七百纸。 九月二十九日，梦见天西北有一 物，长数十丈，青赤色，首尾等大状似虹。 因到张理禁处，问此为何物。 答云：名玄霞之兽，或呼为水母，乃可愁矣。 夫有中之无，未若无中之无，空无之理，难可思议，此九六之灾显矣，人谁知之。 张为保命府禁伯，主请雨水，故以问之。 事出《真址婴，张既善谈虚无，每语辄入斯境。 隐居谓有中之无，自性空也，无中之无，毕竟空也。 但水解说，此何指耳。 右八条，九月中事，并记云梦。
chunks.translated_text:
At that moment, I knew not where I was—only that I moved without conscious will. Upon reaching the Gate of the Bureau of Destinies, I beheld Ziyang, and we met together. He spoke at length of matters too vast to record in full. This must have been an extraordinary event.

On the twenty-fifth day of the ninth month, I suddenly dreamed of Zhang Li, the Master of Prohibitions and Decrees, reciting the *Daode* in full. The two chapters of the *Daode* are indeed the ultimate essence of Daoist scriptures. The Perfected One of the Great Ultimate also said: "Recite them ten thousand times, and you shall ascend to heaven in broad daylight." From the preceding account to this point, all were written in ink on large sheets of western hemp paper, nearly seven hundred in total.

On the twenty-ninth day of the ninth month, I dreamed of a thing in the northwest of the heavens, dozens of *zhang* in length, blue and red in hue, its head and tail of equal girth, resembling a rainbow. I went to Zhang Li’s place of prohibitions and asked what this thing was. He replied: "It is called the Beast of Dark Radiance, or sometimes the Water Mother—truly a cause for sorrow. That which is non-being within being is not as profound as non-being within non-being. The principle of emptiness and nothingness is difficult to fathom. This is the manifestation of the calamity of the nine-six, yet who among men knows it?" Zhang, as the Lord of Prohibitions of the Bureau of Life Preservation, was in charge of petitioning for rain and water, hence my question to him.

This matter is recorded in the *True Records of the Infant*. Zhang was skilled in discoursing on emptiness and nothingness, and his words always entered into such realms. The Recluse said: "Non-being within being is the emptiness of self-nature; non-being within non-being is the emptiness of ultimate truth." Yet these are mere verbal explanations—what do they truly point to?

The above eight entries record the events of the ninth month, all noted in dreams.
