chunks.original_text: 十月二日，梦见洪先生，见令诵《太素祝》。 云云。 未详此出何经。 十月五日，梦见定录君，云：比来多诸进御，善自禁节，勿纵志也。 似应作恣字，既亟有上落实，宜恒加精勤也。 十一日见紫阳，定录保命桐梧来，及移朱阳事。 云云。 不知论此可否云何。 十八日，见定录，云：朱阳非尔所居处，若不能远去，只朱阳左侧，亦好良常为胜，恐尔不能处之耳。 此月十九日，隐居始移朱阳住，周亦同来，既是公馆，当虑有日之事，以为妨碍故也。 二十日，梦见南真紫微。 云云。 二十七日，梦见赵丞洪先生及星事。 云云。 犹应是司二星事耳。 二十九日，梦至一处，名为阴城之宫，大有仙人，而自不识。 未见阴城宫所出处。 右七条，十月中事。 二条云见，五条云梦。 十一月三日，梦见洪君及唐丞，言日：云间星没，唯宜瞩南山坐耳，此虽可瞻，而非求真之体。 三日，应司二星既云闻，亦不宜便眠耳。 十一月八日，梦见定录，因自陈欲寄朱阳束为小屋，未审可尔不。 答云：束好所恨，下葬为不便耳。 夫居当作四合舍，不者不可不作堂束西厢。 若不尔，名为孤凶宅，但以意作之，尔其去矣，以遗来者。 吾见陶某，比意大欲相试尔，但浮此迹，勿畏人不信，得不信，乃为吾之快矣。 东冈有两大窠。 皆可营墓，初本欲於西窠作癣恨广大，更令就窠西立察，近朱阳为好，周今定葬束窠正南向。 十三日，梦见周君言曰：陶某或信不信，多好试人，但尔比亦喧然多诸杂想，可自节。 此频频告云：陶或信不信，欲相试，今追思不意的，有不信事，自从遗想来。 凡一切有为，通无尔恨耳。 於周事实，亦谦尚，亦不乖，芳背正自惬然。 有时见其遇冗，既率意，嫌接神之体不应尔。 至於周欲别立屋，便虚心相许，自为看地，给钱一万。 伊本顾即作三问堂，东西厢各二问，林竹至而道士心未善者，互兴言说，遂不成。 复作厢，止三问堂屋而已。 今日方见事迩如此，明非已立意也。 比者微有准拟，犹欲追为起之，其留启云止请留一问，既为游旧之所，今则并修，理之不令芜杂也。 十五日，梦见洪君来告，曰：尔即欲所居西北面，有故气，吾今共汝看之。 便往至彼处，见一人，形极丑陋。 君日：此即是大都，畏人居之，定无苦。
chunks.translated_text:
On the second day of the tenth month, I dreamed of Master Hong, who instructed me to recite the *Tai Su Invocation*. The source of this text remains unclear. On the fifth day, I dreamed of the Lord of Life Register, who said: "Recently, there have been many offerings to the throne. You must restrain yourself and not indulge your desires." This likely should read "indulge" (恣), for though there have been frequent promotions and demotions, one ought to remain diligent. On the eleventh day, I saw Ziyang, the Lord of Life Register, and Tongwu of the Bureau of Life Preservation, as well as matters concerning the relocation to Zhu Yang. The details are unclear, and I do not know whether this discussion was appropriate. On the eighteenth day, I saw the Lord of Life Register again, who said: "Zhu Yang is not a place for you to dwell. If you cannot move far away, even the left side of Zhu Yang would be better than staying here, though I fear you may not be able to remain there." On the nineteenth day of this month, the Recluse first moved to reside in Zhu Yang, and Zhou also came with him. Since this is an official residence, one must consider the possibility of future events that might prove obstructive.

On the twentieth day, I dreamed of the Southern Perfected One of the Purple Tenuity. On the twenty-seventh day, I dreamed of Minister Zhao, Master Hong, and matters concerning the stars. This likely pertains to the affairs of the Two Stars. On the twenty-ninth day, I dreamed of arriving at a place called the Palace of the Shade City, where many immortals dwelled, though I did not recognize them. The origin of the Shade City Palace remains unknown.

The above seven entries record the events of the tenth month: two describe visions, and five describe dreams.

On the third day of the eleventh month, I dreamed of Lord Hong and Minister Tang, who said: "The stars in the clouds have vanished; you should gaze only toward the southern mountain. Though this may be worth observing, it is not the true essence of seeking the Dao." On the third day, since the affairs of the Two Stars had been mentioned, one should not simply rest. On the eighth day, I dreamed of the Lord of Life Register and explained my desire to build a small hut in the eastern part of Zhu Yang, but I was unsure whether this was permissible. He replied: "The eastern side is a good location, but burial there would be inconvenient. A proper dwelling should be a four-sided courtyard; otherwise, you must at least construct a main hall with eastern and western wings. If you do not, it will be called a 'lonely and inauspicious abode.' Build it as you see fit, then depart, leaving it for those who come after. I have observed Tao’s intentions—he greatly wishes to test you. Do not fear others’ disbelief; if they disbelieve, it will bring me joy."

On the eastern ridge, there are two large hollows, both suitable for constructing a tomb. Initially, I intended to build a vast structure in the western hollow, but it would be better to erect an observation platform near the western hollow, closer to Zhu Yang. Zhou has now decided to bury in the eastern hollow, facing due south.

On the thirteenth day, I dreamed of Lord Zhou, who said: "Tao may or may not believe you, for he often likes to test people. Recently, you have also been troubled by many distracting thoughts; you must restrain yourself." He repeatedly warned: "Tao may or may not believe you and wishes to test you." Upon reflection, I realize there have indeed been instances of disbelief, stemming from my own wandering thoughts. All conditioned phenomena are ultimately without regret.

In Zhou’s affairs, I have been both modest and compliant, never acting contrary to his wishes. Yet at times, I have seen him preoccupied, acting carelessly, which seems inconsistent with the proper demeanor of one who attends to the spirits. When Zhou wished to build a separate dwelling, I readily agreed and even offered to survey the land, providing ten thousand coins. He initially planned to construct a three-bay hall with two bays for eastern and western wings. However, when the trees and bamboo were planted and the Daoist’s intentions were not yet settled, disputes arose, and the plan was abandoned. Only a three-bay hall was built. Today, I see how matters have unfolded so closely—clearly, this was not my original intention. Though I had some preliminary plans and still wished to proceed, the remaining instructions stated that only one bay should be retained, as it was a place for former companions. Now, everything is to be repaired to prevent it from falling into disarray.

On the fifteenth day, I dreamed of Lord Hong, who came to tell me: "The northwest side of your intended residence has residual qi. I will go with you to examine it." We went there and saw a man of extremely ugly appearance. The Lord said: "This is the Great Capital. It is inauspicious for people to dwell here; you will certainly suffer hardship."

chunks.original_text: 朱阳绾及彼察以后，乃有两三椁，状似古冢，· 既林草榛芜，亦可经人，埋尘不见。 有巫场处所，云故气，正当魂爽辈耳，既日无苦，便不为害也。 二十日，见一女人，形容殊丽，上下青衣侍二女，至户内，立而无言。 二十六日，梦见周蓬莱，云北．斗已复不见，而祝於二星云云。 当是二十七，应司二星，今夕已阴晦，必不见也。 二十九日，梦见茅二君，周二君，并有控，乘游於雷平，直取伏龙，定录并举手见向，如谢去状。 雷早在绾东南，伏龙在西北，便升空从绾十度，故得相望也。 右七条，十一月中事。 一条云见； 六条云梦。 十二月三日，见徐瞪应作邓字。 二君，言去。 二十九日，桐梧府校籍顿误上罪人典簿，三人被责。 云云。 便不了此事所以也。
chunks.translated_text:
After Zhu Yangwan and the others had surveyed the site, two or three coffin-like structures resembling ancient tombs were discovered. Though overgrown with brambles and weeds, the place had once been trodden by people, its buried dust now unseen. There was a site for shamanic rituals, said to hold residual *qi*—precisely the abode of wandering spirits. Yet since it posed no suffering, it was deemed harmless.

On the twentieth day, I saw a woman of extraordinary beauty, attended above and below by two maidservants in blue-green robes. She stood at the threshold but spoke no word.

On the twenty-sixth day, I dreamed of Zhou Penglai, who said: "The Northern Dipper has vanished once more, and prayers were offered to the two stars," and so on. This was the twenty-seventh, the day when the two stars were to be observed. But as the evening had turned overcast, they would certainly not be visible.

On the twenty-ninth day, I dreamed of the two Lords Mao and the two Lords Zhou, all riding in a carriage, roaming over Leiping. They went straight to Fulong, where the Record-Keeper raised his hands in greeting, as if bidding farewell. Leiping lies to the southeast of the bend, while Fulong is to the northwest. Ascending into the sky from the bend at ten degrees, they could thus gaze upon one another.

Of these seven entries, the events of the eleventh month: one records a sighting, six record dreams.

On the third day of the twelfth month, I saw Xu Deng—*Deng* should have been written as 邓. The two Lords said they were departing.

On the twenty-ninth day, the Tongwu Prefecture’s registry of penal servitude was found to contain errors, and three men were punished for the oversight of the guilty in the ledgers. And so on. Thus, the matter remained unresolved.

chunks.original_text: 七日，梦往司命处，告玉清清玄事。 云云。 此所论殊高，□ 不略说也。 十一日，梦见韩夫人云：比者情志落落，弥入真相。 云云。 应是韩太华，始以七月度东宫为妃。 十九日，见一人驾大车，形容甚壮，从者十人，直见拜温冻而已。 二十一日，定录告云，前来拜者，邓都执法君蔡子迁也。 尔．方综其上官，故来通报耳。 云云，保命府职僚，皆总治邓岱丞位，弥相关涉上宫，当保籍任也。 二十五日，见赵丞直云：仙籍空矣，尔勿忧矣。 故七月中，定录所叹，亦云方忧仙籍无人。 二十八日夕，见定录，赵丞，范帅三人。 子良问所通辞，仰呈君未。 君云适得。 君仍语丞云：可速因直尔而已，更别余语。 云云。 此中似ZIJ 有事旨，不容备言，亦应是为帅见有辞存。 右七条，十二月中事。 五条云见，二条云梦。 闰月三日，梦见韩夫人云：世上方无复踪如可。 云云。 韩犹应是太华。
chunks.translated_text:
On the seventh day, I dreamed of going to the Bureau of Destiny to report matters concerning the Jade Purity and Dark Mystery. *And so on.* The discourse here was exceptionally profound, [lacuna] and thus not briefly recounted.

On the eleventh day, I dreamed of seeing Lady Han, who said: “Of late, my thoughts and aspirations have grown ever more detached, deepening into the true form.” *And so on.* This must have been Han Taihua, who was first initiated into the Eastern Palace as a consort in the seventh month.

On the nineteenth day, I saw a man driving a great carriage, his appearance most imposing, followed by ten attendants. He came only to bow before Wen Dong and then departed.

On the twenty-first day, the Record-Keeper announced: “The one who came to pay respects earlier was Cai Zijian, the Enforcer of the Deng Capital.” He had come merely to report that you were now overseeing his superior office. *And so on.* The officials of the Bureau of Life Protection all hold concurrent posts in the Deng Terrace Chancellery, which is closely connected to the Upper Palace—this pertains to the duties of the register of life.

On the twenty-fifth day, I saw Attendant Zhao, who said: “The immortal register is now empty—you need not worry.” Thus, in the seventh month, the Record-Keeper’s lament that “the immortal register has no one” was also a cause for concern.

On the twenty-eighth day at dusk, I saw the Record-Keeper, Attendant Zhao, and Marshal Fan. Ziliang asked what message had been conveyed, but the Lord had not yet received it. The Lord said he had just obtained it, then told the Attendant: “You may simply state the matter directly—say nothing more.” *And so on.* There seemed to be some hidden intent in this, which could not be fully disclosed; it was likely due to the Marshal’s lingering grievance.

Of these seven entries, the events of the twelfth month: five record sightings, two record dreams.

On the third day of the intercalary month, I dreamed of seeing Lady Han, who said: “In the world below, there are no longer any traces like this.” *And so on.* Lady Han was still likely Taihua.

On the third day of the twelfth month, I saw Xu Deng—*Deng* should have been written as 邓. The two Lords said they were departing.

chunks.original_text: 六日，见洪先生云：子勤之，勖之，前后事事也。 云云。 此亦励息耳。 十五日，见保命云：尔屋事，勿以在怀，伤人神气，其人寻来就上。 其正月、欲戴屋而所顾，师永不来。 乃云：欲作辞，告县摄之帅，定寻自来，当由此。 故有今告也。 十八日，梦大司命君问日：子欲仙。 不答，实愿仙。 云：愿仙，何，不学仙。 云云。 二十三日，见洪先生云：此所问泛舟者，乃中岳仙人干朴也，其前生经识陶某耳，非今生相识也，岂复来於此邪。 去冬，有人姓顾名道度，从外江还。 云於大雷，忽逢一人，乘小小鹿颈船，工劣容一人，从浪中来，直呼顾姓名，云：下都去，欲寄书与茅山陶隐居。 隐居已与我欲助其功夫，以献主，主正尔，见作书垂，当授与，忽云罢君会不往山，我寻自下云：此人自称姓彭，顾至都匆匆往广陵，欲宣此消息，而无方於华监问，过嗣真绾道士强，文敬因疏寄具还如此，隐居唯听其下，亦不以问周，周当是问强说自私访冥中，既如此告，便当不复自下。 二十五日，见定录保命二君。 保命日：年内多劳，扇削鬼神，三官中奏尔云多罪，吾已却之，不宜三过如此。 云云。 伊蒙神真扶奖如此。
chunks.translated_text:
On the sixth day, I saw Master Hong, who said: “Exert yourself diligently—encourage yourself in all matters, past and present.” *And so on.* This, too, was merely to urge and admonish.

On the fifteenth day, I saw the Lord of Life-Preservation, who said: “Do not let the matter of your house weigh on your mind, lest it harm your spirit and qi. The person in question will soon come to you of their own accord. In the first month, when you wished to build a house but hesitated, the master never came. Then you said you would draft a petition to inform the marshal of the county’s administration, and that he would surely come of his own accord—this is the reason for the present notice.”

On the eighteenth day, I dreamed of the Great Lord of Life-Command, who asked: “Do you wish to attain the Dao?” I did not answer, but in truth I did wish it. He said: “If you wish to attain the Dao, why do you not study the Way of immortality?” *And so on.*

On the twenty-third day, I saw Master Hong again, who said: “The one you asked about—the man who sailed the boat—was Gan Pu, an immortal of Mount Song. In a former life, he had dealings with Tao of such-and-such, but you did not know him in this life. How could he have come here? Last winter, a man named Gu Daodu returned from the outer river. He said that at Dalei, he suddenly encountered a man in a small boat no larger than a deer’s neck, poorly crafted and barely holding one person, who emerged from the waves and called out Gu’s name. The man said: ‘I am going to the capital and wish to send a letter to Tao Yinju of Maoshan. Yinju had promised to assist me in my efforts to present something to the Lord. The Lord was just then drafting a letter to bestow upon me, but suddenly said: “Since you will not go to the mountain, I will come down myself.”’ The man claimed to be surnamed Peng. Gu hurried to Guangling on his way to the capital to deliver this message, but when he inquired at Hua’s office, he missed the opportunity. He then entrusted the matter to the Daoist Qiang, a disciple of Sizhen, who recorded the details and sent them back. Yinju merely listened to the account without questioning its source. It seems Qiang had privately inquired in the unseen realm. Since this was the report given, the man should no longer come down of his own accord.”

On the twenty-fifth day, I saw the Record-Keeper and the Lord of Life-Preservation. The Lord of Life-Preservation said: “You have labored much this year, driving away and suppressing spirits and gods. The Three Offices have memorialized that you have committed many transgressions, but I have already rejected their claims. You should not repeat such conduct three times over.” *And so on.* How fortunate I am to receive such protection and favor from the divine perfected.

chunks.original_text: 不免＝一官所奏，泛庸庸之徒邪，唯各宜如履薄冰耳。 二十六日，见周君云：葛衍之束，水已加八十一丈，南衡山西边，顿崩为渊。 云云。 二十八日，见徐君云：韩众已复有事，今与邓生往看之。 云云。 此诅不众字惠期邪，众亦云作霍林司命。 岁夕梦见司命南真，南真见授一子，大如鹅卵，令瞰之。 司命云：道未成，不得九转之华，且食此，亦足明尔。 云云。 右八条，闰月中事。 六条云见，二条云梦。 右从八月初至闰月末，几六月中合五十一条事。 十六条云见，111 十五条云梦，从九月二十九日来至此，并朱书大度色纸，并纸，黄书共一纸也。 丙申年正月二日，梦造小有天，见王君云：尔何遑遑於人间，名已定，勿亏顿於世路。 云云。 此王屋山清虚王君，为下教二十四真人之首也。 十日，见洪君范帅，云：明是戊寅，上玄治建，可戴屋。 云：但宅不得其所。 洪云：大象尚复无常，人生有何定邪，只此亦好。 又及洞经事。 云云其本欲取此日戴屋，而师不来。 又小雨，遂不果。 至丁亥日，方得戴耳。 十一日，见定录保命桐相周君。 周君云：尔不复骯真道耶，吾将去尔。 子良未得答，定录乃云：其心不然，正是身废耳，紫阳试之邪。 保命云：尔何意顿取人三百斛谷。 子良答：不取。 又云：见取何意顿取人三百斛谷。 子良答：不取。 又云：见取何云不取已尔，别当埤之余，别自语所不能了。 其此数旬中，为起屋事恒伟惶不作，恐身既废，心亦是急，定录讶之耳，取谷之事，了不闻，有此音适，计三百斛谷，是百三十斛米，平人六年食，恐以为食师以此米者，其从来为师使，本是衣食弟子，不应以此为责。 伊云：不取。 神证云：取两不应妄。 又云：别当埤之思。 此答所不解。
chunks.translated_text:
The memorial from a single office concerns but mediocre men—each of you should tread as though on thin ice.

On the twenty-sixth day, I saw Lord Zhou, who said: “At the eastern reaches of Mount Ge’s ridge, the waters have risen eighty-one zhang. The western flank of Mount Heng in the south has suddenly collapsed into an abyss.” *And so on.*

On the twenty-eighth day, I saw Lord Xu, who said: “Han Zhong has resumed his affairs. Now he and Deng will go to observe them.” *And so on.* This must refer not to Huiqi but to Zhong—also called Huolin, the Controller of Destinies.

On New Year’s Eve, I dreamed of the Controller of Destinies and the Southern Perfected. The Southern Perfected handed me a child, large as a goose egg, and bade me swallow it. The Controller of Destinies said: “The Dao is not yet complete; you have not obtained the Ninefold Transformed Flower. For now, eat this—it will suffice to brighten your vision.” *And so on.*

The above eight entries pertain to matters of the intercalary month. Six are accounts of visions; two are dreams.

From the beginning of the eighth month to the end of the intercalary month—nearly six months in all—fifty-one entries were recorded. Sixteen describe visions; fifteen, dreams. From the twenty-ninth day of the ninth month onward, all were inscribed in vermilion on large, pale paper, with one sheet bearing additional yellow-script text.

On the second day of the first month of the bingshen year, I dreamed of ascending to the Lesser Heavenly Realm, where I saw Lord Wang. He said: “Why do you rush so restlessly among men? Your name is already fixed—do not falter on the worldly path.” *And so on.* This was Lord Wang of Pure Emptiness of Mount Wangwu, chief of the Twenty-Four Perfected who transmit the lower teachings.

On the tenth day, I saw Lord Hong, commander of the Fan host, who said: “The coming year is wuyin, when the Supreme Mystery’s governance begins. You may don the cap of office.” He added: “Only the dwelling is not yet properly situated.” Lord Hong replied: “Even the great cosmos is ever inconstant—what constancy can human life claim? This place will do well enough.” He also spoke of matters concerning the *Cave Scriptures*. *And so on.* Though I had intended to don the cap that day, the master did not arrive. A light rain fell besides, so the ceremony was not performed. It was not until the dinghai day that I was finally able to assume it.

On the eleventh day, I saw Lord Zhou, the Peach Record-Keeper, and the Lord of Life-Preservation. Lord Zhou said: “Will you no longer pursue the true Dao? I am about to leave you.” Before I could respond, the Record-Keeper said: “His heart is not so—it is only his body that has failed. Perhaps Ziyang is testing him.” The Lord of Life-Preservation asked: “Why did you suddenly take three hundred *hu* of grain from someone?” I answered: “I did not.” He repeated: “Why did you take it?” I again replied: “I did not.” He continued: “If you did not take it, then why say so? There must be some other matter you cannot explain.” During these past ten-day periods, I have been constantly anxious and unsettled over the construction of the house. Fearing both bodily failure and mental agitation, the Record-Keeper was surprised. As for the grain, I heard nothing of it—this was the first I had heard of such a claim. Three hundred *hu* of grain amounts to one hundred thirty *hu* of rice, enough to feed an ordinary person for six years. I suspect this refers to grain meant for the master’s sustenance. Since I have long served as the master’s disciple, providing for his clothing and food, it would be improper to hold me accountable for this. I said: “I did not take it.” The divine witness declared: “To take or not take—neither should be falsely claimed.” He added: “You must reflect further on this.” This answer I did not understand.

chunks.original_text: 十四夕，梦见许仙侯等五人，自共语。 许云：自宅此宇，未足久便，已近二百许年。 又闻一人答：兆劫尚复倏尔，此何足为远。 不知是谁许长史立山宅，应是晋穆帝永和中，至今一百六七十年耳。 十七夕，见定录唐丞来，中君云：许侯近所言，亦深哉。 唐丞论北台事极多，非可书铭，北台邓都北帝台。 二十四夕，见定录君云：念真不密，秽气无辩，自云研莹之云云。 二十七日，见保命及洪君。 洪君云：勿轻说人事。 云云。 此当有所试，不知是何耳。 右七条起，丙申年正月中事。 四条云见，二条云梦。 三月三日，梦见洪先生云北斗事。 云云。 此复是司二星也，洪是授云，故屡屡言之。 七日，梦见定录云：临海烧山中，有仙人游在人问，自号彭先生，实是郑玄，字子阴，陆浑仙人也。 朱交甫令其观上人情及修道者，其寻或当来，先昨已往建安，临海人书与道士邹尧云：某人彭公在此，不尧得而插静棂，故人得见之。 其人亟乘一刀一刀小船。 而歌日：太霄何冥冥，灵真时下游，命我嚣涂除，采察云中俦，世路多淫浊，真诚不可搜，促驾还陆岭，人间无与酬。 步行亦咏此，其若来，可不接之。 其人形中人，面左边有紫志，着黄绢帽，多髯，而前齿缺是也。 书此一条，独委曲者，当是或欲，示后人也。 烧山即赤水山，今亦属永宁乐，或三县共界，未知邹尧是何处人，显昭形服，如此便是可察，正恐伊知人识，更复改容耳。 九日，见赵丞云：比者情志，何甚索索。 云云。
chunks.translated_text:
On the fourteenth night, I dreamed of Xu Xianhou and four others conversing among themselves. Xu said: “This dwelling of mine has not been long established—barely two hundred years or so.” Another replied: “Cosmic kalpas pass in the blink of an eye; what is this to speak of as distant?” I did not know who it was, but someone mentioned that Changshi Li had built his residence on the mountain during the Yonghe reign of Emperor Mu of Jin—only a hundred and sixty or seventy years ago.

On the seventeenth night, I saw Attendant Dinglu and Tang Cheng arrive. The Middle Lord said: “What Lord Xu said recently was most profound.” Tang Cheng discoursed at length on the affairs of the Northern Terrace—too much to inscribe in full. The Northern Terrace is the Terrace of the Northern Emperor in Dengdu.

On the twenty-fourth night, Attendant Dinglu said: “When thoughts are not kept secret, impure qi cannot be distinguished—he spoke of refining and polishing, and so on.”

On the twenty-seventh day, I saw the Lord of Life-Preservation and Lord Hong. Lord Hong said: “Do not speak lightly of others’ affairs.” And so forth. This must be some kind of trial, though I know not what.

The above seven entries pertain to matters in the first month of the *bingshen* year. Four entries record visions; two, dreams.

On the third day of the third month, I dreamed of Master Hong speaking of the Northern Dipper. And so forth. This again concerns the two stars he oversees, for Hong was the one who transmitted the teaching, hence his repeated mention of them.

On the seventh day, I dreamed that Attendant Dinglu said: “In the mountains of Linhai, where the forests have burned, a transcendent wanders among the people, calling himself Master Peng. In truth, he is Zheng Xuan, styled Ziyin, the immortal of Luhun. Zhu Jiaofu sent him to observe the dispositions of men and those who cultivate the Dao. He may come seeking you soon—he has already gone to Jian’an. A man of Linhai wrote to the Daoist Zou Yao, saying: ‘Master Peng is here, and I, Yao, have not yet been able to withdraw into quietude, so others have been able to meet him.’ The man swiftly boarded a small boat with a single oar. He sang:

*How vast and dark the Great Empyrean,
The numinous ones descend in timely flight.
They charge me to sweep the dust from the path,
To seek and examine the companions of the clouds.
The world’s roads are steeped in defilement,
True sincerity cannot be fathomed.
I urge my carriage back to Lu Ridge—
In the human realm, none are my match.*

He also chanted this while walking. If he comes, do not receive him.” The man appeared of middling stature, with a purple mark on the left side of his face. He wore a yellow silk cap, had a full beard, and was missing his front teeth. This entry is recorded in such detail, perhaps to provide a sign for later generations. The “burned mountain” is Red Water Mountain, now part of Yongning District, though it may lie at the border of three counties. I do not know where Zou Yao is from, but his appearance and attire are so distinctive that he should be easy to recognize—though I fear he may alter his form if he knows others can identify him.

On the ninth day, I saw Attendant Zhao, who said: “Lately, your spirit and will—why are they so listless?” And so forth.

chunks.original_text: 十四日，见定录云：司命来月中旬当来，西宫束官人，亦并来，故逆示。 云云。 此当是云三月十八日事，见其此日亦有辞本存也。 二十日，梦见司命君，君见，令取青此一字章漫，永不可识也。 以呈司命。 司命云：此可耳，心未真也。 当更研莹，见景上期来云：二君今往龟山，聊过令知如此所见，意气欲动，前与人戏过，致使时魅相侵，赖得高监相为，不尔几致变。 闻周在第中，忽辅痛恐是此意。 高监不知谁，洞中不见此人也。 又曰：裹屋人自称不道士者，是北星鬼官所使，勿信之。 以邪情亟惑人，坏人真气，可急诣许，驾去已远，不得久停，便去。 周在都仍就王法明同住南庾第道士馆中，在外屋宿，当是欲进诸木问事？ 故得此，告其还多有问木者，而都不说，此事实能慎密也。 二十五日，见唐赵一．一丞来云，还於旧居，便共觉萧然，多论九转事。 云云并二君令告。 云云。 其是二＋三日，还至山意殊不许游行人问，九转事无闻，一何可叹也。 右六条，二月中书。 五条云见，一条云梦。 三月三日，见保命告勿食草之正心及余事。 云云。 紫文仙忌云尔，止谓此一日耳。 八日，见赵丞云天下邪鬼之事，令慎之诸。 云云。 二十九日，见保命云：勿犯雾露。 云云。 右三条事，三月中事。 并云见。 四月九日，见定录云前疏文辞殊雅，但恐心不必然耳。 云云。 不见此辞本也。
chunks.translated_text:
On the fourteenth day, I saw Attendant Dinglu, who said: “The Lord of Life will come in the middle of next month, and the West Palace’s Attendant Shu will also arrive together—thus I forewarn you.” And so forth. This likely refers to the eighteenth day of the third month, as I have seen a written record of his words from that day.

On the twentieth day, I dreamed of the Lord of Life. Upon meeting him, he ordered me to fetch a green *ci*-chapter—this single character is blurred beyond recognition. I presented it to the Lord of Life, who said: “This will do, but your heart is not yet true. You must further refine and polish it.” Later, I saw Attendant Jingshang, who said: “The two lords have now gone to Tortoise Mountain. I pass this on so you may know. Your emotions stirred, and after jesting with someone earlier, you allowed demonic influences to encroach. Fortunately, Senior Overseer Gao intervened, or it might have led to disaster. I heard Zhou was in the capital and suddenly suffered from pain and fear—this was likely the reason.” I do not know who Senior Overseer Gao is; he is not among those in the grotto. He also said: “The man who wraps his house and claims not to be a Daoist is an agent of the Northern Star’s Ghost Official—do not trust him. His perverse desires swiftly delude people and corrupt their true *qi*. Hurry to Xu; he has already departed far and cannot stay long—leave at once.”

Zhou remained in the capital and stayed with Wang Faming in the Daoist lodge of the Southern Yushu Residence, sleeping in the outer chamber. Was this to consult the wooden divination blocks? That is how he came by this. I told him that many others had inquired about the blocks, but he said nothing in the capital—this matter truly requires discretion.

On the twenty-fifth day, Attendant Tang Zhao arrived and said he had returned to his former residence. Together, we felt a profound emptiness and discussed the Ninefold Refinement at length. And so forth—both lords instructed him to convey this. And so forth. It was the twenty-second or twenty-third day when he returned to the mountain, but he was utterly unwilling to entertain visitors’ questions. No word of the Ninefold Refinement reached me—how lamentable!

The above six entries were recorded in the second month: five describe encounters, and one a dream.

On the third day of the third month, I saw the Lord of Longevity, who warned against eating the heart of grass and other matters. And so forth. The *Purple Text of the Immortals’ Taboos* states this, though it refers only to this single day.

On the eighth day, I saw Attendant Zhao, who spoke of the world’s demonic spirits and urged caution in all things. And so forth.

On the twenty-ninth day, I saw the Lord of Longevity, who warned: “Do not violate the mist and dew.” And so forth.

The above three entries pertain to the third month, all describing encounters.

On the ninth day of the fourth month, I saw Attendant Dinglu, who said: “The earlier memorial’s language was most refined, though I fear your heart may not fully align with it.” And so forth. I have not seen the original text of this memorial.

chunks.original_text: 右三条，六月中事。 一条云见，二条云梦。 七月一日，见洪先生云：八霞之表，已陈尔居处，束莱可不装束，云云大多不可复载。 ，此中当说去留文会。 八日，复梦见韩侯，紫微，杨君，定录等，多为论性命之致，因绿罪福之源，若疏此可三四纸许。 不闻此，亦为殊恨也。 十七日，见保命赵丞，多论天地灾横之事，亦甚多不可记。 此事理难当说。 二十三日，见众真凡三十人，多论人治身之本，谢殃之法甚多。 亦复论作九转事。 云云。 此条不显为恨最深。 右四条，七月中事。 三条云见，一条云梦，从六月初来，共纸一大度白栈纸也。 右从丙申年正月初至七月末，几七月，中合二十八条。 十八条云见，十条云梦。 右从目录，凡用墨朱黄三色书大度白及细纸，合十六番。 八番白，八番色。 并右从去乙未年五月二十三日初通，至今丙申年七月末，合一百九条。 六十三条云见，四十六条1百梦。 从八月初至十月二十七日，舍世凡三月日，中文书记，不复显出。 寻入今年来，月月所记，自疏简未知是，不复悉记，为时近致希邪。 周紫阳记，《九真玉沥丹方》。 云轻於九转，易於九转，此别一纸，无日月。 九茎紫菌琅葛芝一斤。 出南闽，句曲北亦有。 丹朱玉浆二斗。 出南闽，此问亦有也。 右二物，细切芝，竟仍以玉浆一斗渍之一宿，埋阴垣之阳，去垣三寸，入土一尺，以白瓦器容四斗许盛，仍以瓦盘盖之，蜡密封之上，土令厚二寸，以今日午时埋，至明日午时出之。 持之南行，取己所住户十二步，乃置眠林头。 按上至明日午时，又以铜器盛煎之，令火齐器底，勿令火艳出器边也。 得三沸，竟又内玉浆一斗，又加火高初五分许，可以蓬蒿为薪煎，令余一斗洒滓乾之闭汁三日。 三日竟开，视上当有紫光曜目，夜不用然灯，此即成矣。 又以药滓置木臼中，捣三百二十杵，纸裹令密。 若以投水，水流即停。 若封屋室，万人不能开。 若俪劫贼，合众不能动。 封山，山开，封人，人伏。 若欲速登天，可并服之，即死矣。 若欲且留世，当稍服之，尽亦仙矣。 勿以分人，及令人知见也。 唯可心知口服而已，若令人知，空失此药也。 右此一方，无年月日，不知何时书，满一白栈纸。 谨正。 此药名既又云，唯可心知，便是难可思详，已历问同住人，大小咸云，不觉见垣内埋药，亦不闻木臼捣声，恐或别处作，不论耳。 即云服之即死，故追以疑，虽见温酒，亦或假以乱之耳言。 大凡四卷真本，书杂色，合六十五番，或真，或草行。 周氏具通记卷之四竟

Here follows the translation:

---

The above three entries pertain to matters of the sixth month. One records what was seen, and two record dreams.

On the first day of the seventh month, I met with Master Hong, who said: "Beyond the eightfold radiance, your dwelling has already been arranged. There is no need to prepare the bundled herbs." And so on—much of it cannot be fully recorded. Herein should be discussed matters of departure and staying, and the gathering of texts.

On the eighth day, I dreamed again of Marquis Han, the Purple Forbidden Enclosure, Master Yang, and the Register of Destiny. Much was said concerning the subtleties of nature and life, tracing the roots of sin and fortune. Had it been written down, it would have filled three or four sheets of paper. Not to have heard it is a deep regret.

On the seventeenth day, I met with Attendant Zhao of the Preservation of Life. Much was discussed regarding the calamities and disasters of Heaven and Earth—too much to record. The principles of these matters are difficult to expound.

On the twenty-third day, I saw a gathering of immortals, thirty in all. Much was said on the fundamentals of human cultivation and the methods of averting misfortune. They also discussed the work of the Ninefold Transmutation. And so on. This entry, being unclear, is the deepest regret.

The above four entries pertain to matters of the seventh month. Three record what was seen, and one records a dream. Since the beginning of the sixth month, all together they fill one large sheet of white *zhan* paper.

From the first month to the end of the seventh month of the *bingshen* year, nearly seven months have passed, comprising twenty-eight entries in total. Eighteen record what was seen, and ten record dreams.

The above is the table of contents. It is written in three colors—black, vermilion, and yellow—on large white and fine paper, totaling sixteen folios: eight white and eight colored.

From the initial communication on the twenty-third day of the fifth month of the *yiwei* year to the end of the seventh month of the present *bingshen* year, there are altogether one hundred and nine entries: sixty-three recording what was seen, and forty-six recording dreams.

From the eighth month to the twenty-seventh day of the tenth month, when I departed this world, a span of three months, the written records are no longer clearly preserved.

Reviewing the entries made month by month since the beginning of this year, I have been careless and do not know if they are complete. Perhaps the times have grown sparse, and so I have not recorded everything.

Recorded by Zhou Ziyang, *The Elixir Formula of the Jade Fluid of the Nine Perfected*.

It is said to be lighter than the Ninefold Transmutation and easier than the Ninefold Transmutation. This is on a separate sheet, without date.

One *jin* of the nine-stemmed purple fungus, *langge* zhi. It comes from southern Min, and is also found north of Juqu.

Two *dou* of cinnabar-red jade nectar. It comes from southern Min, and is also found in this region.

For the above two ingredients, finely chop the fungus, then soak it overnight in one *dou* of jade nectar. Bury it on the yang side of a shaded wall, three *cun* from the wall and one *chi* deep in the earth. Use a white ceramic vessel holding about four *dou* to contain it, and cover it with a ceramic plate. Seal it tightly with wax, then cover it with two *cun* of earth. Bury it at noon today and retrieve it at noon tomorrow. Carry it southward to a point twelve paces from the door of your dwelling, and place it at the head of a sleeping grove.

From the time of retrieval until noon the following day, boil it in a bronze vessel, ensuring the fire is level with the bottom of the vessel and does not flare beyond its edges. After three boilings, add the remaining *dou* of jade nectar, then increase the fire by about five *fen*, using mugwort or thatch as fuel. Reduce it until only one *dou* remains, then dry the dregs and seal the liquid for three days. After three days, open it: a purple radiance should shine forth, visible even at night without lamplight. This indicates the elixir is complete.

Next, place the dregs in a wooden mortar and pound them three hundred and twenty times. Wrap them tightly in paper. If thrown into water, the water will halt in its flow. If used to seal a house, ten thousand men could not open it. If used to bind bandits, a mob could not move. If used to seal a mountain, the mountain will open; if used to seal a person, the person will submit.

If one wishes to ascend to Heaven swiftly, one may consume both the liquid and the dregs together—though this will result in death. If one wishes to remain in the world for a time, one should consume them gradually, and in the end, one will attain immortality.

Do not share this with others or let anyone witness its use. It may only be known in the heart and consumed in secret. If others learn of it, this medicine will be wasted in vain.

The above is one formula, without year, month, or day. It is not known when it was written, but it fills one sheet of white *zhan* paper.

Respectfully corrected.

The name of this medicine is also said to be "known only in the heart," making it difficult to ponder in detail. I have inquired of all those living with me, young and old alike, and none recall seeing the medicine buried within the wall, nor hearing the sound of pounding in the wooden mortar. Perhaps it was prepared elsewhere—no matter. It is said that consuming it results in death, which gives me pause. Even if warm wine is offered, it may be a ruse to confuse.

In all, there are four volumes of the original text, written in various colors, totaling sixty-five folios, some in standard script, some in cursive.

*Comprehensive Records of the Zhou Clan, Volume Four* ends here.
